Suit for Specific Performance Contract—petitioner praying for impleading him in the suit as defendant on the ground that he is possessing the suit premise, and also carrying on business in the same as tenant under the vendors. His further contention is that as the vendor left for India as per provision of State Acquisition and Tenancy Act the property vested in the Government—it appears that the High Court Division considered the judgment of the trial court and the case of the present petitioner. It was found by the High Court Division that in such a suit the petitioner is not a necessary party as he is a third party. It was also found that in such. a suit only consideration is whether the vendors have executed ‘Bainapatra’ or not. In the suit, the Government who has allegedly taken over the property has entered appearance and contesting the same. The High Court Division found that in such a situation the presence of the present petitioner in the suit is not necessary—we are of the view that the High Court Division as well as the trial Court rightly rejected the petition filed under Order 1 Rule 10 read with section 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

Md. Abdul Hye Vs. Md. Rafiqul Islam Talukder & Ors 8BLT (AD)-301.

Order-1 Rule-10

Principle-addition of a party

Needless to state that the added defendants have direct interest in suit land. Therefore it cannot be said that the added defendants are neither proper nor necessary parties to the suit. The appearance of the added defendants in the suit were therefore correctly thought necessary by the Court to adjudicate the questions relating to possession of the suit land. Moreover, for any effectual decree for possession that may be passed in the suit, the presence of the added defendants is not only of proper but also necessary.

Fulbaria Adarsha Market Dokandar Malik Samity Vs. Fulbaria Adarsha Market Khatigrastha Dokandar Kallyan Samabaya Samity 9BLT (HCD)-157

Order-1 Rule-10

Addition of Parties

In a suit for specific performance of contract the Court is called upon to determine whether the disputed contract is a lawful one and if it is legally enforceable. The Court is not at all concerned to consider the question of title, A person who is not a party to the contract cannot be added as a defendant in the suit to plead his title.

Shubhoda Ranjan Dutta Vs. Md Yusuf& Ors. 9BLT (HCD)-247

Order-1 Rule-10

The Court has enough power under Order-1Rule-10 of the Code to implead any person in the suit at any stage of the proceedings when his presence is found necessary for effective and complete adjudication of the suit. But an applicant claiming title in portion of the suit property acquired during the pendency of the suit, cannot be added as a party in the suit, the question of title being outside the scope of such a proceeding

Sri Rajeswar Dhar & Anr. Vs. Srimati Anima Chowdhury & Ors. 9BLT (HCD)-332

Order-1 Rule-10

Belated stage—the application for addition of parties was filed after closing of the examination of the witnesses of the plaintiff—in the instant case the petitioner instituted the suit for rectification of the deed in question. The deed was executed by Abdul Jalil Sk. Abdul Jabbar Sk. and Abdul Gafur Sk. Abdu Gafur died and his heirs have been left out as defendants in the suit. In that view of the matter, the presence of the heirs of Abdul Gafur Sk. is necessary for effectually and completely to adjudicate upon the suit. Therefore, the heirs of the Abdul Gafur Sk. as mentioned in the application are necessary parties in the suit.

Tajem Ali Mridha Vs Md. Khajem Ali Mridha & Ors. 10 BLT (HCD)-365

Order-1 Rule-10

The respondent Nos. 1-6 would have no cause for concern to proceed with the instant suit in order to secure their interest on the basis of their alleged agreement with the plaintiff of the instant suit and in case the plaintiff did not proceed with the suit before the trial Court, the respondents may have a cause to be impleaded in the suit and to get themselves transposed as the plaintiff in the suit.

Sheikh Shanaz Begum & Ors. Vs. Hazera Khatun I2BLT(AD)-22

Order-1 Rule-10 read with President Order No. 16 of 1972

Allottee is not a necessary party before the Court of Settlement. The necessary party is Ministry of Housing and public Works.

Dhaka Metropolitan Police Commissioner Vs. Dhaka Land (Pvt) Ltd. & Ors 9BLT (AD)-64

Order-1 Rule-10(1)

Held: we are not inclined to add the applicants who are subsequent purchasers of certain floors of the Building constructed with the said plan under order of challenge or cancellation, who are subsequent purchasers of some floors of the Rangs Bhaban as parties in the appeals and the applications for addition of party are, accordingly, rejected.

Chairman, RAJUK & Anr, Vs. A. Rouf Chowdhury & Ors 16 BLT (AD)279

Order-1 Rule-10(2)

Court’s Power to add or strike out parties

Order 1 Rule 10 of the Code of Civil Procedure empowers the Court to add any person to a suit or to strike out the names of any person improperly impleaded therein at any stage of the proceeding if the Court considers the presence of such a party necessary or unnecessary, as the case may be, for the effective adjudication of the proceedings before it. Since the petitioners were not at the scene when the suit was filed but they became interested in the result of the suit subsequently, they cannot be made coplaintiff, over the head of the unwilling plaintiffs. But they should be made defendants in the suit to have their full say in the matter for protecting their interest.

Md. Zahirul Haque Chowdhury & Anr. Vs. Sanker Lal  Deb & Ors. 7BLT (HCD)-1

 

 

Order-1 Rule-10 (2)

Petitioners are to be added as defendants in the suit admittedly the petitioners are in actual possession of a portion of the suit land by way of lease wherein they have constructed a small hut and have been running small shop therein and they are very much interested in the result of the suit and their interests cannot be properly safe guarded by the lessor as contended by the petitioners counsel—Held Learned Sr. Assistant Judge without proper application of his judicial mind to the facts and circumstances of the case and proper appreciation of the scope of Order-1 Rule- 10(2) of the Code of Civil Procedure wrongly and arbitrarily rejected the prayer of the petitioners for impleading there as dependants—the prayer for addition of parties be allowed.

Gobinda Chondra Karmaker Vs. Shanti Ranjan Talukder. 4BLT (HCD)-73

Order 1 Rule — 10(2)

As in the instant case, did not sanction and allow any loan to the defendant Nos.3 and 4, rather the Bank sanctioned loan to the defendant Nos.1 and 2 and allowed said defendants to avail the loan granted and as such it is the liability to the defendant Nos. l and 2 to pay back the dues against the loan.- Held: the High Court Division has committed no error in refusing to interfere with the order of the trial Court striking out the names of the defendant Nos.3 and 4.

Sonali Bank Vs. Md. Sirajul Hoque Chowdhury &Ors 14BLT(AD)128

Order 1 Rule 10(2)

In a suit for specific performance of contract the claim of title of a third party cannot be considered and as such the plea of the petitioner that having title in the suit property he is required to be impleaded as defendant does not inspire us at all to interfere in the matter.

Jamir Ahmed Vs. Siddique Ahmed Sowdagor & Ors 14BLT(AD)16

Order 1 Rule 10(2)

Belated application —Order 1 Rule 10(2) specially provides that the Court may at any stage of the proceeding it seems that the name of any person who ought to have been joined either as plaintiff or as defendant and whose presence before the Court is necessary in order to enable the Court effectually and completely to adjudicate upon and settled all the questions involved in the suit, be added as party either as plaintiff or as defendant.

Ahmed Hossain & Ors Vs. Md. Samsur Ali Mondal & Ors 15 BLT (HCD)181

Order 1 rule 10 (2) read with Order 22 rule-10

Whether the recipients of the disputed deeds were necessary party or not

It is the definite case of the plaintiff that cause of action of the suit arose on 27th October, 1969. The suit was filed on September 3, 1976. Thereafter on July 10, 1988 plaintiff filed petition seeking amendment of the plaint by inserting some facts as well as an additional relief i.e. b (1) seeking declaration that the deeds bearing Nos.l6157 and 16158 dated 27.10.1969 showing transfer of the property at 62 BCC Road to Ali Ahmed Khandker and Wali Mohammad Siddiqui by Jatindra Mohon Roy alias Sachindra Mohon Roy is forged, fabricated and that the transfers by the said Ali Ahmed Khandker and Wali Mohammad Siddiqui, to the defendant Nos.1 and 2 are illegal and not binding on the plaintiff. This prayer for amendment was allowed on November 19, 1988 —the plaintiff having had realized that in the absence of a declaration as was sought for in relief (b) (1) the other reliefs prayed for in the suit even if granted would not be complete one and thus the plaintiff having had sought for relief against the recipients of the deeds dated October 27, 1969 the recipients thereof were required to be made party and having had not impleaded the recipients of the deeds of October 27, 1969 the suit was certainly bad for defect of party so far the same concerned with relief (b)(1).

A N M W Nabi & Anr Vs. Md.Balai Roy & Ors 15BLT(AD)27

Order-1 Rule-10 (2) Read with Order-6 RuIe-17 and State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950 Section-96 (2)

Amendment of the pleadings by way of addition of a party at a belated stage —A belated prayer for addition of necessary parties or for amendment of pleadings by itself is no ground to refuse such a prayer if such addition or amendment of pleadings be found necessary for complete and effectual adjudication of the matters in issue— relied on 33 DLR(AD) 113.

Mst Hasina Khatoon & Anr. Vs. Md. Shamsur Rahrnan & Anr. 5BLT (HCD)-22

Order —2 Rule —2

Suit for a declaration of Title in 4 annas share to the Suit Property —Held: from the evidence it appears that the plaintiff is not in possession in 4 anna share in the suit land. In a suit for declaration of title it is incumbent upon the plaintiff to prove his exclusive possession. There is nothing on record to show that the plaintiff is in possession upon any portion of the suit land. Admittedly the plaintiff was a co-shaerer to the suit holding. Order 2 Rule 2 of the Code of Civil Procedure provides that every suit shall include the whole of the claim which the plaintiff is entitled to make in respect of the cause of action but a plaintiff may relinquish any portion of his claim in order to bring the suit within the jurisdiction of any Court. Thus in the instant suit, the plaintiff being not in possession ought to have sought two relieves, one for declaration of ejmali possession with defendant and thereafter for partition by metes and bounds in the suit land. That has not been done in the instant suit. The learned Additional District Judge has totally failed to consider this aspect and decreed the suit erroneously.

Abu Taher & Ors Vs. Joytuner Nessa & Ors 14 BLT (HCD)522

Order-3 Rules-1 and 2

A person not a party to the suit nor a husband nor wife nor an attorney got no authority to give testimony in a suit in support of the case either of the plaintiff or the defendant.

Mohammad Azim & Ors. Vs. Doly islam & Ors. 7BLT (HCD)-164

Order 3 rule 1 read with, Order 5 rule 3(2)

Provision in the proviso to Order 3 Rule I relates to compliance of order of the Court by any party for appearance in person and the other provision of Order 5 Rule 3(2) CPC relates to compliance of the order of the Court directing the plaintiff to appear in person before the Court on specified date. As per provision of law referred to above it is the Court that may require a party itself to appear before the Court.

A N M W Nabi & Anr Vs. Md.Balai Roy & Ors 15 BLT (AD) 27

Order-3 Rule-2

Under the provisions, a party to a proceeding shall sign the pleading. But when he cannot sign such pleading either for absence or other-wise anyone who is duly authorized by him can sign or to sue or defend on his behalf. If one resides abroad permanently, the provisions of Order III Rule 2 of the Code requires the plaint or such pleading initiating an original proceeding to be signed by a person duly authorized under Order III Rule 2 of the Code, Provisions of order III Rule 2 empowers amongst other a duly constituted attorney to make appearance applications and/or to do acts for and on behalf of such absent party.

Md. Shah Alum Vs. Abul Kalam & Ors. 10 BLT (HCD)-22

Order-3 Rule-4 (1)

The Court found that the power of attorney is forged and fabricated—The Court shall debar the Advocate to act for the party in the court, for the simple reason that he has not been appointed for the purpose by or under a valid power of attorney and has therefore no authority to act on behalf of the party in the Court. The disability attaches to the Advocate and not to the plaint, in such circumstances the trial court ought to have direct for further correct and better power of attorney—May be it was forged and fabricated but that cannot be a ground for disposal of the case

Mathura Mohan Pandit Vs. Most Hazera Khatun 2BLT (HCD)-215

Order 4 rule – 1

A review is never meant nor can be allowed to be utilized as another opportunity for rehearing a matter which has already been closed by a final judgment.

Md. Abdul Mannan Akand Vs. Md. Lutfar Rahman & Ors 14 BLT (AD)211

Order-5 Rule-14

Personal appearance — No party to be ordered to appear in person residing over 200 miles from the court.

M. S. Progati Industries Ltd. Vs. Md. Abdul Majid Mondal & Ors. 5BLT (HCD)-151

Order-5 RuIe-14

The summons of the original pre-emption case was served on the husband of the preempteerespondent—The High Court Division rightly held that—in the instant case there is no evidence that the husband of the pre-empteerespondent was the recognised agent of hers. Therefore the summons was not duly served upon the pre-emptee-respondent.

Abdur Rahman. Vs. Shamsun Nahar Begum & Ors. 7BLT (AD)-125

Order-5 Rule-16, 17 & 18 read with Civil Rules and Order Rule-69

Onus— it was a case of service by affixing of copy of the summons as the petitioners (defendants) refused to receive the summons exhibit “A and on close scrutiny of the exhibit A” it is found to be not satisfactory which has already been indicated that the date of receipt of the summons by the process server appears to have interpolated and tried to make 01.03.1991 from 02.03.1991— it appears that the Courts below tried to shift the onus upon the petitioner to prove service of the summons but in fact when the petitioner came up with the allegations that the summons were not served in that case the onus lies upon the persons who supported and claimed the benefit under the expartee and have to show that the summons were legally served.

Abul Kashem Vs. Md. Selim & Ors. 9BLT (HCD)-31 7

Order-5 Rule-17

It appears that on the refusal to receive the summons, the same was served by hanging and accordance with law in presence of mokabela witnesses namely, DWs 4 and 5. In that view of the matter the petitioner’s plea that summons was not served upon them is not tenable at all.

Lokman Fakir & Ors. Vs. Abdul Jabber Bayati & Ors. 7BLT(AD)-19

 

Order-5 Rules - 17 & 19

In this case, P.W. 2 the process server appeared and testified that summons were duly served. The learned Single Judge of the High Court Division found that apart from the declaration on the return of process server that summons were duly served, notices with acknowledgement dues were posted in the correct addresses of the defendants. The return of acknowledgement dues with postal endorsement clearly showed that notices were refused by the defendants. It is on record that along with service of summons, simultaneously notices with postal acknowledgement dues were sent in the correct addresses of the defendants. Apart from this, the defendants stated that they came to know about the ex parte decree from one Dinabandhu in presence of Rabindra Nath Biswas but curiously enough the said Dinabandhu was not examined by the defendants. The question of taking recourse to Rules 17 and 19 of Order does not arise in the present case.

Nimai Chandra Pal & Ors Vs. Krishna Pada Karmaker & Ors 8BLT (AD)-32

Order 5 Rule 19A

The Judge concerned must take into cognizance the service into evidence on his expressed satisfaction and otherwise, it means that he shall record his satisfaction in his exparte decree about the service of summons. Before proceeding for exparte disposal, a judge needs to record that the summons have been served upon the Defendants to his satisfaction and only after that, he can proceed for ex-parte disposal.

Atar Ali & Ors Vs. Hasan Ali 13BLT(HCD)469

Order-6 Rule-17

Whether in making the prayer for partition by amendment, would change the nature and character of the suit.

(a) The principle is that the nature and character of a suit do not change so long as the fundamental character of the suit remains the same. A suit for declaration of title recovery of possession and/or for partition is essentially based on a common claim of the plaintiff which may call for aforesaid different relief or reliefs in different situations—by adding a relief for partition in a suit for declaration of title and possession there was no alteration to the foundation of the suit and as such the fundamental character of the suit remained the same, there being thus no question of changing the nature and character of the suit appeal allowed.

Abdul Motaleb Vs Md. Ershad Ali & Ors. 2BLT (AD)-164

(b) While allowing or rejecting an amendment of a pleading and for that matter while exercising any discretion under law, the Court must give its reasons so that when the order is balled in question the higher Court may be in a position to see that there has been application of mind by the Court concerned and it was aware of the principles involved in the exercise of its discretion.

Abdul Motaleb Vs Md. Ershad All & Ors. 2BLT (AD)-164

Order-6 Rule-17

The evidence on the side of the plaintiffs having been closed and all the plaintiffs witnesses having been examined and cross-examined, a completely new story was attempted to be added in the additional written statement—the learned Single Judge of course observed in his judgment that there is inordinate delay in filing this application for amendment of the written statement but he allowed this by holding that the same can be compensated by giving money and consequently awarded cost of Tk. 1000/- as compensation to the plaintiffs—the principle guiding the amendment of the written statement as contemplated under the law has not been taken note of and the learned Single Judge allowed these revision cases taking a sympathetic view in the matter which is not permitted by law — that the orders passed by the learned Single Judge need be set aside.

Abul Kalam Azad & Ors Vs Sundar Ali & Ors. 2BLT (AD)-4

Order-6 Rule- 17

Amendment of the plaint—in the instant case the radical changes were sought to be introduced in the plaint by the amendment sought for and allowed by the court. On the other hand the learned Assistant Judge has not discussed the merit of the application or of the nature and character of the amendment sought for but has passed a summary order allowed the amendment of the plaint. This is no way is a judicial order. The Court didn’t apply its judicial mind in passing the impugned order—Case is allowed.

 Samela Begum Vs Chandullya Midha & Anr. 3 BLT (HCD)-130.

Order-6 Rule-17

(a) The guiding principle for amendment is that it ought to be made for the purpose of determining the real question in controversy between the parties to any proceeding or for correcting any defect or error in any proceeding. There lies inherent power of the court and the principle applicable to the amendment of the plaint is also applicable to the amendment of the written statement.

Md. Nazrul Islam Mujumder Vs Tahmina Akhter 2BLT (HCD)-131

(b) The amendment of the plaint in family court case — the amendment was sought for by the wife in her own suit the certain fact had happened after the institution of the suit and it is necessary to be taken into notice of the court by way of an amendment for doing complete justice and to settle the real controversy between the parties — The Family Court allowed the said amendment and the learned District Judge affirmed the same — the courts below had rightly done so.

Md. Nazrul Islam Mujumder Vs Tahmina Akhter 2BLT (HCD)-131

Order-6 Rule-17

Amendment of the plaint — During pendency of the civil revision the petitioner filed a petition for amendment of the plaint of the partition suit praying for declaration of title of the petitioner to the suit land — the petitioner prayed for partition of the share of his predecessor in interest and since the opposite party has no claim over this portion of land. The opposite party will not suffer any injury if the amendment is allowed for proper adjudication of the suit— amendment be allowed.

Md. Hurmuj Ali Sheikh Vs Amullah Ch. Guha Chowdhury & Ors. 2 BLT (HCD)-195

Order-6 Rule-17

From the reading of the assertions made in the original written statement and in the proposed amendment it appears that the defendant No 3 wanted to change the entire stand taken by her in the earlier written statement. At this the plaintiff will be prejudiced. The application for amendment was rightly rejected by the Subordinate Judge.

Shawkat Ara Begum Vs Md. Wajuddin & Ors. 2BLT (HCD)-226

Order-6 Rule- 17

The plaintiff opposite party instituted title suit against the defendant. Petitioners for declaration of plaintiffs title in eight katha of land and for recovery of khas possession of petitioners No. 1 and 2 and another—During the cross-examination the plaintiff opposite party filed an application for amendment of the plaint — in the plaint it has been clearly stated that a boundary wall existed between the land of the plaintiff and the defendant petitioners. The plaintiff should have made a prayer in the plaint for demolition of the existing boundary wall between the plaintiffs and the petitioner’s land. It appears that plaintiff omitted to make a prayer for the same. As such the plaintiff should not be allowed to make a prayer by way of amendment at this stage as contended by the learned petitioners Counsel—Held: In the application for amendment there was a prayer made for demolishing of the wall and the super structure raised thereon. In the absence of any statement in the plaint that the defendant petitioner disposed the plaintiff opposite parry from the suit land and in absence of any prayer for demolishing the existing wall in the plaint we are of the view that the amendment proposed could at last change the character of the plaint which is not permissible under the law — the order passed by the learned Subordinate Judge is set aside.

Md. Mohiuddin Ahmed Vs. Md. Habibur Rahrnan & Ors. 4BLT (HCD)-34

Order-6 Rule-17

From the impugned order it appears that the learned Assistant Judge did not at all applied its mind to the question involved and without disclosing any reason whatsoever rejected the application for amendment — impugned order is liable to be set aside — relied on 13 DLR - 317, I5BLD -519, PLD 1970 (SC)-173.

Abdur Rahman Vs. Md. Shamsuddin & Ors. 4BLT (AD)-173

Order-6 Rule-17

In the appellate Court plaintiffs No. 1-7 and the appellants filed a solenama on the basis of which the suit was ordered to be decreed and it was remitted to the trial court for the said purpose. The plaintiffs could not be permitted to open the new issue (by amendment) for decision in the suit after having already entered into compromise  admitting the claim of the appellants.

Sunil Chandra Mondal & Ors. Vs. Naragan Chandra Shil & Ors. 5 BLT (AD)-101.

Order-6 Rule-17

Whether in the absence of an initial prayer in the plaint for recovery of possession the subsequent prayer would entail a change in the nature and character of the suit, particularly when the alleged dispossession took place after the filing of the suit.

The plaintiff instituted the suit for declaration of the title to and confirmation of possession in the suit land. Thereafter the plaintiff filed an application seeking amendment of the plaint by way of adding a prayer for recovery of khas possession in the suit land stating, inter alia that during the pendency of the sine defendant No. 1 in collusion with some of the tenants of the plaintiff dispossessed them from the suit land—Held: The plaintiffs application for amendment of the plaint is allowed.

Central Co-operative Bank Vs. Majibur Rahman & Ors. 7BLT (AD)-5

Order-6 Rule-17

Suit for Partition—The amended prayer was plaintiffs be allowed a decree to purchase the share of defendant No. 8 and consequential relief be passed in pursuance thereof.

The High Court Division held that the plaintiffs can pray for such relief at the initial stage by including the relief in the plaint itself or at any stage subsequent thereto. The only entitlement of defendant No.8 is to file an additional written statement and also to get a reasonable cost from the plaintiffs for filing an additional written statement. We do not think that the High Court Division committed any error of law in holding the said view.

SharijAbdul Mannan Vs. Mst Motahara Banu &Ors. 7BLT(AD)-126

Order-6 Rule-17

It is true that the learned Judge of the High Court Division has not mentioned in the impugned order that in view of the amendment of the plaint the defendant may file an additional written statement if he is so advised. Even in the absence of any such direction for filing additional written statement, the defendant, before disposal of the suit, shall always have the right to submit additional written statement on the amendment of the plaint.

Khondker Monjur Morshed Vs. Khandker Monjur Hasan 7BLT (AD)-21

Order-6 Rule-17

Amendment of Pleadings

The settled law for amendment of pleadings is that a prayer for amendment should be considered liberally for bringing all possible controversies between the contending parties in a single suit for complete and effective adjudication of the suit by avoiding multiplicity of litigations.

S. A. A. Abu Shafiq & Ors Vs. F. E. M Assaduz,arnan Khalif. (HCD)-359

Order-6 RuIe-17

The Court may at any stage of the proceedings allow either party to alter or amend his pleadings in such a manner and on such terms as may be just, and all such amendments shall be made as may be necessary for the purpose of determining the real question in controversy between the parties.

Jarina Khatun & Ors. Vs. Gani Howlader & Ors. 9BLT (HCD)-437

Order-6 Rule-7

We observe on scrutiny of the plaint and the evidence that there was not such divergence between the plaint and the evidence which would attract the operation of Order 6 Rule 7 of the Code of Civil Procedure. The farogs stand in the name of the plaintiff and the settlement was taken of the plaintiff and the settlement was taken by the father of the plaintiff. This fact was in the plaint. At the time of trial the plaintiff made out a case that his father had taken the lease for his (plaintiff’s) benefits and interest during his infancy. The departure in the evidence from the plaint has not been of such a dimension that the defendants were unfairly taken by surprise. The defendants suffered these evidence to be taken. Evidently this has caused no prejudice to the defendants. Both the parties had all opportunities to lay before the court all their evidence respecting the title and possession of the suit land. In such circumstances the operation of Order 6 Rule 7 of the code of Civil Procedure will not come in.

Kochi Mm Vs. Suruj Mia & Ors Order-6 Rule-17

8BLT (AD)-125

Amendment —it is now well settled that though the allowing of an amendment is discretionary but the same should be exercise judicially in the facts and circumstances of the case and not arbitrarily or for allowing the parties to fill in the lacuna in their pleadings. Before allowing any amendment to the plaint the Court must come to a finding that such amendment is necessary for determining the real question in controversy between the parties and that the same shall not change the nature and character of the suit. In the instant case without any rhyme or reason amendment has been allowed with the omnibus observation that it is necessary for proper adjudication of the suit and that it does not change the nature and character of the suit or the pleading without detailing how and why the amendment is necessary.

Akitullah & Ors Vs. Zafala Begum & Ors. 10BLT (AD)-132

Order-6 Rule-17

The object of Order VI, Rule 17 of The Code is to aid justice by making it possible for parties who had not framed there in a proper form, to correct the Mistake or supply the omissions with a view to bringing to the notice of the Court the real question to controversy in the suit. A provision intended to advance justice cannot by itself be so applied as to cause injustice to other party. Liberal exercise of discretion is to be checked by the consideration of likely prejudice causing harm to other side, particularly when other party suffers loss of valuable right already accrued in its favour. Amendment cannot be permitted as reward on ones negligence at the cost of right of other.

Haji Md. Siddique Master Vs. Samsul Haque & Ors. 11BLT (HCD)-14

Order-6 Rule 17

In view of the plaint, the Question at which the parties likely to be at variance are which of the handing agents is liable to pay as per adjudication order to be passed by the defendant No. 1 and for which period of the agency. The plaintiff has not denied the execution of the joint declaration with defendant no. 2 on 01.08.1991 nor he was denied his liability to pay for the period from 01.08.1991 period either before 01.08.1991 or after 03.02.1993 and the relief sought for in the plaint is sufficient to address its grievances. The proposed amendment to add further of C-I, that the joint declaration dated 01 .08.1991 to be declared void ab inition and be cancelled and C-III that, defendant No.2 and/or no 3 to be declared liable and responsible to pay the money to be assessed by Defendant No. 1 in different adjudication orders on the basis of Import General Manifest are not at all necessary for adjudication of the aforesaid real issues. Further relief of C-II for a money decree for a sum of Taka 3,90,735 and C-IV a decree of mandatory injunction directing defendant No. 2 and 3 to pay the penalty and other amount to be assessed by Defendant No. 1 are equally not necessary. Because if the plaintiff succeeds to fix the responsibility of Defendant No. 1 and or No. 3 and gets a decree accordingly then, pursuant to the decree the Defendant No. 1 would be obliged to return gets a decree realized from the plaintiff on 07.02.1999 and would need no mandate from the court to realize the dues from the agent found responsible. Besides, in view of the principles enunciated in the above cited Messers Malik & Haq and another V. Muhammad Shamsul Islam Gopal Das V Mul Raj in a suit for a decree of declaration an amendment for adding further relief of a money decree cannot be allowed.

Bangladesh Shipping Lines Ltd. Vs. Commissioner of Customs & Ors. 11BLT (HCD)-56

Order —6 Rule —17

On a perusal of the application for amendment of the plaint it appears that the plaintiffs sought to amend the word’ gift’ and to replace it by ‘will’ and the word ‘tank’ to be replace by ‘bank of tank’. The plaintiff also sought to include certain facts relating to filing 10 case in the Courts and also sought to include facts relating to death of plaintiff’s father John Gomez leaving behind 2 daughters, sons and wife and the said sons were minors. The plaintiff also claimed to include that they acquired title in the suit land by adverse possession also and sought to amend the valuation of the plaint at Tk. 40,000/- in place of Tk. 2,000/- and to pay advalorem court fees. The plaintiffs also sought to include a prayer for declaration of their title on the basis of adverse possession. On a perusal of the Statements sought to be included in the plaint by way of amendment it does not appear that such amendment would in any way change the nature and character of the suit or the proposed amendment are in any way barred by any law. The proposed amendment may be inconsistent with the plaint case as made out by the plaintiff but that will not disentitle to plaintiff to an order of amendment of the plaint.

Elezabeth & Ors. Vs. Naresh Palama & Ors. 11BLT (HCD)-323

Order-6, Rule-17

Suit for permanent injunction

During the pendency of the suit, the plaintiff filed an application under Order 6 Rule 17 read with section 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure for amendment of the plaint by adding a new paragraph after paragraph 4 of the plaint stating that during preparation of the plaint certain important and relevant facts could not be stated and that due to bonafide omission new khatian No. 769 was written whereas in reality the new khatian will be khatian No. 766. Held; the change of number of khatian by way correction will not in way change the nature and character of the suit nor does it shift the place of property as stated in the kabala the basic document.

Md. Sirajuddin Vs. Mohibunessa & Ors 12 BLT (AD)138

Order 6 Rule-17

Amendment application at belated stage during Pending of the Appeal.

The amendment of the plant is essentially a matter  for discretion of the court which needs to be urged for complete and effectual resolving of the controversies between the parties. The power of amendment is intended to be exercised for advancing the power of justice but not for preventing the power of justice.

Shahidul Islam Vs Anwarul Islam & Ors. 13 BLT (HCD)418

Order-6 Rule-17

Money Suit—the plaintiffs cannot be permitted to say that even after the expiry of the stay their right to claim further damages did no accrue or they were not in a position or entitled to make the application for amendment of their plaint for adding further damages.

Mirza Fashiul Atom & Ors Vs. Sonali Bank & Ors 12 BLT (HCD)233

Order 6 Rule 17

Whether the amendment introducing an alternative basis of claim of pre-emption would change the nature and character of the application for pre-emption.

Held: we are of the view that the High Court Division has quit correctly held that by the proposed amendment the pre-emptor has sought for subsisting one cause of action for another i.e. initial claim for pre-emption as Certificate officer-sharer is being sought to be substituted by amendment upon introducing case of pre-emption as contiguous land owner. The amendment so sought and allowed by the trial Court has completely changed the color of the claim of pre-emption and thereupon after closure of evidence pre-emption is sought on a new ground. Since amendment so sought and allowed by the trial Court changed the nature and character of the entire claim of pre-emption at a belated stage in our view the High Court Division has committed no error setting aside the order of the trial Court allowing amendment of pre-emption application and addition of party.

Md. Lehajuddin Vs. Md. Salim Mia & Ors 13 BLT (AD)33

Order 6 Rule -17

The appellant filed an application for amendment of plaint for adding a prayer for a declaration of title and that the judgment and decree dated 08.08.1988 passed in Other Suit No.26 of 1983 of the Court of Munsif, Cox’s Bazar is fraudulent, void and not binding upon setting aside the said decree. The said application was allowed in part allowing the prayer for adding declaration of title but rejecting the prayer for amendment incorporating the prayer that the decree in Other Suit No.26 of 1983 is fraudulent, void and not binding upon the plaintiff on the ground that the suit is beyond the pecuniary jurisdiction, of the learned Subordinate Judge. But instant case being having the higher pecuniary jurisdiction is also entitled under law to decide the suit involving a decree in a suit with less pecuniary value.

Md. Shamsul Haque Vs. Md. Salimullah & Ors 14 BLT (AD)07

Order-6 Rule-17

Amendment of plaint at a belated stage

In the instant case the plaintiff appellant omitted inadvertently some facts not showing break up in the plaint. Such Mistakes of the plaintiff overlooked unintentionally and such Mistakes are not fraudulent. Plaintiff cannot be punished for such unintentional Mistake. Courts duty into complete justice deciding the real matter in controversy and the court has wide discretion in allow the amendment at any stage of the proceedings.

Janata Bank Vs. Saful Islam 15 BLT (HCD)18

Order-6 Rule-17

Whether the amendment cannot allow

Amendment can only be refused if it introduces totally different, new and inconsistent cause, or changes the fundamental character of the suit or such amendment will take away from other side a legal right accured in his favour by lapse of time.

Janata Bank Vs. Saful Islam 15 BLT (HCD)18

Order-6 Rule-17

The provisions embodied in Order 6, Rule 17 of The Code constitute a Rule of Procedure advancing a remedy to rectify an error, Mistake, omission or default in pleadings of parties. The consideration is to minimize the litigation and to advance cause of justice instead to stifle it. Prayer for amendment is to be liberally allowed so that rights of the parties can be fairly and conclusively determined and multiplicity of suits avoided. It is, also, to be remembered that amendment must not alter the fundamental character of the suit, that is, the edifice on which the suit is based. Where the proposed amendment neither changes, the cause of action nor does it introduce any case inconsistent with that set up in the original plaint, the Court should allow the amendment to be brought about.

Hazi Afsar Uddin Mina & Ors Vs. Selina Begum @ Rani & Ors 15 BLT (HCD)303

Order-6 Rule- 17 read with Arbitration Act, 1940 Section-23

Allowing additional claim by amendment for the period during which the matter was pending before the higher courts

Pendentilite interest—the Arbitrators so appointed by the court gave an Award on 12.08.1997 with 16% interest per annum till payment of the Awarded amount and the learned Court made the Award a Rule of the Court with direction to pay the Awarded amount within 30 days, in default, to pay 16% interest till realisation—Held: We find that as per the terms of the Award the petitioner failed to pay the amount within the stipulated date filing of Bank Guarantee along with the application to set aside the Award does not mean actual physical payment and that 16% interest allowed up to the date when actual payment is made. Furnishing of Bank Guarantee does not relieve the petitioner form payment of interest as per terms of the Award.

University of Dhaka Vs. Associated Engineers & Drillers. 9 BLT (HCD)-214

Order-6 rule-17 read with Order-21 rule 17(2)

Order 6 rule 17 of the Code of Civil Procedure though is designed for amendment of pleadings but the provision of order 21 rule 17(2) providing that where an application is amended under the provisions of sub-rule (1), it shall be deemed to have been an application in accordance with law and presented on the date when it was first presented.

Dhaka University Vs. Md. Akbar Hossain 12 BLT (AD)-33.

 

1349

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 [Order XL - XLVII]

Citation: 4 BLT (AD)-4, 7BLT (AD)-211, 16 BLT (HCD)303, 1BLT (HCD)-1, 11 BLT(HCD)-1, 7BLT(AD)-101, 7BLT (HCD)-350, 7BLT (HCD)-303, 8BLT (HCD)-57, 7BLT (HCD)-146, 7BLTMD)-7, 7BLT (AD)-311, 7BLT(AD)-367, 7BLT (AD)-145, 7BLT (HCD)-241, 7BLT (HCD)-80, 3BLT (AD)-131,

Subject: Civil Procedure

Delivery Date: 1970-01-01

 

 

 

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908

Order-40 Rule-1

Simply because the property in suit was under the management of a receiver for a long period of time it cannot be regarded as a just and convenient ground for appointment of a receiver as Order XL Rule (1) does not authorise court to do so on such a ground.

Kamiruddin & Ors Vs Md. Mokshed Ali Biswas & Ors. 4 BLT (AD)-4.

Order-40 Rule-1

Appointment of receiver

It appears that the trial court with a view to saving the property of the suit from being sold in auction due to non-payment of tax and duties passed the order for appointment of receiver with an observation that whether the plaintiffs have acquired any right, title in the suit property will be decided in the suit itself. Upon such finding of the trial court and in the facts and circumstances of the case it cannot be said that the learned Judge of the High Court Division has committed an error of law in upholding the impugned order of the trial court.

Mohammad Mosharef Hossain & Ors. Vs. Jalal Uddin Ahmed & Ors. 7BLT (AD)-211

Order 40 Rule—1

Appointment of Receiver

In the instant case, the application made under Order XL Rule-1 simply discloses that the plaintiff is going to let out some shops in favour of some other persons and is going to realize salami from the shopkeepers. Save and except the said assertion there is no other case brought before the Court for getting an order for appointment of receiver. The order of status quo in respect of possession was passed on contest on 13.4.1999 and that after that order the plaintiff being in possession was receiving rent from the shop keepers and that he took an attempt to repair shops. The defendant-opposite parties being not in physical possession and having accepted the order of status quo in respect of possession in the suit shops were not entitled to make application for appointment of receiver long after about 7 years of the status quo order was passed. Order-40 Rules 1(2) is clear bar in allowing the prayer for appointment of receiver.

Md. Matiur Rahman Vs Dr. Fayez Uddin & Ors. 16 BLT (HCD)303

Order 40 Rule—1

The receiver should not remove any person from the possession or custody of the suit property unless a compelling circumstance is appearing for doing so.

Md. Matiur Rahman Vs Dr. Fayez Uddin & Ors. 16 BLT (HCD)303

Order 40 Rule—1

The object and purpose of appointment of receiver may generally be stated to be the preservation of the subject matter of the litigation pending judicial determination of the rights of the parties and it must be with the dominant object to prevent the ends of justice from being defeated. Before allowing an application it should be the duty of the court to see that the rights of the parties are not jeopardized and the ends of justice not defeated.

Md. Matiur Rahman Vs Dr. Fayez Uddin & Ors. 16 BLT (HCD)303

Order-40 Rule-(l)(a)

There is no bar in rule-1 of order-40 for the appointment of a receiver during the pendency of the appeal.

Shamsuddin Ahmed and Ors. Vs Bangladesh 1BLT (HCD)-1

Order-40 Rule-1(a)

Principles —appointment of a receiver

Suit for partition — in the instant case, the parties are in separate possession of the suit property left by their father on the basis of a registered partition amongst them since 1991. Out of six sisters and two brothers, Plaintiff No. 1 only wants appointment of a receiver. And her success in the suit mainly depends on the proof that the registered deed of partition was forged and void, and/or not acted upon. In the circumstances, introduction of a third party as a receiver of the valuable property cannot be surely said would not result in Mismanagement of or harm to the property — there should be no appointment of a receiver.

Md. Ali  Akbar & Ors. Vs. Sakina Begum & Ors. 11 BLT(HCD)-1

Order 40 Rule-1(2)

Whether a co-sharer in exclusive possession to be ousted therefrom by a receiver

Held: Suit for partition admitted position being that defendant Nos. 2-4 have been asserting their exclusive control over the income of the petrol pump in question, although they claim that they have been doing the business investing their own capital in the said petrol pump which originally belonged to their father, late Md. Imam Sharif, the common ancestor of both the parties of suit, it does not appear that the learned Judges of the High Court Division have passed the impugned order of appointment of receiver inequitably and in violation of Rule 1(2) of Order 40 C.P.C.

Mohammad Moslem Khan & Ors. Vs. Mohammad MohsinKhan & Ors. 7BLT(AD)-101

Order-41 Rule 11(1)

A close reading of Order 41 Rule 11(1) read with Rules 12 and 13 leads to the irresistible conclusion that the impugned judgment and order is not an order of dismissal of the appeal. It is an order finally disposing the appeal without admission of the appeal and without serving notice upon the respondent. Such order as has been passed under the impugned judgment and order is not an order of dismissal of appeal rather it is a final order setting aside the order of status quo passed by the trial court without giving an opportunity to the respondent to which she was entitled to. The judgment and order impugned has no legal sanction in that it is not an order within the meaning of order 41 Rule 11(1) C.P.O.

Most. Fouzia Nigar Chowdhury Vs. Md. Iqbal &Ors. 9BLT (AD)-216

Order-41 Rules-11 (2) & 19

It appears that the order dated 24.1.94 was passed at the time of admission hearing of the appeal and as such the order was passed under Rule 11 (2) of Order of the Code of Civil Procedure and therefore, the application for readmission of the hearing filed under Rule- 19 of Order-4 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure is maintainable.

Otaruddin Mollah Vs. Nesaruddin Molla 7BLT (HCD)-350

Order-41 Rule-12

Written statement—Opposite parties No. 1 & 2 flied a written statement for the first time in appeal, the Appellate Court accepted the written statement—Held: The written statement is to be filed in the trial court according to the provisions of Order-8 Rule(1) of the Code—the Appellate Court fell in serious error of law in allowing the opposite parties No. 1 & 2 to file their written statement for the first time in appeal and in accepting the same for the Appellate Court does not have such power.

Narayan Chandra Saha & Anr Vs. Jatindra Chandra Saha & Ors. 7BLT (HCD)-303

Order-41 Rule-12(l)(2)

After admission of the appeal it is a mandatory to serve notice upon the respondents fixing a date for hearing giving sufficient time to appeal and answer the appeal on such day.

Abdul Wahab Biswas Vs. Abdul Matin Mia & Ors. BLT (HCD)-227BLT (H

Order-41 Rule-19

The respondents filed the appeals under Section 43 of the Waqf Ordinance. Appeals Section 43 of the Waqf Ordinance, Appeals were dismissed for default—Held: From a consideration of the provisions of the Code as well as Section 43 of the Waqf ordinance it appears that as the District Judge as contemplated under Section 43 of the Waqf Ordinance is not a persona designata but a court and as it is a court of civil nature. the provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure is very much attracted in the present case and accordingly the provisions of Order-41 Rule- 19 of the Code of Civil Procedure is available to the respondents.

Aminul Haque Shah Chowdhury Vs. Abdul Wahab Shah Chowdhury & Ors8 BLT (AD)-50.

Order-41 Rule-19

Re-admission of an appeal dismissed for default.

Although a liberal view is generally taken in interpreting “sufficient cause” to explain the default of the appellant leading to dismissal of his appeal for default, an undue latitude cannot be allowed to the appellant for the repeated laches of his engaged Advocate. When it is found that the appellant is guilty of gross negligence in prosecuting his appeal, he cannot be allowed to have mercy of the court in the interest of justice.

Md. Anwar Hossain & Ors. Vs. M/S Eagle Box manufacturing Co. Ltd. & Ors 8BLT (HCD)-57

Order-41 Rule-21

Ex parte disposal of an appeal on merit is by itself no ground to refuse a relief under Order 41 Rule 21 of the Code of Civil Procedure when the applicant proves his case of prevention by sufficient cause.

Md. Abdul Haque Vs. Md. Mostafa Mondal & Ors. 7BLT (HCD)-146

Order-41 Rule-23

Where no remand should be made.

The two Courts below concurrently found that the plaintiff failed to discharge the onus to prove that the impugned documents were obtained by fraud. How could an order of remand be made to fill up the lacunae left by the plaintiff himself? The High Court Division also ignored the con current finding of the Courts below that the defendants have been in possession of the suit land on the basis of the sale deeds in question. The order of remand was therefore absolutely uncalled for.

Md. Nazir Hossain Khan & Anr. Vs. Shahida Begum & Ors. 7BLTMD)-7

Order-41 Rule-23

When a case should be remanded

Suit for Specific Performance of Contract— On a reference to the judgment of the High Court Division it is seen that it held that the real question of controversy has not been adjudicated on the basis of evidence. Upon such finding the High Court Division remanded the case the trial Court for the ends of justice and ordered that the parties should be given opportunity to prove their respective case in accordance with law. As the High Court Division remanded the case for fresh trial with liberty to the parties to adduce evidence to prove their cases the order of remand was made legally we do not find that the impugned judgment and order of the High Court Division occasioned any failure of justice.

Amal Bhushan Singha Vs, Khalokuzzaman. & Ors. 7BLT (AD)-311

Order-41 Rule-23

Remand—We hold that the Division Bench ought to have either dismissed the appeal for default or ought to have adjourned it to some other date as it was a part-heard appeal or could have passed other orders but it was certainly not authorised to consider the appeal in the absence of the appellant and decide it on merits. It was simply an unacceptable manner of disposal of the appeal and in that view of the matter, the First Appeal ought to be remanded to the High Court Division for fresh hearing on merit.

Govt. of Bangladesh & Anr Vs. WaqerAhmed & Ors. 7BLT(AD)-367

Order-41 Rule-23

Remand—when the courts below decided the suit on merit on the basis of the evidence on record, the High Court Division is not at all justified in law in sending back the case on remand to the trial court for holding trial afresh, rather in the interest of justice the High Court Division itself ought to have decided the case on merit on the evidence on record and in accordance with law.

Indrajit Kundu & Ors. Vs. Sekanader Ali 7BLT (AD)-145

Order-41 Rule-23

The Family Appellate Court cannot exercise power in sending the suit back on remand to the Family Court for disposal and it can only decide the appeal keeping its authority within the four walls of the Family Court Ordinance, 1985 itself.

Md. Atiqur Rahaman Vs. Ainunnahar 7BLT (HCD)-241

Order-41 Rule-23

On remand—In the present suit learned Subordinate Judge has committed a mistake while distributing the saham which has not been done by metes and bounds. It appears that he has distributed the property leaving aside Kha schedule property which was sold by the defendant No. 1 to defendant No.2 but that has also must come with the partition and this may be allotted to defendant No. 1 which admittedly was inherited by the plaintiff and defendant No. 1—We are inclined to send the case back to the trial court for fresh hearing and disposal of the matter.

Bina Roy Chowdhury Vs. Amullya Roy Chowdhury & Ors. 7BLT (HCD)-80

Order-41 Rule-23

The predecessor of the appellant as plaintiff instituted the Title Suit — the Trial Court decreed. In revision High Court Division found that there are Misreading of evidences and that both the Courts below have not at all considered the material evidence on record and for that he send the case back on remand to the trial court — it is not consonance with equity and justice that an old case of 30 years could be remanded so lightly as has been done by the High Court Division even if it is accepted that there is Misreading of evidence and non-consideration of material evidence then the High Court Division was within its competence to dispose of the matter on the materials on record without remanding the suit.

H. A. Chowdhury & Ors Vs. M. A. Amin & Ors. 3BLT (AD)-131

Order-41 Rule-23

Order of remand by the appellate court on preliminary point not proper when the said preliminary point was raised in the trial court and judgment was passed on discussion of the entire evidence on record adduced by both parties.

S. M. Shahjahan Vs. Md. Akmal Hossain 5BLT (HCD)-19

Order-41 Rule-23

Remand—whether a particular document is a deed of sale or deed of gift can only be decided on discussion of evidence— the case ought not to have been sent back on remand after 22 years.

“Where on the basis of the materials on record the appeal could be disposed of by the lower appellate court, it should be disposed of in accordance with law without any fodder forenamed”.

Mst. SalehaBibi Vs. TaibAli & Others 1BLT (HCD)-57

Order-41 Rule-23

Remand—Suit jote originally belong to Mohir Sheikh and Iman Sheikh—the opposite party claimed title to the suit land on the basis of an auction purchase by the opposite party No. 1 for the share of Mohir Sheikh. Share of Iman Sheikh has not been auction-sold and the petitioner purchased the share of Iman Sheikh and from disinterested heirs of Mohir Sheikh—so, since the holding has not been petitioned amongst the co-sharer and both the parties are co-shared of the suit properties and the permanent injunction suit generally cannot lie in such a holding as the petitioner filed the suit for injunction against co-sharer with a Misconceived idea and the court decided the title of the suit property against him—the Courts below decided the partition suit on the basis of the title and possession decided in the suit for permanent injunction between the part is —the partition suit is sent back on Order of remand by the appellate court on remand for fresh trial.

Md. Hurmuj Ali Sheikh Vs Amullah Ch. Guha Chowdhury & Ors. 2BLT (HCD)-195

Order-41 Rule-23

Where evidence clear has been only duly placed before the trial court and it has decided the suit on merit the revisional court has no power to remand by shirking its duty particularly solely for the purpose of writing the judgment afresh.

Hosne Ara Begum & Ors. Vs. Montaj Ali & Ors. 10 BLT (AD)-99

Order-41 Rule-23

In view of the clear finding of the trial court regarding Hiba-bil-Ewaz as aforesaid we are of the view that this open remand order for a fresh decision in the suit allowing parties to adduce of the pleadings of the parties, which is not the intent and object of the order of remand contemplated under Order-41 Rule-23 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

Akitullah & Ors. Vs. Zafala Begum & Org. 10 BLT (AD)-132

Order 41 rule-23

On perusal of the record of the case it appears that in the instant case all the evidences and materials were before the lower appellate Court who itself could have disposed of the appeal finally. It is settled principles of law that unnecessary order of remand entails hardship, agony of fresh hearing and additional expenditure and the same is to be deprecated and discouraged as it tends to delay the administration of justice far from advancing its course.

Abdul Quiyum Jalali Ponkhi Vs. Md. Lukman &Ors 15 BLT(HCD)122

Order 41 rule-23

The Law is settled now that an order of remand is not well founded in law if the same is premium for the laches and negligence of one of the parties to the suit or to enable a party to fill up a lacuna in his case which inspite of the opportunity to fill up the said gap, the party did not care to take step in that regard.

M.A. Hashem & Ors Vs. Shafiuddin Ahmed & Ors 16 BLT (AD)42

Order —41 rule —23

The present case is an old case of more than 27 years. Superior courts generally show aversion to an order of remand in old cases and it is warranted in law that the court should decide the issues on the basis of evidences on record. It is well settled that remand orders are not to be made as a matter of course and it should be avoided as far as possible when there are sufficient evidence on record and specially the remand orders are disapproved and deprecated in old cases. The case of Mustafizur Rahman Vs. Abdul Kader, 3 BLC (AD) 38 may be noted in this connection that an order cannot be held more unconscionable and unjust than to send the case back on remand to the trial court for fresh disposal after such a long laps of time. After more than 27 years when as per evidence on record the defendant No.1 who palpably held documents of title to the suit property is now about 80 years of age and forsaken and abandoned by the plaintiff husband by contracting a second marriage behind her back and without her consent before even filing the present suit, the present suit needs to be decided on the basis of evidence on record in the ends of justice.

A.H. Md. Ali Haider Quoraishi Vs. Shaheen Quoraishi & Ors 16 BLT (AD)323

Order-41 rule-23

Order of remand

It is now the settled principle of law that order of remand should not be made lightly by the superior court and that if materials on record are sufficient for the disposal of the suit in that case instead of sending the suit back on remand the superior court should dispose of the same. The above is the general as well as broad principle of law. But there may be case (s) as the instant one, even though there is no prayer from the parties in the proceeding for sending the suit back to the trial Court or to the lower appellate Court for disposal where right of the parties to the proceeding so send back Of remand is depended on the result of a suit filed earlier still remains pending the order of remand by the appellate/higher Court made in such a situation cannot he considered unjustified.

Begum Lutfunnessa Vs.Md. Shafiullah & Ors 12 BLT (AD)-66

Order-41 Rule-23

The trial Court has considered the evidence on record and decreed the suit bit the Court of appeal below without reversing the finding arrived at by the trial Court dismissed the suit. The High Court Division, however, remanded the suit to the lower appellate Court for writing a proper judgment in accordance with law. The evidence on record are sufficient to dispose of the case in its revisional jurisdiction under section 115(1) of the Code of Civil Procedure and in that view of the point of law involved in this case decision on the contesting issues involved in the suit could be given by the High Court Division by assessing the evidence. This Court feel that it should not decide the points raised in this appeal and with all fairness and keeping the spirit of expeditious disposal of the suit, the High Court Division could dispose of the rule upon hearing the parties on the merit of the suit considering the pleadings and the evidence on record together with the point of law involved in the case.

Mrs. Zakaria Chowdhury & Ors Vs. Abdul Hamid & Ors 12 BLT (AD)136

Order 41 rule 23

Additional evidence —It appears that the plaintiff filed a petition on 11.12.2001 before the High Court Division whereby it was stated that they failed to produce the patta dated 13- 3-195 1 and kabala dated 17-3-1951 in the trial court but they tiled said 2 documents in the court of appeal below hut the said documents were not considered by the court of appeal below and in such view of the matter, the learned Single Judge was justified in sending the case on remand to the trial court take steps to prove the said documents in the interest of justice and proper adjudication of the matter in controversy between the parties.

Narayan Chandra Ghosh & Ors Vs. Moksed Mollah & Ors 13 BLT (AD) 28

Order 41 rule – 23

Remand — suit for Permanent injunction - held, we feel that in the absence of relaying of the land in suit with reference to the map already by the Railway in Title Suit No.563 of 1987 of the 4th Court of Assistant Judge Dhaka the moot contention of the parties can hardly be addressed in its correct perspective and in the absence of relaying the land in suit with reference to the map so filed by the Railway there is likelihood of Misscarriage of justice.

Bangladesh Railway Vs. A.F.M. Basher, Advocate & Ors (AD)176

Order—41 Rule—23

In the instant case without ascertaining the point of identification of suit land or addition of the interested persons in the suit and without asserting, whether the purchaser Mustafa Khondaker’s nick name is Md. Motiullah Khondaker, the decision cannot be taken. So it is a fit case for sending the case back on remand to the trial court for ascertaining all these points for interest of justice. An order of remand can be passed if it is necessary to do so in the interest of justice. The power of remand must be regulated by the provision of rule 23 of order 41 and that inherent powers under section 151 of the Code cannot be exercised by the appellate court to order remand. The power of remand was thus, strictly a limited power and yet in practice, the case like this arose wherein remand was necessitated for some reasons.

M. Matiullah Khondaker Vs. Md. Yousuf Shikder & Ors (HCD)375

Order-41 Rule-23 read with Section-151

High Court Division observed, it is amply clear that the conduct of the defendant No. I has been vexations from the beginning with a motive to delay the proceedings, probably because the property in the city of Dhaka is under her long possession—Held : Even compensatory costs as awarded in the instant case cannot justify an order of remand in the name of ends of justice when the order itself defeats justice.

F. Alam & Ors. Vs. Zobaida Nahar & Ors 5BLT(AD)-88

Order 41 rule 23 read with Section 80

The appellant-I was impleaded as defendant on 24.11.1996 and the suit itself has been decreed ex-parte against the appellant-I on 20.2.1997. There is nothing in the plaint to indicate that any notice as required under Section 80 of the Code of Civil Procedure were issued served. It thus appears that mandatory period of three months has not been allowed to the appellant to enable it to submit its written the matter we submissions made Attorney General and on this score alone the suit, according to us, is required to be sent back to the trial court on remand, directing the trial court to give reasonable time to defendant No. 4 to submit written statement and the trial court shall proceed in accordance with law.

Bangladesh & Ors, Vs. Md. Sirajuddin Khan & Ors. 15 BLT (AD)09

Order-41 Rules-23 & 25

In a second Appeal, in an old case of 27 years of the passing of the impugned judgment— Held: In order to do complete justice and by way of practicing the principle preached above as to avoiding an order of remand, we ourselves looked into the evidence of the 7 P.Ws. and feel satisfied that the evidence of possession is fully uniform coming from competent witnesses and there is no major discrepancy or infirmity in the said evidence—the appeal is allowed.

Kabir Ahmed & Ors Vs. Nurul Islam & Ors. 6BLT (AD)-253

Order-41 Rules-23, 24 & 25

It is now a well settled principle of law of in a suit the plaintiff has paid court fee on advolerm basis, the court is competent to give him relief which he deserves in view of the facts and circumstances of the case but where no such court fee has been paid the court is not in a position to grant any such relief and in that case the court is either to dismiss the suit or the appeal but appellate court in proper cases may remand the suit to the trial court for amendment the plaint and payment of advolern court fees.

Md. Abu Taher Vs. Pubali Bank Ltd. & Ors. 9BLT (HCD)-299

 

 

Order-41 Rules-23,24 & 25 read with Section-107

The plaintiff suit being a suit for partition, the question of benami character of the two deeds could be gone into and well decided by the appellate court and a separate relief of declaration of title on the question of benami character of the deeds was not required and even if there was an application for amendment of the plaint incorporation the relief of declaration of title and that application could be disposed of by the appellate court and appellate court was quite competent enough to dispose of the side amendment matter — the lower appellate court was fully competent: to decide the case by itself all the evidence and other materials on record were sufficient to enable it to come to a final decision without entailing the parties unnecessary trouble and expenses there was no necessity for sending the suit back on remand to the trial court.

M. K. Bhuiyan & Ors. Vs. Most. Lutfunnaher Begum & Ors. 5BLT (HCD)-95

Order-41 Rule-27

Admittedly, the plaintiff filed the suit of the basis of a deed of agreement dated 27.1.197 1 and the suit was filed in 1982. In that suit Government appeared as defendant No. 2 and filed a written statement challenging the bainapatra as fabricated and ante dated—Held: The learned judges of the High Court Division should not have accepted this deed of agreement dated 27.01.1972 which was produced before the High Court Division for the first time without examining the executant Mahmood Alam or without as to his whereabout. As a matter of fact this filing of this deed of agreement at a belated stage without sufficiently explaining the cause for not filing this document in the suit, moe particularly when the respondent stated in Ext. 2 that she would not produce any more witness and would not produce any document in her favour before the Trial Court.

Govt. of Bangladesh Vs. Mrs. Noorjahan Khan & Ors 8BLT (AD)-1

Order-41 Rule-27

Unless an application under Order-4 1 Rule 27 C.P.C. is filed for acceptance of the documents as evidence in a case and the documents are made exhibits, mere filing of the same in a court is no ground for a remand of the case on the ground that uninhabited documents filed in the court may be treated as evidence.

Nurul Islam & Ors. Vs. Daud Hossain & Ors 8 BLT (AD)-174

Order —41 Rule-27

It appears that the learned Judge of the Court of appeal below sent hack the suit on remand for fresh trial but I find that the learned Judge took notice the evidences oral and documentary on record but as a last court of facts failed to weigh and sift the same and to decide the same finally and should not sent the suit back on remand for fresh trial ---It is settled principles of law that unnecessary order of remand entails hardship, agony of fresh hearing and additional expenditure and the same is to be deprecated and discouraged as it trends to delay the administration of justice far from advancing its course.

Lutfunnessa @ Lutfa Begum Vs Abdul Halim Khan 16 BLT (HCD)283

Order-41 Rule-27(1)(b)

Clause (b) of rule 27(1) of the Code of Civil Procedure confers discretion on the appellate court to allow additional evidence in order “to enable it to pronounce judgment, or for any other substantial cause.” This discretion should not be given a restricted interpretation as would, in effect, amount to tying down the hands of the appellate court and stand in the way of doing complete justice in a cause.

Anu Mia & Ors. Vs. Babar Au Mondal & Ors. 9BLT (AD)-27

Order-41 Rule-28

The suit was filed on 14.9.81 praying for a decree for permanent injunction restraining defendant petitioner and others from declaring the Boalia Siddikia Bilateral Madrasha closed and shifting the movable assets of the said Madrasha to some other place—even if the Madrasha was as reported by the Advocate Commissioner closed on 20.11 .81 the cause of action for the suit was very much present at the time of the filing at the suit on 14.9.81 and when the order for ad interim injunction was passed, plaintiffs opposite parties filed Miscellaneous case for violation the order of injunction passed by the learned trial court but the trial court did not dispose of the said Miscellaneous case, prior to the disposal of the main suit, further the trial court has dismissed the suit without considering the deposition of the plaintiff and papers filed by him. In view of the above the learned Appellate Court had reasons to set aside the judgment of the trial court. The learned Appellate Court in his elaborate judgment discussed the necessary of taking further evidence for the pronouncement of the judgment and for proper adjudication of the suit—the appellate court may allow evidence or document to be produce or witness to be examined—order for remand should not be made when there is any specific provision in the Code which would meet the necessity of the case.

M. A. Satter Debipuri & Anr Vs B. Madrasha 3BLT (HCD)-155

 

Order-41 Rule-28

We are of the view that ends of justice would best be met if the case is being sent to the lower appellate Court i.e. to the court of District Judge, Dinajpur, for disposal of the appeal upon disposing of the matter of production of additional evidence as the defendant sought by filing an application under Order 41 Rule 27 of the Code of Civil Procedure in Titled Appeal No. 21 of 1969, which was disposed of by the learned Subordinate Judge on 291h December, 1969. We are also of the view that in the background of the facts of the case High Court Division was not in error in passing the order to afford opportunity to the parties to adduce further evidence if they so advised.

Joydeb Ray & Ors. Md. Muntasir Reza & Ors. 9BLT (AD)-203

Order-41 Rule-30

It has long been held that under Order 41 Rule 17 CPC the use of the word “may” does not mean that it is open to the -Appellate Court to dispose of the appeal on merit in the absence of the appellant.

Govt. of Bangladesh & Anr Vs. WaqerAhmed & Ors. 7BLT(AD)-367

Order-41 Rule-31

The appellate court being the final court of fact must active at its own independent findings on the issues involved in the case.

Amirunessa & Ors Vs Abdul Mannan Howlader & Ors. 3BLT (HCD)-245

Order - 41 Rule – 31

 The object of Rule 31 of Order 41 of the Code of Civil Procedure is to see that the appellate Court does not act mechanically in concurring with the findings of the trial Court. It requires that the appellate Court must discuss and consider the material evidence on record and come to its independent conclusions on all points at issue on the basis of the evidence. The appellate Court is also required to set aside the material findings of the trial Court with reference to the evidence on record adverting to the reasons assigned by it. In the case of affirmance general agreement of the appellate Court with the findings of the trial Court may be considered sufficient but in case of reversal the discussion of evidence must necessarily be fairly elaborate.

Sattendra Nath Roy Vs. Md. Mokshed Ali & Ors. 7BLT (HCD)-195

Order-41 Rule-31

The learned Subordinate Judge did not discuss about the evidence of the witnesses and furthermore he did not controvert the findings of fact arrived at by the trial court. In that view of the matter the judgment and decree passed by the Subordinate Judge are liable to be set aside.

Jobeda Khatoon Vs. Shorab Hossain & Ors. 7BLT (HCD)-290

Order-41 Rule-31

Whether the judgment of the High Court Division was not a proper judgment of reversal

It is imaginable that defendant No. I by virtue of his very dignified and powerful position in the administration in aid of the Martial Law Authority was in a position to enlist the support of the Sub-Zonal Martial Law Authority to get his personal end served at the cost of an ordinary citizen of the state. The evidence on record leave no room for doubt that the plaintiff was subjected to coercion, intimidation and undue influence into making the compromise which has been sought to be set aside. The trial court noticed all these facts and more. The appellate court lost sight of these salient facts of the case and Misdirected itself in reversing the judgment of the trial court without any discussion of evidence and without adverting to the reasoning of the trial court.

Abul Hossain Vs. Farooq Sobhan & Ors. 7BLT (AD)-389

Order-41 Rule-31

Non application of judicial mind

On scrutiny of the records we find that the application for setting aside the abatement was made only after 14 days and not 7 months of the order recording abatement as opined by the learned Single Judge. We also find that the application by the respondent under Order I Rule 10 of the Code has not yet been disposed of. It is also a fact that the alleged existence of a daughter of Khairunnessa was canvassed for the first time before the High Court Division and that also without any support of evidence. Again, all throughout haziras were filed before the trial court on behalf of the deceased defendant Khairunnessa till 20 July 1985 when Nurul Islam made an application disclosing her death. It is obvious that the plaintiff had no inkling of the death of Khairunnessa till 20 July 1985. It is only in or about the middle of November, 1985 that the plaintiff seems to have the definite knowledge of the death of Khairunnessa without leaving any heir behind. He then came up with an application on 17 November 1985 praying for amendment of the plaint by way of substituting the Government for Khairunnessa. The learned Assistant Judge, however passed an order on 22 December 1985 recording of abatement of the suit. The plaintiff made the application for setting aside the abatement after the order was passed on 22 December 1985 which is within 14 days of the order. The learned Judge of the High Court Division completely overlooked these facts and set aside the order of the learned Assistant Judge dated 13 August 1987. The learned Single Judge laid unnecessary stress upon certain averments in the written statement which were only matters of contest between the parties at the trial and hart no bearing upon the abatement. In our opinion the impugned judgment of the High Court Division is a product of non application of judicial mind and suffers from patent illegality.

Md. Badruzzaman Vs. Begum Shamima Naz Siddique & Ors. 7BLT (AD)-344

Order-41 Rule-31

Whether impugned judgment is not a proper judgment of reversal

In the instant case the appellate court did not advert the reasonings of the trial court and also did not discuss the material evidences which were considered by the trial court and these hit the root of the merit of the case—and it also appears that the appellate court also did not comply with the requirements of Order 41 Rule 31 of the Code of Civil Procedure in delivering the impugned judgment—Held: The impugned judgment and decree is not a proper judgment of reversal—relied on 1997 BLT(AD) 15.

Md. Harejuddin Mondal Vs. Md. Palu Sarder & Ors. 7BLT (HCD)-229

Order-41 Rule-31

The learned lower appellate court by the finding arrogated himself to the position of a legal adviser as such committed an error of law resulting in an error in its decision occasioning failure of justice in as much as advising the parties before him to file partition suit is not the function of a Judge, 1st appellate Court being the final Court of facts Misdirected himself both on law and fact and acted illegally in reversing the judgment and decree of the trial court without assigning sufficient and cogent reasons as contended by the petitioner’s counsel.

Held: On perusal of the judgment and decree of the trial Court I find that learned appellate Court having Misdirected himself both on law and facts in course of the judgment impugned travelled for beyond the scope of rule 31 of order 41.

Md. Kamal Bhuiyan Vs. Anowar Hossain & Ors. 4BLT (HCD)-60

Order 41 Rule-31

Principles of Law laid down on reversing the Judgment and Decree passed by the Court below

The trial Court decreed the suit holding that the defendant by making unauthorised changes in the structures of the suit premises rendered himself ejectable there from. The High Court Division did not at all reverse such finding of fact in reversing the decree of the trial Court.

Musammat Mohsena Khatun Vs. M/S. Habi Knitting Mills. 5BLT (AD)-12

Order-41 Rule-31

In the Judgment of the appellate Court, we could not find any consideration on any of the questions raised. He just stated the grounds taken in the memorandum of appeal one after another and expressed his agreement with them and set aside the report. In the aforesaid facts and circumstances, the judgment and decree of the appellate court cannot stand in law as well as on facts and accordingly, is liable to be set aside. Such decision has no doubt results in Miscarriage of justice.

A. Ali Sheikh & Anr Vs. K. Ali Sheikh & Ors. 11BLT (HCD)-444

 

Order 41 Rule-31

It is a settled principle of law that the lower appellate court being final court of fact will have to discuss and reassess the evidence on record independently while either reversing or affirming the findings of the trial court. In case of reversal it is more incumbent upon the appellate court to reassess the evidence on record and to arrive at his own independent finding.

Hazarilal Mondal & Ors Vs. Md. Mozaffor Bepari & Ors. 11 BLT (AJ3)-139

Order-41, Rule-31

The High Court Division found that the amendment of the plaint was allowed by the trial court which was not challenged by the petitioners in a higher forum. The lower appellate court therefore correctly enhanced the share of the plaintiffs in accordance with the amended plaint as the plaint case was fully proved by the plaintiffs. Consequently there has been no failure of justice.

Abdul Majid Sarder & Ors. Vs. Sayed Chowdhury & Ors  8BLT (AD)-44

Order-41 Rule-31

The appellate Court did not consider any evidence on record nor gave its own decision on the question of title and possession — the judgment of the appellate court is base on total non-consideration of the evidence on record and absence of any findings of its own, such judgment must be held to be no judgment at all in the eye of law.

Jarina Khatun & Ors. Vs. Gani Howlader & Ors. 9BLT (HCD)-437

Order —41 rule —31

After more than 7 years of the filing of the appeal the plaintiff, who already secured the decree in his favour, filed an application for amendment of the plaint in the appeal on 17.6.2001 praying for incorporating in the plaint paragraph 15(a), 15(b) and 15(c) on the ground “in view of some important subsequent events that took place in the suit and as these events are required to be incorporated in the plaint for ends of justice, the plaint needs to be amended.” The plaintiff also filed an application for additional evidence on 26.6.200 1 along with a list of documents required to be admitted as evidence in the suit. The appellate court below i.e. the High Court Division after hearing the said applications decided to dispose of the same at the time of disposal of the appeal — Held: From the impugned judgment it appears that the High Court Division disposed of the aforesaid applications while pronouncing the judgment of the appeal itself without considering the above facts and circumstances and thus arrived at an erroneous decision and so we are unable to see eye to eye to the impugned judgment and order. (Majority view)

A.H. Md. Ali Haider Quoraishi Vs. Shaheen Quoraishi & Ors 16 BLT (AD,)323

Order 41, Rule-33

The High Court Division dismissed the First Appeal No. 589 of-l99l and thereon dismissed the Artha Rin Suit No, I of 1990—Held: The learned Counsel because of the admitted facts, and in view of the terms and conditions of Ext. 1, the agreement between the Bank and the loanee (defendant No. 2 in the Artha Rin Case No. I of 1990) could not take factually as well as legally sustainable exception to the findings and decisions of the High Court Division as to the prematurity of the Artha Rin Suit No. I of 1990 i. e. the suit that was filed by the Bank against the loanee for realization of loan money and interest accrued thereon.
