Sonali Bank & ors Vs. Md. Harun. 11 BLT (AD)-209

Order-41 Rule-33

Neither from the averments made in the plaint we find that the plaintiff claimed the property in suit as a vested property nor we find that the learned Subordinate Judge held that the property is a vested property. But in spite of such averments made in the plaint and the finding of the learned Subordinate judge the learned judges of the High Court Division have made out a third case in holding that the property is a vested property. Mr. Pal rightly contended that the learned Judges of the High Court Division made out a third case in holding that the property in suit is a vested property. For the above reasons we are of the opinion that the learned Judges that the suit property is a vested property.

Md. Shamsul Huda Vs. Bangladesh & Ors 8 BLT (AD)-152

Order 41 rule 33

Appellant as plaintiff instituted Money Suit for recovery of Tk.4,05,481.00 against the defendant Nos.1-3 —The defendants 1 & 2 jointly and defendant No.3 separately contested the suit by filing two sets of written statements —the trial court considered the evidence of P.W. I and the evidence of D.W. 1,2. 3 & 4 and held that the defendant No. 3 executed the deed of undertaking on 29.10.85 and admitted that he had withdrawn the amount in question as over drawing from the account of the defendant No.1 and accordingly concluded that the defendant No.3 was liable for the repayment of the amount in question and the defendants I & 2 are not liable for the said amount. Accordingly by the judgment and decree dated 19.2.91 the trail court dismissed that suit without cost against defendants 1 & 2 decreed the suit with cost against defendant no 3 directing him to pay Tk. 4,05,841 .00 to the plaintiff —The plaintiff preferred the instant appeal —Held: We therefore do not find any reason to disagree with the finding arrived at by the trial Court holding that the defendant No.3 alone was liable for the overdrawing of the amount in question.

Pubali Bank Ltd. & Anr Vs. Md. Nurul Islam & Ors 15BLT(HCD)112

Order 41 rule-33

In the instant case the plaintiffs are claiming the land in suit by purchase and as heirs of the purchasers and the purchasers were made between 1932 and 1968. It was the case of the plaintiffs that land described in schedule ‘Kha accreted in 1935 to the C.S. Plots. If that assertion of the plaintiffs is accepted then it would have been quite natural to have the mention of the accreted land in the kabalas of the years between 1943 and 1968 and there would been mention of said fact upon referring to the plot(s) to which there was accretion of land and the quantity thereof, but conspicuously in the deeds of the years 1943- 1968 there is no mention of the plot of the accreted land nor quantity of land accreted to particular C.S. plot and also there is no mention of quantity as stated hereinbefore. It was the definite case of the defendants that there was no existence of accreted land till 1963 i.e. at the time when the S.A. record was made final. Had there been any accretion of land to the C. S. plot during S. A. survey the same would have surely been recorded in the S.A. Record which was published on 1.8.1963. In the aforesaid state of the matter it has been observed by the trial Court that there was no reason to believe that the accreted land was in existence in 1963. It may be mentioned that during the period between 1935-1947 no rent was paid by the plaintiffs in respect of the land said to have accreted to the C.S. plots — The trial Court on consideration of the entire materials on record arriving at the finding that plaintiffs have no title and possession in the land in suit and that accreted land settled with the defendant Nos.6-8 was the khas land of the Government. Since the plaintiffs have no right, title and interest as well as possession in the land in suit, the suit as framed is not maintainable as per provision of section 42 of the Specific Relief Act —Held: on reading the judgment of the High Court Division it is seen that the said Division did not at all applied its mind to the reasonings and findings of the trial Court while disposing of the suit and that also was not collect in arriving at the finding that the trial Court was unaware of the law laid down by this Division in the case reported in 31 DLR (AD) 195. Since the trial Court addressed itself to all the points involved in the suit and that in addressing itself to the points involved in the suit the trial Court was not in error we are of the view the High Court Division was not correct in setting aside the judgment and decree of the trial Court.

M.A. Hashem & Ors Vs. Shafiuddin Ahmed & Ors 16BLT(AD)42

Order 41- Rule 33 read with Arbitration Act, 1940 Section -29

In the suit interest was prayed from 07.06.1995 which is the date of the pronouncement of the award till realization and this interest is neither pre-reference period interest nor pendente lite interest but future interest, that is, from the date of the award till realization of the money and this prayer appears to be in accordance with justice and fairness . Though neither the Arbitrators nor the Trial Court granted interest this Court in the exercise of the power confected upon it under Order XLI, Rule 33 of The Code of Civil Procedure can grant interest.

Chittagong Steel Mills Ltd & Anr. Vs M/S MEC & Ors. 13 BLT (HCD)230

Order-47

In the case of review of a decree under order 47 of the Code the date of the decree will always be the date on which the decree is reviewed, the scope of order 47 is wider than that of sections 152 of the Code.

Bangladesh Vs. Luxmi Bibi & Ors. 2BLT (AD)-182

Order-47 Rule-1

Though the application was described as under section 151 of the C.P.C. but Court is not to be guided by the description in the heading of the application but by the contents of it as if the petitioners filed an application for review of the order on the ground of Mistake and also on the face of the record or by any other sufficient cause the interference of the court would have been perfectly justified even if, the petition instead of being described as for rectification under order 47 rule 1 of the C.P.C. it has been described as under section 151 of the C.P.C. as contended by the learned counsel for the petitioners.

Held: The application filed by the plaintiff petitioners may be treated as an application for review under order 47 rule 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure though wrongly it has been described as an application under section 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure and the merits of the application should be reconsider’’ and though the appeal in question has been finally disposed of there is a scope for review under order-47 rule 1—the rule is made absolute.

Md. M/Sir Ullah Vs. Syed Khaliullah Malek & Ors. 4BLT (HCD)-38

Order-47 Rule-1

Application for review will be governed by Article 173 of the Limitation Act, the prescribed period for which is 90 days and not by Article 52 of the same, the prescribed period for which is 30 days.

Shawkat Ara Begum Vs. Md. Wajuddin & Ors.m 2BLT (HCD)-226

 

Order-47 Rule-1

Review of a part of the order—The order was made upon a wrong assumption that the plaint did not contain any prayer for the said relief. Such an erroneous assumption of material fact amounts to an error apparent on the face of the record calling for a review of the order.

Md. Abdul Jabbar Vs. Bangladesh Bank & Ors 7BLT (AD)-151

Order-47 Rule-1

The amendment application—It is well recognized that a review can be allowed only on showing that the order or the decision recorded by the court suffers from a flagrant error of law apparent on the face of the record. The review can never be allowed to be utilized as an opportunity for rehearing a matter which is closed by a decision recorded by a Judge.

Muzaffar Hossain Vs. Md. Shahidullah & Ors. 7BLT (HCD)-208

Order-47 Rule-1

In writ proceeding

Order 47 Rule 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure which is applicable in a writ proceeding enjoins the learned judges amongst others to review their own judgments or orders on the reason of Mistake or error on the face of the record. The instant case was the best case in this respect. We find, where the learned Judges ought to have exercised their review power. The reason upon which the review application was rejected must be held to be unconscionable and erroneous and so also was the memo of the Ministry of land impugned in the writ petition. We, therefore, come to the conclusion that the High Court Division ought to have allowed the review application and ultimately it ought to have declared the impugned memo of the Ministry of Land as illegal without lawful authority and of no legal effect.

Ratul Basu & Ors. Govt of Bangladesh & Ors. 10 BLT (AD)-185

Order-47 Rule-1

There are certain general principles of review whose authority is universally acknowledge that ought not to be disregarded. The fundamental is that an error is necessary to be a ground for review but it must be one, which is apparent on the face of the record, and so obvious that keeping it on the record will be legally wrong.

E. T. V. Ltd & Anr. Vs. Dr. Chowdhury M. Hasan & Ors. 11BLT(AD)-18

Order-47 Rule-1

Proportionality —It is submitted that if this concept is taken into consideration our judgment will have an important impact on our law and any open the door to areas, which were traditionally not conceived. According to him, the concept he is advocating is already recognized as a general principle of law and applied both by the European Court of Justice and the European Court of Human Rights. It aims at maintaining a proper balance between any adverse effect, which the court’s decision may have on the rights, liberties or interests of persons, and the purpose which the court pursues in its judgment. It involves the exercise of balancing relevant considerations like, the balancing test, the necessary test and the suitability test. This concept involves the court to evaluate whether proportionate weight has been attacked to one other consideration relevant to the decision. As a ground judicial review it is absolutely a new concept to our jurisprudence. And in accepting it this court shall have to accord different weights to different ends or purposes and different means which cannot be allowed in a review.

E. T. V. Ltd & Anr. Vs. Dr. Chowdhury M. Hasan & Ors 11 BLT (AD)-18

Order-47 Rule-1

Review is not a rehearing of a case, Review is not in an appeal, or to put it differently, Review is by no means an appeal in disguise whereby an erroneous decision stands corrected. Not mere error of fact and law, but error apparent on the face of the record is a ground for Review, Review lies only on a patent error. There is real distinction between a mere erroneous decision and an error apparent on the face of the record. Error apparent on face of record is an error which can be seen by a mere perusal of record without reference to any other matter and to find out error one has not to scrutinize the evidence or record but it should be self evident from a perusal of record itself and can be pinpointed without elaborate examination.

Haji Md. Siddique Master Vs. Samsul Haque & Ors. (HCD)-14

Order-47 Rule-1

Since this court, in its revisional jurisdiction, discharged the rule only on the issue of limitation, for ends of justice, both the parties should be allowed to agitate all the other issues involved in the suit as well as in the appeal.

Md. Ali & Ors. Vs. Md. Aminuddin & Ors. 11 BLT(HCD)-80

Order 47 Rule-1

Since a very old document has recently been discovered, which apparently was not within the knowledge of the plaintiff-petitioner, this application for review may be allowed for consideration of the said deed by the Trial Court in accordance with law. As such, the suit is required to be sent back to the Trial Court on remand for trial afresh on taking into consideration the newly discovered document.

Chaitanya Biswas & Ors. Vs. Surendra Nath Gharami & Anr. 12 BLT (HCD)512

Order 47 rule – 1

Review petition is not rehearing of an appeal or an appeal in disguise.

Govt. of Bangladesh & Ors. Vs. Au Akbar Ansari 14 BLT (AD)26

Order—47 Rule—1

Since the plaintiffs petitioners succeeded to make out a case for review on the ground of discovery of important facts or new evidence, which were cogent and sufficient causes for allowing review. As important matter of amendment was within the knowledge of the learned court which escaped his notice and such sort of Mistakes could be corrected by the court on review.

Ramizuddin Vs. Jamila Khatun & Ors 14 BLT (HCD)370

Order—47 Rule —1

On consideration of order 47 rule I of the Code of Civil Procedure, I am of the view that a wrong application of law or non-application of law by a court, whether original or appellate, is no ground to apply order 47 rule I of the Code of Civil Procedure.

Executive Engineer, Vs. Naderuzzarnan & Ors 15 BLT (HCD) 539

Order-47 Rule-1 read with Civil Procedure Code (Amendment) Ordinance, 1962

Pre-emptee Seeks review of the Judgment recorded in civil Revision case

The transfer of subsisting interest in contiguous plot no. 334 by way of gift by Pre-emptor Subitri Sundari Mali to substituted opposite party No.1 (a) was not within knowledge of the Pre-emptee when the Civil Revision was heard and disposed of. This is a discovery of new and important matter and this discovery is a good ground for Review of the decision passed in Civil Revision case.

Md. Mafizul Islam Sarker Vs. Sunil Chandra Biswas & Ors. 12 BLT (HCD)-169

Code of Civil procedure (Third Amendment) 2003 Section-5A(2)

The defendant opposite party may appear before the court and get the matter be disposed of within seven days and in this particular case the defendant without going to the trial court preferred appeal and obtained an order of stay, of course, it is not barred by any law. But as it appears just not to prolong the matter the recent amendment has come into force and in this view of the matter I hold that the parties may get the matter heard before the trial court and dispose it of within seven days.

Zakaria Haider Vs. Global Travel Bangla Pvt. Ltd. & Ors. 12 BLT (HCD)284

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908

Amendment of the Written Statement

Prayer for amendment of the written statement — trial court rejected the prayer for amendment on the ground that since the petitioners filed the additional written statement, his application for amendment of the original written statement cannot be allowed—Held: Amendment of the written statement as sought by the defendant further the proposed amendment may also be necessary for the purpose of determining the real question in controversy between the parties Rule is made absolute.

Rafiqullah & Ors Vs. Momtaz Uddin & Ors. 4BLT (HCD)-76

Answer to Interrogatories

Petitioner is the elected chairman of Pourashava—Respondent No. 2 challenging the electing of the petitioner, on the ground that he was a defaulter in repayment of loan taken from the Bangladesh Krishi Bank. The petitioner appeared and contested the case stating, inter alia, that he was not a defaulter. On the date for further examination of the petitioner, an application was filed on behalf of the petitioner seeking leave of the court to ask him two specific questions, namely (1) what was the time of repayment of the loan sanctioned by the Krishi Bank and how this time has been given? and (b) was the payment of installment re-scheduled by the Bank and if so what are the re-scheduled dates? The tribunal rejected the said application, the High Court Division observed that the petitioner should be allowed to give his reply in question No. 1, without saying anything about question No.2.

Held: It is difficult to appreciate why the Tribunal rejected the prayer for the aforesaid 2 questions to be put to the petitioner because his case apparently was that he was not a defaulter. In order to substantiate his defence, he cannot bring any relevant fact on the record. Evidently the answers to the two questions will be relevant for the purpose of his defence. The petitioner should have been allowed to reply to both the questions.

Abdur Razzak Ashis Vs. Elec. Tri & Sub Judge & Ors. 3BLT (AD)-182

Civil Rules and Order

Note (1) of Rule 388(2)

It is for the Advocates to be present at the proceeding to make themselves acquainted with the order passed and it is not the duty of the officers of the Court to call upon the advocates to show the orders issued or to inform them of the nature of the orders passed and so in view of the absence of the signature of the petitioner’s Advocate in the margin of the order sheet it cannot be said that the order was not known to the petitioner’s Advocate.

Manirunnessa Khanam & Anr Vs. Syed Madassir Ali & Anr 15 BLT (AD) 356

Civil Rules and Order,

Notice in N-10 Form

Prayer for restoration of the Civil Revision case to its file and number

It appears the High Court Division fell in error in not considering that due to the death of Mr. Jitendra Narayan Deb, Advocate (since deceased), the sole engaged lawyer of the petitioners, in the eye of law it will be demanded that the Civil Revision No. 10067 of 1991 stood “Not Ready” on 20.8.2000 and in the above circumstances notice in N10 Form should have been issued to the petitioners. The respondents also did not make out a case, as submitted by the learned lawyer subsequently engaged by the petitioners, that Mr. Jitendra Narayan Deb, Advocate, was not dead when that Rule taken up for hearing and discharged for default and that he was alive on that date. Moreover in their application for restoration the petitioners specifically stated that they were not aware of the death of Jitendra Narayan Deb, Advocate, and it is only on receiving a letter from their lawyer presently engaged they came to know about his death and then they, on collecting signatures of all the petitioners, filed the application for restoration —Held: The Rule is restored to its file and number out the same be disposed of expeditiously.

Ruhitar Rahman & Ors Vs. Satish Chandra Roy Chy. & Ors 16 BLT (AD)21

Civil Rules and Orders Vol-1, Rule-143

Ex parte decree

“A judgment in ex parte cases shall however, state specifically and explicitly which of the reliefs are granted and against which of the defendants-see Rule-143 of the Civil Rules and order Vol-i

Alfu Miah and others Vs. Bangladesh 1BLT (AD)-25.

1350

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 [Order XXI - XXXIX]

Citation: 14 BLT(HCD)136, 9BLT (AD)-207, 8BLT (AD)-278, 10BLT (HCD)-17, 8BLT (HCD)-268, 7 BLT (HCD)-193, 8 BLT (HCD)-133, 9BLT (HCD)-141, 7 BLT (HCD)-358, 9BLT (AD)-209, 8BLT(HCD)-5, 9BLT (HCD)-342, 4BLT (AD)-155, 8 BLT (HCD)-400, 16 BLT (HCD)290, 16 BLT (HCD)300,

Subject: Civil Procedure

Delivery Date: 1970-01-01

 

 

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908

Order 21, Rule 6 Original quantum of decreetal land

Decree holder opposite parties are entitled to have the decree execution as obtained in title suit No.143 of 1952 and an execution proceeding seems to be obstructed on the ground that the excess land is going to be handed over. It seems that before filing of this present application the judgment debtor has also preferred similar application before this court which went up to Appellate Division and that was rejected. Therefore under this circumstances the application alleging that excess land is going to be delivered is just a decree to make delay in executing and delivering the possession of the decreetal land. Therefore the executing court must not make further delay in delivery of possession in respect of decreetal land by appointing an Advocate Commissioner after demarcating the boundary in respect of 55 Bighas of land as per schedule within one month from the date of receipt of this order.

Bikram Baral & Ors. Vs Shaylendra Nath Mondal & Ors 14 BLT(HCD)136

Order-21 Rule-11

In the instant case the decree was drawn up and signed on 15.09.1999 and the execution case was filed within three months from the date of passing the decree, issuance of notices upon the judgment debtor was absolutely illegal and without jurisdiction.

Managing Director Rupali Bank Vs. Hazi Jahan Ara Begum & Ors. 9BLT (AD)-207

Order-21 Rule-16

It appears from the judgment of the Court of appeal below that the plaintiff received copy of the application for execution of the decree endorsing thereon ‘no objection” through his Advocate Zakir Hossain and as such it cannot be said that copy of application for execution of the decree was not served under Order 21 Rule 16 of the Code. When the petitioner himself consented to the execution of the decree by endorsing “no objection” he is debarred from raising the question of service of notice.

Md. Selim Vs. Amir Hossain & Ors 8BLT (AD)-278

Order-21 Rules 18 and 19

Claim of the judgment debtor for adjustment

The ratio decidendi of the cases is that on general principles and in the exercise of its inherent power, an executing Court can entertain and give effect to a claim to set off even in cases which do not come strictly under Order XXI Rule 19 of the Code. And quotable set off can be claimed in a case where cross demands arise out of the same transaction may not arise out of the same transaction hut they are so connection in the nature or circumstances that it would be inequitable to allow one party to separate suit or proceedings. Granting of set off however rests entirely with the discretion of the Court, No party, of course, as of right can claim such set off. It is needless to say that the discretion is to be exercised judicially. In such view of the matter the claim of the judgment debtor for adjustment.

Shankar Lat Das Vs. Janata Bank & Ors. 10BLT (HCD)-17

Order-21 Rule-22

Execution case has been filed within three months from the date of passing the decree—Held: It appears to us that the Executing Court concerned acted beyond jurisdiction in issuing the notices upon the judgment debtors in as much as the Court is not required to issue such notice as the decree execution case has been filed within three months from the date of the decree. As the Court below acted in a manner, which is not provided in law, the process of execution of the decree will be delayed to the prejudice of the petitioners decree holders.

Haji Jahanara Begum & Ors. Vs. Rupali Bank & Ors 8BLT (HCD)-268

Order-21 Rule-29

Admittedly both the SCC. Suits are not in the same court and Order 21 Rule 29 of the Code has got no manner of application in this case when the proceedings was stayed are not pending in the same court.

Monowara Begum Vs. Atiqullah 7 BLT (HCD)-193

Order-21 Rule-29

Power of the Court to stay execution of its decree, Where a suit is pending in any court against the holder or a decree of such Court, by a person against whom the decree was passed, the court may stay the execution of the decree passed in the earlier suit till the disposal of the pending suit. For the purpose of the Rule, the court of the Subordinate Judge and Artha Rin Adalat and the Court of the Subordinate Judge are not the same Courts.

BCIC Vs. Eastern Bank Limited & Ors 8 BLT (HCD)-133

Order-21 Rule-29

Where a suit is pending in any court against the holder of a decree of such court on the part of the person against whom the decree was passed, the court may, on such terms as to security or otherwise as it thinks fit, stay execution of the decree until the pending suit is decided. The Executing court got no power to order stay of execution where the suit is against Decree Holder filed by Third Party. Since, the petitioner is not a party to the suit and the decree and Execution case he got no legal right or character to maintain any application under Rule 29 of Order 21 of the Code to stay further proceeding of Title Execution case.

Rotis chandra Das Vs. Sudhir Chandra 9BLT (HCD)-141

Order-21 Rule-32

Objectionable remarks—Age of the petitioner is of no relevance

The learned Assistant Judge taking a correct view of law and facts and on proper scrutiny of materials and evidence on record rightly passed the impugned order. Since by the impugned order the petitioner No. 1 has been sentenced to undergo civil imprisonment for 15 days the age of the petitioner No. 1 is of no relevance. In that view of the matter I am of the view that in the instant case no lenient view can be taken simply on the ground that the petitioner No. 1 is aged about 60 years and fact remains that he has violated the courts order and ousted the plaintiff opposite party from the suit land.

Madhu & Ors Vs. Maharam Ali 7 BLT (HCD)-358

Order 21 Rule 32

In the case of Kad Banu and ors Vs. Hajera Khatun and ors 36 DLR (AD) 183 executing court attached the properties of the judgment debtors for alleged disobedience of a decree for perpetual injunction. District Judge in revision set aside the order of the executing Court holding that an application under order 21 rule 32 of the Code of Civil Procedure was not maintainable. On further revision under the repealed provision of Section 115(3) of the Code. High Court Division made the rule absolute. Leave was granted at the instance of the judgment debtors by this Division to consider the question whether a petition under order 21 rule 32 of the Code was maintainable. The appeal was allowed and the case was sent back to the trial court to give an opportunity to the parties to prove that the defendants Judgment debtors had willfully disobeyed the order of injunction impliedly holding the order of injunction impliedly holding that application under order 21 rule 32 of the Code was maintainable. A Division Bench of the High Court Division with one of us and presided over by Ismail Uddin Sarker J. heard a reference made by D. M. Ansaruddin Ahmed J. to resolve the conflicting decisions of different Single Benches as to the maintainability of an application under order 21 rule 32 of the Code. The said Division Bench relying on the aforesaid decision of this Division held that such an application is maintainable.

Zainal Abedin & Anr. Vs. Md. Abdur Rahim 9BLT (AD)-209

 

 

Order-21 Rule-32 (1)(2)

A decree for injunction is enforceable in law.

Whenever a decree for permanent injunction is violated or willfully disobeyed by the judgment-debtor the decree holder becomes entitled to execution of the decree under Order 21 Rules 32 (1) and (2) CPC by the attachment of the property of the judgment debtor or by his detention in the civil prison or by both.

Jiban Bima Corporation Vs. Mr. Mohibul Majid &Anr. 8BLT(HCD)-5

Order-21 Rule-35

In the instant case, it is not disputed that the lot in occupation of the judgment-debtors was allotted to the decree-holder by exhausting all procedures after the preliminary decree for partition by metes and bounds. Any objection against such allotment that might be raised to such allotment must have been met with before the preliminary decree was made final. Once a final decree is passed on the basis of such allotment and after exhausting all procedures against such final decree by way of appeal or otherwise, when such decree was put into execution for possession of the lot allotted to the decree-holder, and the application did not suffer from any defect, it is the duty of the executing Court to deliver possession to the decree holder under sub-rule (1) of Order 21 Rule 35 of the Code, and if necessary, by removing all obstructions or obstacles put up by the judgment-debtors.

Mirza Abdul Ban Beg & Ors Vs. Zahidannessa & Ors. 9BLT (HCD)-342

Order-21 Rule-38

The maintainability of the second application under Order 21 Rule 38 C.P.C. was challenged on the ground that it was baited by resjudicata, an earlier application having been dismissed by the Artha Rin Adalat. The High Court Division rightly held that the principle of resjudicata is not applicable in such proceeding.

Sonali Bank Vs. S. Razia Nahar & Ors. 4BLT (AD)-155

Order-21 Rule-52

Held: From the above facts we find, the Subordinate Judge, First Court by his order dated 22.07.1989 practically attached the fixed deposit amounting Taka 92,83,782.20 which was already attached and placed in the custody of the Commercial Court no. 1 in Money Suit No. 91 of 1986. The order was communicated to the said Commercial Court for taking necessary steps. By his order dated 15.03.1997 the Subordinate Judge, First Court again requested the Commercial Court No. 1 to take steps in light of his order dated 22.07.1989 On further prayer of the petitioner dated 25.03.1997, the Subordinate Judge. First court wrote a letter to the said Commercial court requesting him to remit the decreetal amount of Taka 58,08,215 out of the fixed deposit. The steps taken and the procedure followed by the Subordinate Judge. First Court we are afraid fulfilled the requirements of Order XXI Rule 52 of the Code to make the attachment valid. Because, to effect a valid attachment in respect of the fixed deposit, it was necessary to issue a prior notice under Rule 52 of Order XII of the Code as the notice is a condition precedent to the order of attachment as is stated in Kanhayalal Hanmantrao v Reginald Mathalone, AIR 1951 Nag 52, and Then Mal v Income Tax Officer 67 CWN 916 We could not find any such statutory notice was ever issued by the Subordinate Judge before attaching the fixed deposit which is already in the custody of the Commercial Court No. 1 by prior attachment. The communication of the order dated 22.07.1989 of the Subordinate Judge to the Commercial Court No. 1 is not sanctioned by the Rule.

Md. Hanif Vs. Agrani Bank & Anr. 8 BLT (HCD)-400

Order 21 Rule-58

The case relates to an award

The petitioner raised objection against auction sale of the joint property, detailed in the schedule of the Execution Case —It appears that the petitioner was not a party either in the Award or in the Rule of the Court and hence the inclusion of the name of the petitioner as judgment debtor No. 3 in the Execution Case No. 02 of 2005 is illegal and without lawful authority as well as is without any order of the Court —And his name should be struck down from the execution case and the same be amended accordingly and the objection raised under Order-XXI Rule-58. C. P. C. be disposed of afresh in accordance with law reviewing the impugned order passed by the Executing Court.

Mohiuddin Ahmed Vs MIDAS & Anr 16 BLT (HCD)290

Order —21 Rule—58

The learned executive Court without carrying on any investigation into the prayer has rejected the said application only on the reason that the present petitioners are sons, daughter and wife of the judgment debtor

This provision imposes duty upon the Executing Court for holding a true investigation mandatorily but in the instant case without executing any investigation the court has rejected the application of the present petitioner summarily by a non speaking order. In view of the non-speaking order and that the impugned order having passed without having any investigation, we are of the view that the impugned order has been passed not in accordance with the provision of order 21 Rule 58 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

Mst. Sufia Begum & Ors Vs Sonali Bank Ltd. 16 BLT (HCD)300

Order-21 Rules 58 & 61

There is no doubt that the scope of enquiry under Order XXI Rule 58 of the Code is very limited, which is confined to the question of possession. But such possession such be independent of the judgment debtor and not through the judgment debtor within the meaning of Rule-61.

Mohammad Yunus Mia & Ors. Vs. Bangladesh Krishi Bank & Ors. 9BLT (HCD)-473

Order-21 Rule-77(2) V

Public auction of moveable property — in the instant case the auction sale was held on 5. 11.88 and the executing court accepted the quotation of the auction purchaser appellant the auction sale of the appellant was formally accepted by the court by its order dated 10.11.88 giving time to the auction purchaser appellant to deposit the entire deed amount by 15.11.88 and the same was duly deposited — sale become absolute and cannot be set aside.

Fariduddin Chowdhury Vs. M/S Sylhet glass Works Ltd & Ors. 3BLT (AD)-168

Order 21 rule 98 read with Artha Rin Adalat Am, 2003 Section-26

Since specific provision is not available in the Act enabling the Artha Rin Court to put the decree-holder into possession, the Court may exercise its such Jurisdiction as provided in rules 97 and 98 under Order XXI of the Code read with section 26 of the Act, and give necessary directions to execute its order.

IFIC Bank Limited Vs. M/S. Marinar Fashions Wear Pvt. Ltd. & Ors 15 BLT (HCD)425

Order-21 rule 100(2)

In the instant case it appears from the record that on perusal of the application made under order 21 Rule 100 of the Code of Civil Procedure, the executing Court did not issue any summon upon the Petitioner and did not record any evidence to get itself satisfied, that possession was handed over upon any land beyond decretal land. I find that the executing Court proceed not in accordance with the provision of order 21 Rule 100(2) of the Code of Civil Procedure.

Md. Abdul Gufran & Ors Vs. Md. Ahsan Ullah Bhuiyan & Ors 16 BLT (HC’D,)30

Order-22 Rules-1& 10

Plaintiff seeking enforcement of its personal service right and during pendency of the appeal he died— Held: The entire proceeding initiated by plaintiff has been abated on his death.

Rabindra Nath Bose & Ors. Vs. Shantilota Bain & Ors 10 BLT (HCD)-32

Order-22 Rule-3

The Code of Civil Procedure does not prescribe any special “Form” for making such application for substitution. But as a matter of practice such application is made furnishing the legal requirements viz, the date of death of the deceased, names and other particulars of his heirs to be substituted and their relationship with the deceased and as to whether such applica tion has been made within the prescribed period of limitation.

Md. Siddique Rahman & Ors. Vs. Profulla Bala Devi & Ors. 6BLT (AD)-57

Order 22 rule-3

Under Order 22 Rule 3 of the Code of Civil Procedure is concerned. Under this rule a legal representative can only prosecute the cause of action originally framed and similarly, a defendant cannot raise any defence which he could not have raised against the deceased Plaintiff himself.

Swarupa Banu & Ors Vs. Ankura Begum & Ors 15 BLT (HCD)118

Order-22 Rule-3 read with Order-22 Rule-10

Substitution of the “Legal representatives”

The suit is for cancellation of the deed in question of the ground that the deed dated 16.08.1977 is forged deed. Opposite parties No. 1-5 claim that they are in possession of the suit land on the basis of purchase from sole plaintiff Lal Mohon by registered deeds and that they have acquired interest in the suit land. Therefore, they claim that they may be allowed to prosecute the suit since Lal Mohon is dead—Held: No question of substitution of the opposite parties No. 1-5 under Order 22 Rule 3 C.P.C the death of sole plaintiff Lal Mohon arises at all, firstly because, they opposite parties are not the legal heirs of the deceased Lal Mohon nor successors of the deceased nor are they executors or administrators of the deceased’s estate appointed by the deceased and as such, they are not legal representatives within the meaning of 2(11) of the Code of Civil Procedure. Secondly since the heirs of Lal Mohon are already on record on question of abetment arises at all —l am of the view that Order 22 Rule 10 C.P.C is the only provision of law on which, they may be allowed to be substituted and leave to be granted to continue the suit.

Abu Taher Bhuiyan Vs. Sri Lal Mohon Mondal & Ors. 10 BLT (HCD)-127

Order-22 Rule-4(4)

Five Miscellaneous cases were filed under section 96 for pre-emption. During pendency of these cases opposite party No. 2, 13 & 22 died leaving behind heirs. The petitioners of all these cases filed petitions for striking out the name of the deceased opposite parties — the trial court rejected the prayer for striking out the names of deceased opposite parties on the ground that the case already abated for not substituting the heirs of those deceased opposite parties—the lower appellate court set aside the order of abatement the High Court Division affirmed the appellate order — Held The High Court Division rightly held that the amendment made by the Calcutta High Court before 1947 is a part of Bangladesh law and are effective as other laws in Bangladesh—the heirs of the deceased defendants were not necessary parties because their predecessors in spite of receipt of notices of the original cases did not appear and file any application for ratable pre-emption as co-petitioners—petition is dismissed.

Most T. Banu & Ors. Vs. Md. YusufAli & Ors. 4BLT (AD)-82

Order-22 Rule-4 (4)

In the instant case a definite Saham measuring 1.31 acres of land was allotted to deceased defendant No. 5 Abdus Salam he had and after his death, his legal representatives have a right to get possession in their allotted Saham with reference to the existing possession of the parties but unless they were brought on record their interests can be said to be properly safeguarded by the action of the Advocate Commissioner, against whose report written objection had already been filed. Since evidently the final decree was passed against deceased defendant No. 5 Abdus Salam, after two months of his death without bringing his legal representatives on record by way of substitution, it is to be held that vital interests of the petitioners have been adversely affected in effecting the final decree in their absence.

Kabirunnessa & Ors Vs. Abdul Shahid & Ors. 5BLT (HCD)-189

Order—22 Rule—9

Whether the appeal stood abated as a whole on account of failure to substitute the heirs and ugal representatives as the plaintiff No.2

It appears that the suit was for declaration of title and recovery of khas possession and for further declaration that the suit property was not a vested property. The share of the Plaintiff No. 1 and 2 has not been specified in the suit-stood abated as a whole on account of the death of the Respondent No. 2 and on account of non substitution of his heirs within 90 days.

Md. Raziur Rahman Chowdhury Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh & Ors 14 BLT (HCD)381

Order —22 rule 9(2)

It appears that originally the suit was pending before, the Court of Munsif, Thakurgaon, Dinajpur, till 31 .5.1984. Thereafter, the suit was transferred to the Court of Munsif at Birganj and was renumbered as Other Class Suit No. 5 of 1984. This was recorded in the Order sheet of the said Court on 30.9.1984. It appears from the order sheet that on 2.12.1984, the defendants made their appearance and 10.12.1984 was fixed for settling date of the suit. By the Order No. 5, dated 10.12.1984, the settling date was again fixed on 25.12.1984. In the meantime earlier on 12.12.1984, the heirs of the plaintiff filed an application divulging the date of death of the plaintiff on 28.9.1984 and prayed for amendment of the plaint by substituting them in place of the deceased plaintiff. This shows that there was no laches on their part in appearing and making the application for substitution on the very first opportunity. Even if we assume that the sole plaintiff died on 28.7.1984 but because of the transfer of the suit obviously no petition could be made within the statutory period of 90 days and the learned Assistant Judge was well justified in holding that there was substantial cause for which the heirs of the sole deceased plaintiff could not make their appearance earlier within the statutory period of limitation specially when the materials on record do not disclose culpable negligence or mala fides on their part.

Hafizuddin & Anr Vs. Moherjan & Ors 15 BLT (HCD)88

Order-22 Rule-9(2)(3)

Principle on Abatement

Abatement on the death of a party to a legal proceeding follows automatically unless his heirs and heiresses are substituted within the prescribed time. To substantiate the legal representatives of the deceased party on setting aside abatement, the applicant is required to prove that he had no earlier knowledge about the death of the deceased party and he had no laches and negligence in making the prayer for setting aside abatement. In view of the fact that abatement is essentially a technical default, which may deal a shattering blow to his claims, the court is usually inclined to consider an application for setting aside abatement liberally, unless there are gross laches and negligence on the part of the applicant.

Garakh Nath Shib Thakur Vs. Md. Fatikuddin Mondal & Ors. 7BLT (HCD)-202

Order-22 Rule-9(2)(3)

In the instant case, though the learned Subordinate Judge did not accept that plaintiff No. 14 was the sole tadbirkar for the plaintiffs in the suit, he found that plaintiff No. 1 was a simpleton and took a merciful view to the default of the surviving plaintiffs in the absence of any willful negligence on their part. He gave them the benefit of section 5 of the limitation Act and set aside the order of abatement in his discretion to achieve the ends of justice—The application for substitution after setting aside abatement filed in the present case substantially contains the prayer for condonation of the delay describing circumstances. Therefore the Subordinate Judge was not much wrong in treating the application as one also for condonation of delay.

Abdul Kader Mondal &Ors. Vs. Md. Shamsur Rahman Chowdhury & Ors 8 BLT (AD)-82

Order-22 rule 9(3)

It appears that the date of knowledge of death is not relevant. Ignorance of the date of death does not furnish sufficient ground for setting aside abatement. There must be a good ground for ignorance not attributable to negligence. Thus it appears that the grounds taken in the application for setting aside abatement due to ignorance of the date or news of death of the sole defendant or that the plaintiff being the government has, allegedly little chance of knowledge about any persons death or the news of death was not brought to the notice of the court by the defendant in due time are not at all sustainable in law.

Gopal Chandra Shil and Ors Vs Govt of Bangladesh 14 BLT (IICD)19

Order 22 Rule-9(3) read with Limitation Act Article- 177

The period of limitation to file an application to set aside the abatement order begins to run from the actual date of abatement, and not from the date of passing of an order of abatement. If, on the expiry of 90 days from the date of the defendant’s death, no application is made to impaled his legal representatives, the suit or appeal automatically abates or dies. From that moment time begins to run and unless within 60 days from the date of abatement an application be made under Order 22 Rule 9 the matter ends, as has been observed by various jurist of the sub continent.

Gopal Chandra Shil and Ors Vs Govt of Bangladesh 14 BLT (HCD)19

order-22 Rule-10

Order-22 Rule-10

In the instant case. Late Pro

In the instant case. Late Probat Chandra Das, in the year 1332 B.S. dedicated the suit properties to his family deities by registered Arpannama. Last Shebayet Chitta Ranjan Das migrated to India in 1981 without making any arrangement to perform Sheba Puja and look after the debattar property. That the local Hindu community in a meeting formed a broad-based trust committee and elected the appellant as its Secretary—the appellant as the Secretary of the Committee is ‘entitled to be substituted in place of Shebayet-defendants.

Falguni Majumder Vs. Mokbul Hossain Biswas & Ors. 7BLT (AD)-12

Order-22 Rule-10

Defendant No. 3 as plaintiff filed a suit for declaration of his title to the suit land and obtained an ex parte decree against the present opposite parties—Defendant No. 3 transferred the suit land to the present petitioner by a registered kabala after ex parte decree. The opposite party Nos. 1-5 have filed a title suit for declaration that the exparte decree is void—the petitioner filed a petition for adding him as party to the suit when the trial was started but the learned trial court rejected the petition— the interest of defendant No. 3 in suit land has been devolved upon the petitioner by a registered kabala, so the defendant No. 3 has got no interest in the suit land and if he does not contest in the suit the petitioner will suffer—hence in the interest of justice, the petitioner should be added as party to contest the suit—Rule made absolute.

RafiqulAlam Bhuiyan Vs GaziAlam & Ors. 2BLT (HCD)-137

Order-22 rule-10

It appears from the record that the Suit was filed in the year 1997 and the Opposite Party Nos. 4-16 claimed to have purchased by as many as 11 kabala deeds of different dates i.e. from 29.3.1987 to 09.4.1996. The Opposite Party Nos. 4-16 have asserted their possession in 31½ decimals of land. This being the fact— The Opposite Party Nos. 4-16 being purchaser on the basis of registered kabala deeds are entitled to be added as party in the appeal under Order 22 Rule 10 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

Abdul Sobahan & Ors Vs. Noresh Chandra Mondal & Ors 15 BLT (HCD)91

Order 22 Rule-10 read with section 146

The petitioner as the assignee of defendant No.5 claiming interest in the suit property may file an appeal as a third party or stranger though he was not a party in the suit if his interest is affected by an order or a decreed as was asserted to have been caused by the impugned judgment and decree.

Mansur Ali Howlader Vs. Nurul Islam Howlader 13BLT(HCD) 71

Order 23 Rule 1

Withdrawal of Appeal along with Suit

When the title of the plaintiff was seriously contested simple suit for eviction was doomed to fail. And seeking a decree of declaration of title, the plaintiff is required to state clearly the history of title as he could trace.

In the circumstances, we are of the view if the appellant is not allowed to sue afresh for a decree of declaration of title he would be deprived of an opportunity to vindicate his right to the property in question. The application therefore merits consideration.

Dil Mohammad Vs. Jamir Hossain & Ors 13 BLT (HCD)285

Order—23 Rule—1

The original defendant Nos. 3-6 after being transposed as plaintiffs on 13.3.2002 filed an application under Order 6 Rule 17 of the Code of Civil Procedure for amendment of the plaint stating that the plaintiff No.1 and defendant No. 1 are in exclusive possession of their paternal suit property as described in “Gh’ schedule of the plaint which needs to be recovered from the possession of the plaintiff No.1 and defendant No.1 by a decree of recovery of Khass possession from them. On the other hand, on 13.4.2003 the plaintiff No. 1 also filed an application under Order 23 Rule 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure to withdraw the suit for filing the same afresh- Held; It appears to us that the application filed by the plaintiff-petitioner under order 23 Rule 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure is Misconceived and incompetent in the sets and circumstances of the case.

Nurun Nahar & Ors. Vs. Begum Asmatunnessa Khatun & Ors 14 BLT (HCD)343

Order 23 Rule—1

After conversion of the Arbitration Miscellaneous case into a title suit the Respondent was shown as the plaintiff of the so converted title suit This being the position the Respondent as plaintiff was competent to file an application under Order 23, Rule 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure seeking withdrawal of the suit in which he is a plaintiff. The trial Court being quite unmindful of the said state of the matter and the provision of law rejected the prayer for withdrawal of the suit and consequently committed error which had legally been interfered by the High Court Division.

Sena Kalyan Sangstha Vs. Bangladesh Thai Aluminum Ltd 15 BLT (AD)172

Order-23 Rule 1(2)

As to the formal defect or Mistake there is no legal bar in granting an application for withdrawal of a suit with liberty to instituted a fresh suit for the same cause of action even at the revisional stage if the other requirements are fully complied with.

Abdul Wahed Mia Vs. Saia Khatun 3 BLT (HCD)-148.

Order-23 Rule-1(2)

The grounds for withdrawal with permission to sue afresh on the same cause of action must necessarily be vital defects which out at the very root of the plaintiffs case and renders him non-suited. It is thus manifest that where the trial court dismissed the suit not only on formal defects but also for want of merit in the plaintiffs case, permission to withdraw the suit with liberty to sue afresh on the same subject. matter is clearly not contemplated in law.

Md. Habibur Rahman Paiker Vs. Sree G. G. Datta &Ors. 6BLT (HCD)-146

Order-23 Rule-1(2)

In this case no permission to sue afresh was either sought or accorded. The plaintiffs suit was dismissed and the withdrawal of the suit without any permission to sue afresh will not prejudice any vested interest of the defendants j who cannot be vexed with any further litigation on the same cause of action. The defendants will not suffer. The order of setting aside of the decrees of dismissal while according permission to withdraw the suit being in consequence of the order of withdrawal is perfectly justified.

Abdur Rahim & Ors. Vs. Kheru Malitha & Ors. 5BLT (AD)-216

 

 

Order-23 Rule- 1(2)

Issues were framed-Plaintiff filed a petition for withdrawal of the suit with permission to sue afresh—Hold : On perusal of the application itself for withdrawal of the suit with permission to sue afresh I find it has not been stated specifically what are the legal, formal or other defects which cannot be cured even by amendment of the plaint. All the assertions made there in the petition are vague and made in lump. When an application is filed under order 23, rule 1(2) of the Code of Civil procedure for withdrawal of a suit with liberty to institute a fresh suit, the first thing is that the court has to decide whether there is any formal defect or sufficient ground for which the withdrawal should be allowed.

A.KM. Mozammel Hoque Vs. Md. Nazrul Islam & Anr. 10 BLT (HCD)-167

Orders 23(1)(2)

The formal defect of “Other sufficient grounds” as under sub rule 2 of rule-1 of Order 23 C.P.C should be liberally construed and there is no legal bar in granting an application for withdrawal of a suit with liberty to file a suit afresh on the self-same matter even at the revisional stage provided the other requirements of the aforesaid provisions of law are fully complied with.

Mustafa Kabiruddin Ahmed Vs. Mst. Badrun Nessa Chowdhury. 10 BLT (HCD)-220

Orcler-23 Rules-1 and 2

Withdrawal of suit and institution of fresh suit for the same subject matter

The plaintiff is at liberty to withdraw his suit at any stage without any permission from the Court but he needs permission for withdrawal if he wants to sue afresh on the same cause of action, without which he shall be precluded from bringing a fresh suit on the same subject- matter. An appeal being a continuation of the suit, it is always open to the appellant to unconditionally withdrew his appeal without the intervention of the Court. According permission to the appellant to withdraw his appeal but refused to allow his prayer to file afresh suit on the same cause of action is illegal and arbitrary.

Shaymal Chandra Roy Vs. Probhat Ch. Roy 7BLT (HCD)-212

Order-25 Rule-1

Held: We find that at any stage of a suit filed by a non-resident foreigner having non- sufficient immovable property in Bangladesh can be directed by the court suo motu or on the application of the defendant to give security for payment of all costs incurred or likely to be incurred by the defendant. There is nothing in the aforesaid provision that such a plaintiff can be directed to give security only after filing of the written statement. It is the discretion of the court to direct such a plaintiff to give security for the cost. If the court finds considering the facts and circumstances of the case that such security is to be furnished either before or after filing the written statement that cannot also be found fault with. But the court should not reject the prayer for furnishing security by such a plaintiff merely on the ground that written statement has not been put in. The court should consider the merit or otherwise of the application before rejecting it. In the instant case the defendant petitioner is not precluded from filing a fresh application for furnishing security by the plaintiff for cost of the suit after filing written statement.

Danish Milk Bangladesh Ltd. Vs. Danish Dairy Board. (AD)-192

Order-26 Rule-1

Commissioner’s power—Trial Court on application of the plaintiff, passed order that the deposition of the plaintiff who is a pardanashin lady would be recorded on commission by an Advocate Commissioner at her residence—the Advocate Commissioner fixed 22.6.89 for taking down the deposition but the plaintiff having with an application on 21.6.89 supported by a medical certificate and prayed for shifting the date. Commissioner rejected her prayer and submitted report to the trial court stating that the plaintiff was not ill.

Held: The Commissioner has exceeded the jurisdiction in two ways, first, the application of the petitioner to adjourn the date for taking down her deposition in not submitting the same to the court for necessary order and secondly, observing that it seemed to him that she was not ill, disbelieved medical certificate.

Rabeya Khanam Vs. Asstt. Comm. Housing & Settlement & Ors. 3BLT (HCD)-160

Order-26 Rule-1

For examination of the widow mother on Commission—witness is very much pardanashin and never goes out of her residence after the death of her husband — the application for examination of the widow mother of the petitioner on commission is allowed.

Pallab Kumar Deb Vs. Gonendra Chandra 5BLT (HCD)-18

Order-26 rule-1

Plaintiff No. 1 was aged about 72 years and was sick—the application rejected on the ground that no paper in Support of Sickness was filed —Held: learned joint District judge was not right in refusing to exercise the jurisdiction vested to him just on surmise that the witness might not to be sick.

Alhaj Badiuzzaman & Ors Vs. Government of Bangladesh & Ors 12 BLT (HCD)184

Order 26 Rule-1

Application Under Order.26 rule. 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure —neither any such ground as required under Rule 1 of order XXVI has been made out in the application nor the Tribunal gave any finding of its own or assigning any reason whatsoever as required thereunder —Order is Liable to be set aside.

Alhaj M.Kamaluddin Chowdhury Vs. M. Anowarul Azim & Ors. 13 BLT (HCD) 65

Order-26 Rule-5

Defendant No. 1 is an ailing person and he is suffering from several diseases and is bed- ridden at Karachi but his attorney is living in Bangladesh and is capable of giving evidence and contest the present suit on behalf of this principle. Even his son being young man could come from Karachi and depose the case—the application for examination of the two witnesses at Karachi was rightly rejected.

Shawkat Ara Begum Vs Md. Wajuddin & Ors. 2 BLT (HCD)-226.

Order-26 Rule-7

Principle — Commissioner report

The report submitted by the Advocate Commissioner on a local investigation is just a piece of evidence like any other evidence. The court may accept it or reject it. Acceptance of the report of the Commissioner does not mean that the court is bound to act upon it in preference to other evidence on record. The court will, of course, consider the Commissioner report along with other evidence and will be at liberty to draw its own conclusions on the totality of the evidence and the legal incidence that clearly flows therefrom. The parties shall be at libertly to adduce evidence at the trial in support of their respective cases.

Malahar Balika Junior High School & Ors. Vs. Matri Managal Junior High School & Ors 8 BLT (HCD)-53

Order-26 Rule-9

Local investigation for relying the suit land in a suit for Permanent injunction. Since there is no specific provision that in a suit permanent injunction, local investigation cannot be allowed and also the subject matter of local investigation as stated in the application, Annexure-A that the survey knowing advocate Commissioner should be appointed to rely the suit land with the Map physically I find no bar to allow the application for appointing Commissioner.

Mrs. Sufia Khatun Vs. Shamsuddin Ahmed Babul & Ors. 9BLT (HCD)-135

Order-26 Rule-9

Appellate Courts jurisdiction-the suit was brought for declaration of title simplicitor in respect of 25 decimals of land of Town survey plot No. 184--Held, we find no bar for the appellate court to exercise the jurisdiction under order XXVI rule 9 of the Code in the facts of a case. Such step is definitely taken as an aid of the final decision that may be arrived at in the appeal.

Sree Ratan Chandra Deb Gupta Vs. Comilla Pourashava 12 BLT (HCD)290

Order-26, Rule-9

The object of the local investigation under 26 Rule 9 of the Code of Civil Procedure is to obtain evidence which from its peculiar nature can best be had from the spot itself. Such evidence enables the court to properly and correctly understand and assess the evidence on record. It appears that earlier two inspections were held under order 39 Rule 7 of the Code of Civil Procedure. Local investigations as it is expected would determine the disputed claim of parties by spot visits by a survey knowing advocate. Local investigation is necessary for the purpose of elucidating the matter in dispute and in the present case the plaintiff made specific prayer for determining the fact whether the alleged unauthorized construction work has been done attracting or covering the disputed land and drain on the suit plot No. 2075.

Ashik Mia Vs. Bokshi Koysor Rashid & Ors 12 BLT (HCD) 452

Order-26 Rule-9

Suit for simple permanent injunction

It appears that the plaintiff filed the suit praying for a decree for permanent injunction in respect of the suit land asserting his exclusive possession in the suit land but the defendant contested the suit filing written statement stating the suit land as vague and uncertain. Under the circumstances the plaintiff filed a prayer for local inspection of the suit land for ascertaining the question of structure standing thereon. The defendant as well filed an application under order 26 of rule 9 of the Code of Civil Procedure for holding local investigation of the suit land in order to ascertain the suit plot and its boundary through an Advocate Commissioner. By order dated 15.10.1998 the learned Assistant Judge allowed both the prayers but the plaintiff being aggrieved by the order allowing local investigation on application of the defendant moved the High Court Division and the High Court Division discharged the Rule holding, inter-alia, that the defendant raised the prayer of identity of the suit land and sought for a local investigation to ascertain the same in order to resolve the issue involved in the suit -application is dismissed.

Secretary Zilla Parishad & Ors Vs. Md. Ali Ashraf Khan & Ors 16 BLT(AD)159

 Order-26 Rule-12(2)

 An issue has to be framed on acceptance of the evidence (the report of the Accounts Commissioner) before the suit goes on trial as contended by the petitioners counsel

Held: According to this provision it is discretion of the Court to direct further inquiry if court thinks fit on examination of the report submitted by the Accounts Commissioner. Acceptance of the report and order to consider at the time of hearing cannot be said that submission of the report simpliciter makes it obligatory on the part of the court to consider the same which according to the provision is evidenced before trial—In this case the Artha Rin Adalat has rightly directed that the report would be considered at the time of preemptory hearing of the suit.

Serajuddin Hawlader Vs. Pubali Bank 4BLT (HCD)-80

Order-26 Rules-13 and 14

Commission to make partition of immovable property and the procedures to be followed by the Commissioner

Order 26 Rule 13 of the Code authorises the Court to issue commission to make partition of undivided properties according to the rights declared by the Court while rule 14 provides the procedures for the Commissioner to prepare and allot sahams to the contending parties and to submit report to the Court. After hearing any objection against the Commissioners report, the Court may vary or set aside the report on the merit of the objection.

In the instant case, on receipt of an application for execution of the award decree the learned Execution Court straightway issued writ to the Commissioner for effecting delivery of possession to the applicant in an undivided and unspecified joint property without making the preliminary decree final in accordance with law. The action of the Execution Court is evidently illegal and arbitrary.

Md. Mizanur Rahrnan Khan & Anr. Vs. Mrs. Jinnatul Ferdous & Ors. 7BLT (HCD)-278

Order-27 Rule-4

Service of summons on the Government Pleader is good service on the Government

Govt. of Bangladesh Vs. Ramananda Sarker 9BLT (AD)-30

Order-32 Rule-3

In Rule 3 the word “shall is construed to be mandatory and not directory. The above provision manifests that a minor is to be represented by a proper person as his guardian in the civil proceedings through the trial, appeal or revision and in no case he would be unrepresented or to be placed ex parte for the one reason or the other. The appointment of a guardian, therefore, of minor heirs of defendant who died during pendency of suit is absolutely necessary. A minor cannot be considered to be a party to suit unless he is properly represented in a suit by a duly qualified and competent guardian. When a minor has legally become a party to the suit, only then the court would acquire jurisdiction to decide the case. Decree passed against an unrepresented minor defendant being a decree against a person not a party to the suit would be without jurisdiction, null and void. In other words it can be said that a decree passed against a minor defendant not property represented is without jurisdiction and a nullity.

Mohammad. Azim & Ors. Vs. Doly Islam & Ors. 7BLT (HCD)-164

Order-32 rule-3

The appointment of guardian ad-litems is not a mere formality. It is an imperative duty of the Court. It is the duty of the Court to see that minor’s interest is properly represented as a decree passed against a minor without proper guardian-ad-litem being appointed for him is a nullity (1929 Cal. 586) and accordingly the decree against the said minors was a nullity and the same was not binding upon them.

Sahani Bibi & Ors. Vs. Nurul Islam & Ors 12 BLT (AD)-11

Order-34

P.O. No. 88 of 1972 created special forum for restoration of mortgaged property. But it did not take away right of redemption available to a mortgagor by filing a mortgage suit under Order 34 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

Asmat Ali Vs. Abdur Rafique Mridha & Ors. 9BLT (AD)-12

Order-34 Rule-2(1)

In a suit for sale the preliminary decree is drawn up in the same manner as in a suit for foreclosure—the plaintiff-appellant is entitled to interest ‘pendent lite’ i.e. from the date of the institution of the suit up to the date of the passing of the decree.

Sonali Bank Vs. M/S Begg and Beg Jute Incorporated Ltd. & Ors. 6 BLT (AD)-174.

Order-34 read with P.O. 88 of 1972

The filing of a suit for redemption of mortgage in a civil court is wholly different from filing an application under P.O. 88 of 1972 before the Revenue Authority - P.O. No. 88 of 1972 created special forum for restoration of mortgaged property. But it did not take away right or redemption available to a mortgagor by filing a mortgage suit under Order 34 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

Asmat Ali Vs. Abdur Rafique Mridha & Ors. 9 BLT (AD)-77.

Order-37 Rules-1 & 2

Summary procedure on negotiable instruments and institution of summary suits upon bills of exchange, promissory notes etc.—.F.D.R. receipts are not negotiable instruments While depositing money on a fixed deposit or time deposit by a client, the bank issues to him a deposit receipt, which is usually marked as not negotiable. it can, of course, be transferred to third parties by way of assignment but that by itself does not make an F.D.R. receipt a promissory note as defined in the Negotiable Instruments Act. Consequently, the provisions of Order 37 of the Code have no application to F.D.R. receipts.

Rupali Bank Ltd. Vs. Federal Insurance Co. Ltd. 7 BLT (HCD)-244.

Order-38 Rule-5

Plaintiffs application for attachment before judgment does not disclose any particulars in support of the allegation which obviously are vague—which calls for an interference revision is allowed.

Md. Israil Hossain Vs M/S. Himalaya Ice & Cold Storage Ltd. 2BLT (HCD)-67

Order- 38 Rule-5

Dispute between the buyer and the seller

No order could be passed under Order 38 rule 5 of the Code of Civil Procedure against the proceeds of letter of credit.

Cooryonly (BD) Textile Ltd Vs. Chartkar Informa. Holding Ltd & Ors. 9BLT (AD)-114

Order 38, rule 5

Whether the defendants he entitled to get the aid of Provisions of Order 38 rule 5

Defendants of any suit have no concern with 38 rule 5 of Code of pray for attachment the provisions of Order Civil Procedure as to before judgment.

Abdur Rahman Bepari & Ors. Vs Most: Rahima Khatun & Ors 14 BLT (HCD)133

Order-39

Mandatory injunction — it appears that on consideration of the facts of the case the trial court was satisfied that the plaintiff- respondents succeeded in making out a prima facie case for injunction in respect of the disputed shops and that the locking of th same by the defendant-petitioners was contrary to equity and justice. The High Court Division also noticed that the defendant- petitioners received the notice of the application for injunction and pre-empted the plaintiff- respondents in order to forestall all possible orders of the courts in favour of the plaintiffs. In such a situation this court had already held in Abdul Jalil Munshi and another Vs. Abu Bakar Siddique, 35 DLR (AD) 42 that a mandatory injunction was justified, we have nothing to depart from this view.

Bangladesh Railway & Ors Vs. Abdul Mannan & Ors. 5BLT (AD)-217

Order-39 Rule-1

(a) The plaintiffs petitioners instituted a suit for partition and in that suit they filed an application for temporary injunction restraining the defendants opposite parties l-5 from withdrawing compensation money awarded due to acquisition of some of the suit land and prayed also restraining the land acquisition officer from paying the said compensation money to the said defendants— the said defendants 1-5, objected to the said prayer by filing written objection but did not file any written statements when the matter of temporary injunction was heard — both the courts below refused to grant temporary injunction to the plaintiffs, on the ground that the plaintiffs could not file any documents or papers in support of their claim of title to the suit properties and also held that the plaintiffs might be adequately compensated in the event of their success in the suit A prima facie case is not necessarily to be shown by filing documents or papers a prima facie case is spelt out in the plaint in which’ the partition will go on trial and as such the court has to consider- the question whether there is a good prima facie case or not on careful consideration of the pleadings but the courts below have a finding that there was no prima fade case without considering the pleadings the judgment and orders — of the courts below are set aside the prayer for ad interim injunction as prayed for is allowed.

Abdul jabbar Vs SultanMia & Ors. 2BLT (HCD)-139

Order-39 Rule-1

In the declaration suit the plaintiff prayed for temporary injunction which was i-ejected by the trial Judge after holding that as the disputed madrasha had already been shifted but lower Appellate Court granted the prayer for temporary injunction after holding that the defendants could not produce any paper before the court for showing that the said madrasha had already been shifted to the new site. This being purely a finding of fact High Court Division found that the balance of convenience is in favour of the plaintiff and has rightly refused to interfere — hence maintained the injunction order.

Md. Abul Hossain & Ors Vs. Md. Salamatullah & Ors. 2BLT (AD)-58

Order-39 Rule-1

The lease having been granted initially for 3 years it cannot be said that the plaintiff has acquired continuing right in the suit fishery after the expiry of the lease period. The learned Judges of the High Court Division rightly considered the reported decision of 40 DLR (AD)-62 and refused to grant injunction as plaintiff has no inchoate right over the fishery which can be protected by an order of injunction.

Mathshyajibi Samabaya Samity Ltd. Vs. The Revenue Deputy Collector & Ors. 4BLT (AD)-228

Order 39 Rule-1

Mandatory requirements—I find from the original plaint filed along with revisional application that the lands of S. A. Khatian No. 593 Dag Nos. 2338 and 2329 have not been fully described — they are not entitled to get any relief even if they succeed in proving their title—relied on 42 DLR (HCD) 434.

Abdul Hashem Mollah & Ors. Vs. Ukiluddin & Ors. 4BLT (HCD)-202

Order-39 Rule-1

Whether an order of temporary injunction can be granted by a civil court in respect of a sale notice published under Article 34 of the Bangladesh Shilpa Rin Sangstha Order, 1972 in view of the embargo put under Article 34 (5) (a) (III) of the said order

Bangladesh Shilpa Rin Sangstha Order, 1972 is a special law and the Sangstha has got the authority to publish the sale notice for the purpose of selling the industrial concern—Held It is palpably clear that the learned trial Judge as well as the learned Judges of the High Court Division acted illegally and without jurisdiction in granting temporary injunction in a matter covered under Article 34 of the BSRS order which is a special enactment and it will prevail over general law.

Bangladesh Shilpa Rin Sangstha Vs. Aziruddin Choudhury 7 BLT (AD)-81.

Order-39 Rule-1

Whether ad interim status quo order need to be reasonable order

Both the petitioner and respondent No.5 are claiming the goods. The petitioner is claiming the goods as importer and respondent No.5 is claiming as auction purchaser of the said goods. Thus we feel that the status quo order need to be maintained till disposal of the writ petition.

M/S. South Asia Mercantile Vs. Commissioner of Customs & Ors. 7BLT(AD)-144

Order-39 Rule-1

In an application under Order 39 Rule 1 C.P.C the precise question needs to be decided is whether the plaintiffs proved a prima facie case in his favour to obtain an order of injunction. In the instant case the learned Judges of the High Court Division rightly found that the plaintiffs failed to prove so. An order of injunction is not to issue merely on the plea of the plaintiffs that the defendants are trying to take forcibly possession of the property in a case in execution for satisfaction of such decree.

Abu Matbar and Others Vs. Shahidul Islam & Ors 8BLT (AD)-287

Order-39 Rule-1

Ad-interim mandatory injunction the plaintiff was admittedly, as is averred in the plaint, dispossessed by the police on 22.05.2000. So by the order it was intended to restore possession to the plaintiff, which is simply beyond the jurisdiction of the Court. It should be noted that such extra-ordinary jurisdiction cannot be used as a device to restore possession to a party in a suit who is out of possession since before the institution of the suit.

Fulbaria Adarsha Market Dokandar Malik Samity Vs. Fulbaria Adarsha Market Khatigrastha Dokander Kallyan Samabaya Samity 9 BLT (HCD)-157

Order-39 Rule-1

Order directing the parties to maintain status quo

It appears that the trial court passed the order directing the parties to maintain status quo in the matter which was affirmed by the High Court Division. When the suit is still pending and the defendant has already filed written statement and there is an order to maintain status quo, we are not inclined to interfere in the matter at this stage.

Sikam Fashion Ltd. Vs. Miaco Ltd. & Ors. 10 BLT (AD)-39

 

 

Order-39 Rule-1

Question of injunction against construction in urban areas

Suit for partition—scarcity of land and pressure for accommodation either for residential of commercial purposes in urban areas are growing hand in hand every day while the time for resolution of a dispute particularly, regarding partition is so uncertain that nobody can say certainly when it will finally come to an end. In such situation, right of a co-sharer to develop the land by a interlocutory order of injunction till partition, which would be inequitable.

Abul Kalam Engineer & Anr. Vs. M. Nasiruddin Howlader & Ors. 10 BLT (HCD)-435.

Order-39 Rule-1

Temporary mandatory injunction

The plaintiffs are claiming title and possession in the land in suit asserting that they inherited the land in Ka’ and Kha’ schedules from their father Mofaruddin Sarkar. After instituting the suit the plaintiffs filed an application for temporary injunction and thereupon the Court granted ad-interim injunction restraining the defendants from disturbing possession of the plaintiffs in the land in suit. Subsequent to the order of ad-interim injunction the defendants dispossessed the plaintiffs from the ‘Kha schedule land. Thereupon plaintiffs filed an application with the prayer for temporary mandatory injunction for directing the defendants to restore possession of the ‘Kha” schedule land.-Held; High Court Division has committee no error in refusing to interfere with the order of the learned District Judge passed in the Miscellaneous Appeal affirming the order of the learned Assistant Judge allowing the prayer for mandatory injunction and thereupon making direction to the defendants to vacate the land of Kha’ schedule and to restore possession thereof to the plaintiffs.

Rozanur Ahmed Dulal & Ors. Vs. Mst. Fatema khatun & Anr. 12 BLT (AD) 132

Order-39, Rule-1

In Partition suit

Being in possession of the land which the plaintiffs purchased, the plaintiffs have got no right to put a restraint by way of injunction upon other co-sharers in specific possession to enjoy their share the way they think best.

Moshfiqur Rahman Vs. Md. Shiru Mia & Ors 12 BLT (HCD)471

Order 39 rule – 1

Dispute being pending between the parties and there being application for restraining the present petitioner and others from making pucca construction or changing the nature of the suit land, the lower appellate court, in the facts and circumstances considered it fit to pass an order directing the parties to maintain status quo.

A.N.M. GaziulAzim Vs. M.A. Kader& Ors 14 BLT (AD)175

Order 39 rule-1

Ad-interim injunction and ad-interim mandatory injunction.

The plaintiff was alleged to have been appointed distributor under the defendant Nos.l and 2 and that admittedly the petitioner continued as a distributor till 29.1 .2003. The alleged violation of any contract between the plaintiffs and the defendant could be compensated by monetary compensation and as such the plaintiffs are not entitled to any injunction—since the alleged cancellation was dated 29.1.2003 with the assertion of the defendants that they have been carrying on their business appointing another distributor for the purpose and that the suit has been filed on 9.8.2003, the plaintiffs do not have any prima facie case for injunction inasmuch as and to restore possession thereof to the plaintiffs.

Rozanur Ahmed Dulal & Ors. Vs. Mst. Fatema Khatun & Anr 12 BLT (AD)132

Order 39 Rule-1

Suit for declaration that the managing Committee constituted with the defendant No.1-10 and approved by the defendant No.12 to be illegal, unlawful, void and not binding upon the plaintiff —In the instant case the plaintiff being the Headmaster and the managing Committee in question having started functioning since before the filing of the suit there lies no prayer for temporary injunction against the said committee as prayed for.

Altab Hosen & Ors Vs. Md. Muhammad Ali & Ors 15 BLT (HCD) 187.

Order-39 Rules-1&2

Admittedly, State Acquisition Record of Right stands in the name of the plaintiff school. The claim of the defendant Mosque that the record of right standing in the name of the plaintiff school is wrong cannot be determined in this inter-locutory matter like temporary injunction and that can be decided only by legal evidences on the institution of a proper suit to that effect. The plaintiff has filed rent receipts showing payment of rent to the Government and also city corporation or municipal tax receipts evidencing payment of taxes to the city corporation. This payment of rent to the Government and tax to the city corporation prima facie manifests plaintiffs possession on the suit property and the plaintiff is entitled to get an order of injunction at least to preserve the subject matter in dispute in status quo.

Lakshmi Bazar Shahi Masjid Committee & Anr Vs. St. Francis Xavier Girls High School 7 BLT (HCD)-237.

Order 39 Rule-1 and 2

The courts, may grant an order of temporary injunction if it is prima facie satisfied on the papers and documents produced before it that such an order is necessary to restrain an apprehended act or make such other order for the purpose of preventing such removal of any property, as the Court thinks fit until the disposal of the suit or until further orders, such as till hearing of the petition for temporary injunction. This kind of order is the most solemn and authoritative form of order made by a Court, commanding a party to refrain from doing a particular act which is known as prohibitory injunction but when it enjoins a party to do a particular act, it is known as a mandatory injunction. Whatever form it may be if an order of injunction is made it must be obeyed.

M. M. Hossain & Ors. Vs. Saidur Rahman (Pvt.) Ltd. & Ors. 11 BLT (HCD)-349

Order-39, Rule-1 & 2

Restraining from making any construction

A person who wants to make construction must have a clear title on the land. If one is allowed to make multistoried construction on land which he purchased in excess of the share of a co-sharer, then in the event of decree in the suit, partition of such multi-storied building would thereby unnecessarily be made difficult. Moreover, it would not be just and equitable to allow such purchaser to make construction on such excess land until final adjudication of the shares of the co-tenants.

Mohammad Farid Miah Vs. Mohommad Azizur Rahman & Ors 12 BLT (HCD)469

Order-39 Rule-1 read with Section-151

The merit of the suit has got nothing to do with the matter of granting an order of mandatory injunction. The outcome of the suit will depend on its merit on evidence but an order in the nature of mandatory injunction will be issued to remedy an immediate wrong, perpetrated by the offending party in obtaining an advantageous position, by bringing him back to where he was at the time to institution of the suit and to maintain status quo ante till the suit and to finally settled. The administration of justice requires it is justifiable, of necessity, is to be issues forthwith and should not be delayed to any further period or till hearing of the suit on any pretext or excuse, otherwise, confidence of the people on the administration of justice shall be seriously shaken up to the detriment of the society as a whole.

Md. Mobasher Hossain &Ors. Vs. M/S Saidur Rahman (Pvt.) Lts. & Ors. 10BLT (HCD)-278

Order-39 Rules-1& 2 read with Section- 151
