Temporary mandatory injunction—in an appellate stage—affairs of the executive committee on one side and the ad-hoc committee on the other side—it appears that the executive committee of the plaintiffs claim themselves as the lawful committee as duly elected committee and their claim is their life, the life of the plaintiffs executive committee has been lawfully and duly extended by the general body of the samity wherein 107 members including defendants No. 2-10 were also present- Held I find that the learned District Judge acted within his inherent power and has rightly allowed the plaintiffs prayer for temporary injunction and restraining the defendant Nos. 1 and 2 from disturbing the plaintiffs in the management of Mymensingh-Dhaka Coach Malik Samity till disposal of the suit.

Aminul Haque Shameem &Ors Vs. A. K. M. Shamsuddin & Ors. 4 BLT (HCD)-154.

Order-39 Rules-1and 2 read with Trade Marks Act, 1940 Section-21

In an application under order XXXIX rules 1 and 2 of the Code of Civil procedure made on the allegations of infringement of Trade Marks, the Court is required to see whether the plaintiff is likely to succeed in the suit for Perpetual Injunction or not on prima facie proof of infringement of his registered Trade Mark within the Mischief of Section 21 of the Trade Marks Act, 1940 apart from the balance of convenience. It must also be noted that the concept of Prima Facie case, as we generally understand by the phrase in civil proceedings is no more relevant in Trade Marks cases.

M/S Hamja Robber Industries Vs. Golam Dostogir Gazi. 9 BLT (HCD)-280.

Order-39 Rules-1 & 2 read with Companies Act, 1913 Section-95

Balance of convenience and inconvenience

It appears from the plaint that the chairman of the company twice asked the defendant No. 2 company secretary to call a meeting of board of directors on 05.04.1999 and then, on 08.04.1999 but he did not comply with any. Thereafter, the chairman himself called the 68the meeting of the board of directors on 15.04.1999 after service of notice dated 14.04.1999 but defendants by their letter dated 14.04.1999 informed of their unwillingness to attend the meeting. The notice dated 08.04.1999 contains various agenda of which agenda no. 3 is ISL affairs. No. 3.2 attending the 9th Board Meeting of Sheba Telecom and 3.3 performance of MD. The meeting was adjourned to 28.04.1999 and the chairman was requested to request defendant Nos. 1 and 3 to attend the meeting. But they again refused to attend the adjourned meeting the writing a letter-dated 27.04.1999. After such refusal, it does not fit the mouths of the defendants that the meeting was held without in statutory notice. In the adjourned meeting, resolutions were adopted withdrawing nomination of defendant No. 1 and 3 to represent the ISL in the STL board, and also the nomination of defendant No.1 to represent as member in the managing committee of the STL. Defendant No.1 was also removed from the office of managing director and defendant No.2 company secretary on various considerations. Such holding of the meeting of the board cannot be deemed to be not duly called and held and the decisions taken therein are not valid for want of fresh notice Linder Section 95 of the Act. I also could not find any valid reason for the defendants to abstain from the meeting and/or withhold their c6operation in the transacting of important business of the company—the balance of convenience and inconvenience is clearly in favour of plaintiff.

Mr. S.I. Khan & Ors. Vs. Integrated Service Ltd.  & Ors. 10 BLT (HC’D)-130

Order 39 Rule 1 & 2 read with Section —151

Payment —against the back to back L/Cs

The petitioner Bank did not oppose the application for temporary injunction against payment under the letter of credit or took any step for vacating the order of status quo or ever challenged the same, instead paid the bulk of the amount under the letter of credit and thereafter only in July, 2002 raising the plea before the High Court Division that on enquiry by its officials revealed non-existence of the beneficiary of the letter of credits when bulk of the proceed is already paid, the issuing bank has got no right to without the payment notwithstanding the fact that the payment was not complete.

Standard Bank Ltd. Vs. Tripos Engineering and Trading Company &Ors 13 BLT (AD)201

Order-39 Rule-2

Mandatory injunction- in a case where parties are entitled to revoke or dissolve the agreement High Court Division in effect held that the trial Court ought to have heard the respondents before issuing an ex parte order of ad-interim mandatory injunction, with which we find no reason to differ.

The Dhaka Sangbadpatra Workers Bahumukhi Samabaya Samity Limited Vs. The Dainik Janakantha & Ors. 4BLT AD)-247

Order-39 rule-2

In a civil suit the parties are required to prove their respective cases on preponderance of evidence on balance of probabilities. But in a proceeding under clause 3 of Order XXXIX rule 2, since punishment of penal nature, is involved, a higher degree of proof than the balance of probability is required although not to the extent of proof beyond reasonable doubt, as in the case of criminal proceedings. The line of demarcation in such a proceeding is somewhere in between these two standards of proof, one under civil jurisdiction, the other under criminal jurisdiction. But whatever may be the standard, the Judge must be satisfied on evidence about the guilt or otherwise of the violator.

M.M. Hossain & Ors. Vs. Saidur Rahman (Pvt.) Ltd. & Ors 11 BLT (HCD)-349

Order —39 Rule —2 read with Arbitration Act, 2001 Sections 3(1) and 3(4)

The law as in Sections 3(1) and 3(4) of the Act barring the Court from granting an order of injunction is limited in application as to the arbitration being held in Bangladesh, but not as to matter restraining a particular party from proceeding with arbitration in foreign Country in respect of a contract signed in Bangladesh.

Unicol Bangladesh Ltd. & Anr Vs Maxwell Engineering Ltd & Anr. 13 BLT (AD)106

Order-39 Rule-2(3) read with Section-151 Order-21 Rule-32(2)

Suit for declaration that the result published by the Chittagong University is not binding upon the opposite party No. 1 due to the fault that the college authority did not send the tutorial marks to the university—High Court Division found on evidence on record that the authorities did not send the tutorial marks to the university before publication of the examination result of the opposite party l—Court directed the varsity to add 50% of the tutorial marks to the total marks 322 obtained by the opposite party No. 1 Rule discharged with modification of the impugned order.

University of Chittagong Vs A. K. M. Monirul Haque & Ors. 1BLT ‘HCD)-7O

Order-39 Rule-2 and Specific Relief Act, 1877 [1 of 1877] Section-55

In our jurisdiction, under Rule 2 of Order 39 of the Code of Civil procedure the Court has jurisdiction to grant an order of temporary injunction but only in a suit for perpetual injunction for restraining the defendant from committing any breach of contract or other injury of a like kind arising out of the contract. The right to get supply of the gas in protection of which the plaintiff prayed for temporary injunction as created by the contract is made subject to the duty or obligation to pay the bills of the gas consumed regularly as set out in the contract, In case of default in the payment of the bills, the right to supply of gas stands forfeited. A plaintiff can of course ask for a injunction in case of any threatened breach of the contract only after fulfilling his part of the contract by paying the bills originally at equity and now under our codified law—in a properly constituted suit the consumer has a right to an order of injunction, prohibitory or mandatory as the situation demand in case of injury, or threatened breach or breach of the contract on the proof that it has not failed in performing its part of the contract.

Managing Director, Titas Gas Vs. Immense Washing Plant & Ors. 9BLT (HCD)-304

Order —39 Clause —3 to rule-2

The Court is hot concerned with ultimate decision taken after hearing the injunction petition or after conclusion of the suit but whether the order of injunction while it was subsisting, was violated, if it was violated with the knowledge of such an order, the relevant person(s) would be liable for punishment under clause 3.

M. M. Hossain & Ors. Vs. Saidur Rahman (Pvt.) Ltd. & Ors. I1BLT (HCD)-349

Order-39 Rule-7

Belated—In the facts of the present case it will not be fit and proper to allow an inspection when the plaintiffs admittedly obtained possession of the unit in 1984 and when, after having unilaterally enjoyed possession thereof for five years, applied for inspection in 1989 when the unit was still in its possession—it will be an idle exercise to allow inspection at this stage.

Shafiq A. chowdhury & Anr. Vs. Bangladesh & Anr. 6BLT(AI))-164

Order-39 Rule-7

Appointment of an Advocate Commissioner —Court had jurisdiction to ascertain the identity of the land which is the subject matter of the application under Order 21 Rules 100 and 101 of the C.P.C.—Held: We find no fault with the order of the High Court Division passed in discretion.

Jebunnessa (Rima) Vs. Mrs. Parveen Abedin & Ors. 7BLT (AD)-341

Order —39 rule- 7

Order 39 rule 7 of the Code of Civil Procedure authorizes the Court to pass an order for inspection of the property which is the subject matter of the suit or as to which any question may arise therein. Thus when the occasion demands such power could be exercised including when inspection is necessary for proper appreciation and adjudication of the matter.

Md Baziur Rahman Mridha & Ors Vs. Mst. Asma Begum & Ors 12 BLT (‘AD)202

Order-39 Rule-7 read with Order-26 Rule-9

Investigation and inspection

Investigation however requires examination and discovery of all facts and circumstances about any fact in issue in order to obtain the truth. Investigation leads a Commissioner to go beyond what he sees on the spot and to find out the truth on behalf of the court by collecting evidence and examination of witnesses, which from its peculiar nature can be best had from the spot. Such evidence enables the Court understands or assesses the fact in issue or which clarifies or explains any point, But the Court cannot direct such Commissioner to decide any issue, which ought to be decided by Court on evidence, Assistance of the Commissioneris necessary to elucidate any ambiguous or cryptic point, which cannot be clarified by direct evidence in Court. On the other hand, a person authorized under Rule-7 of Order 39 of the Code has got no power to collect such evidence. He will go to the spot to examine the subject matter of suit or to do anything in respect of such subject matter as the Court directs him to do, and inform back to the Court.

Arif Iftekhar Ali & Ors. Alhaj Sekander Ali Howlader 10 BLT (HCD)-424. 

1351

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 [Section 1 - 114]

Citation: 13 BLT (AD)231, 14 BLT (HCD)255, 5BLT (AD)-108, 9BLT (AD)-220, 10BLT (HCD)-476, 10BLT (HCD)-347, 11 BLT (HCD)-95, 11BLT(HCD)-63, 8BLT (HCD)-364, 13 BLT (HCD)506, 14BLT(AD)216, 2BLT (HCD)-77, 11BLT (HCD)-35, 12 BLT (HCD)354, 6BLT (HCD)-33, 6BLT (HCD)

Subject: Civil Procedure

Delivery Date: 1970-01-01

 

 

 

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908

 

Section-2 read with Specific Relief Act, 1877 Section-42

It appears that the learned Subordinate Judge decreed the Suit on contest against defendant Ns.52, 56, 107 and 26 with costs and against the defendant Nos.120, 121, 127, l0-30 on contest without costs and exparte against rest declaring that the decree passed in Title Suit No.49 of 1958 (18/56) dated 6.12.1958 as fraudulent and not binding upon the plaintiffs. The appeal was dismissed but the High Court Division while maintaining the same found that as Abul Kasham Hawlader was not present in the country during the pendency of the previous suit and the Miscellaneous proceeding thereto and hence the impugned judgment and decree is not binding upon him as the same was fraudulently obtained-Held; A decree in a suit declaring that the decree is passed in Title Suit No.49 of 1958 dated 6.12.1958 is fraudulent and not binding upon the plaintiff is not a devisable one and as such aforesaid finding of the High Court Division is unwarranted because the decree against other plaintiffs that has been maintained was opposed to law.

Shamsun Nahar Begum & Org. Vs. Zohora Begum & Ors 13 BLT (AD)231

Section 2(2)

Any Order of dismissal for default shall not be Counted a decree.

Saleha Begum Vs. Artha Rin,, Adalat, Chandpur 14 BLT (HCD)255

Section-2(II) Read with Order-20 Rule-12

The present suit was not an SSC suit but regular Title suit and there is no reason why means profits cannot be allowed.

Parimal Ranjan Das Vs. Mrs. Nasima Khatoon 5BLT (AD)-108

Section 2(2) read with Non-Agricultural Tenancy Act, 1949 Section-24(1)

A referent to Section 2(2) of the Code of Civil Procedure shows that a decree may be either preliminary or final. Explanation to Section 2(2) provides that ‘a decree is preliminary when further proceedings have to be taken before the suit can be completely dispose of. It is final when such adjudication completely disposes of the suit.” In a suit for partition, after filing of the report along with the case map, field book, saham list by the Advocate Commissioner final decree takes effect and thereafter remains nothing to be done. In a pre-emption proceeding under Section 96 of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, the question of co-shareship in the tenancy is relevant, but in Section 24(1) of Non-Agricultural Tenancy Act the co-shareship in the land is material. In that view of the matter, the passing of the final decree in a partition suit finally determines the right of the co-sharers in the land. Hence, the application for the preemptor-respondents on the basis of co-sharership is not maintainable.

Md. Shafiuddin Chowdhury Vs. Md. Abdul Karim & Ors. 9BLT (AD)-220

Section-2(4)(8) read with Family Court Ordinance. 1985 Section-17(7)

Definition of the District Judge—there is no scope to accommodate the Judge of Nari-O-Shishu Nirjatan Daman Bishes Adalat as District Judge required under the Family Court Ordinance, 1985.

Karitck Chandra Dey Vs. Manju Rani Dey & Ors. 10BLT (HCD)-476

Section-9

In the instant case, it appears from the plaint itself that not shares in Albert David (Bangladesh) Ltd. has yet been transferred in favour of the plaintiff. This fact as mentioned in his own plaint shows that he has got no interest in the said company and cannot file a suit on its behalf without any specific and tangible interest in the said company.

Shafi A. Chowdhury Vs. Pubali Bank Ltd. & Ors. 10BLT (HCD)-347

Section-9

Plaintiff opposite party being an employee of petitioner Uttara Bank Limited his condition of service are controlled and regulated by Uttara Bank Employees (Service) Regulation, 1981 which came into force on 12.09.1981 and the plaintiff-opposite party was terminated by order issued by defendant no.4 on 19.09.1981 and Plaintiff-opposite party was terminated when the Service Regulation of 1981 was already in the field and Eastern banking Corporation Ltd. Staff (Service) Rules, 1965 ceased to play any role in controlling, governing and regulating the service of any employer or officer of Uttara Bank Limited and termination order issued on 19.09.1981 was under a dead (Service) Rules and dead law and that termination order is absolutely a nullity and without jurisdiction. When an order is nullity, ultravires and without jurisdiction validity of that can be very much challenged under the Ordinary Civil Jurisdiction in as much as the Civil Court or any Tribunal got the authority to see and examine whether action taken or done in any proceeding is a nullity and Quarum Non Judice.

Uttara Bank Limited Vs. Quazi Salaur Rahman & Ors. 11 BLT (HCD)-95

Section-9

The mutawalli of Waqf estate instituted the suit for declaration of the Waqf estate in the suit land.

The issues involved in such suit are whether or not the Waqf has not got title in the suit land and whether or not the record of rights in respect of the suit land as prepared and published is correct. The issues are essentially civil in nature. Under Section 9 of the Code all suits of civil nature will lie in civil courts unless the same is specially barred by specific provision of law. It is now well settled by a long line of authorities that jurisdiction of a civil court cannot readily be read to have stood ousted.

Kamrul Ahsan & Ors Vs. A. N. M. Ziauddin & Ors. 11BLT(HCD)-63

Section-9

On 22.01.1977 opposite party-plaintiff joined the defendant Bank as typist in Kishoreganj Branch, On 09.05.1981 the plaintiff was put under suspension pending decision of a police case lodged against him by the said branch of the Bank. On 18.11.1982 the plaintiff was dismissed from service under the service rules of the Bank.

Held I find from the record that after the plaintiff was put under suspension, proceeded with under the Banks Old Service Rules and finally dismissed from service on 18.11.1982 under the Bank’s Service Rule No. 39. His departmental appeal was also dismissed under Rule not 43 on 25.091984. All though he was proceeded with under the Service Rules of the Bank. This is permitted under Section-3 of the SO Act, On 18.111982 when he was dismissed for service, the defendant Bank was not brought within the ambit of the AT Act, So the plaintiff had no scope to seek remedy under the AT Act, 1981, Equally, as the plaintiff was not dismissed under any provision of the SO Act. 1965 he had also no right to go to the labour court established under the Industrial Relations Ordinance —the plaintiff opted to sue in a Civil Court and he is quite entitled to proceed with his suit in the Civil Court.

Sonali Bank & Ors. Vs. Md. Jalaluddin & Ors 8BLT (HCD)-364

Section-9

The facts which are not disputed are that deceased Rafiqul Islam insured his life for Taka 200,000.00 with the appellant company and the appellant on receipt of the first premium issued a life policy being Policy No.000021527 dated 28.12.1996. Respondent No. 1 the wife of the insured was made his nominee in the policy. On 25.03.1997 Rafiqul Islam died whereupon the respondent No.1 made the insurance claim to the appellant. On inquiry, the claim was found valid. As the insured amount was not being paid by the appellant the dispute was referred to the Controller of Insurance, respondent No. 3 purportedly under Section 47A of the Insurance Act, 1938, shortly the Act, On 28.01.1998 respondent No. 3 in presence of representatives of both the appellant and respondent No. 1 found the claim valid and asked the appellant to pay claim. Pursuant to the order of the respondent No. 3 respondent 1 started Money Execution No. 06 of 1998 for recovery of the insured amount in the above Court. Thereafter the appellant instituted the above T S No. 30/1999 in the same Court for declaration that the order of respondent No. 3 dated 28.Ol.1998 vide letter No. ll21/53/197172 asking the appellant to pay insured amount to the respondent No.1 is illegal, malafide, void and not binding upon the appellant—we do not have any doubt that in the facts and circumstances of the case, the appellant has no right to sue in a civil Court for the simple reason that an insurer does not have any such right under the law.

Homeland Life Ins. Co. Ltd. Vs. Jahanara Begum & Ors 8BLT (HCD)-361

Section-9

Law is well settled that even if jurisdiction of a Civil Court is excluded still Civil Court got jurisdiction to examine into cases where provisions of any Act, Ordinance, Regulation etc. have been complied with or not and Statutory Authority/Tribunal has not acted in conformity with provisions embodied in Statute, Ordinance and Regulation.

RAJUK & Ors Vs Habibur Rahman & Ors 13 BLT (HCD)506

Section – 9

Section 9 of the Code of Civil Procedure expressly provides that the Courts shall (subject to the provisions herein contained) have jurisdiction to try all suits of a civil nature excepting suits so which their cognizance is either expressly or impliedly barred. The nature of the dispute which was being litigating upon is entirely a civil dispute and can only be decided by competent Court of civil jurisdiction.

Mutwali Vs. Md. Mahbubey Alam & Ors 14BLT(AD)216

Section-9 read with Order-7 Rule-Il

Civil Courts can try all suits which involved the determination of any civil right— If the circumstances of the case permit, Court can grant such relief as not claimed in the plaint application for rejecting the plaint has got no merit —Rule discharged.

Zainal Abedin Vs A. K. M. Faziul Haque & Ors 2BLT (HCD)-77

Section-9 read with Administrative Tribunal Act, 1980

The Civil Court has jurisdiction to declare any legal character of a person and the same is not triable by Administrative Tribunal.

Md. Tomser Ali Sarder Vs. Md. Nazrul Islam & Ors. 11BLT (HCD)-35

Section-9 read with Acquisition and Requisition of Immovable Property Ordinance, 1982 Section-43 and 44

Jurisdiction of Civil court

In the instant suit, the plaintiff has not challenged any order passed or any action taken in the acquisition proceeding being LA Case No. 26/1998-99. The plaintiff sought a declaration that the society alone was entitled to the compensation as was already awarded. It did not even raise objection to the quantum of compensation. In the circumstances, the instant suit cannot be barred under the section.

Animal Protection Society Vs. Sree Laxman Chandra Das & Ors 12 BLT (HCD)354

Section- 10

Where a party seeks relief under section 10 C.P.C. to stop further proceedings of a subsequently instituted suit between the same parties, it lies squarely upon the applicant to show to the court that a multiplicity of action in the subsequent proceeding is vexatious and totally unwanted. One essential but of the applicability of section 10 C.P.C. is whether the decision in the earlier suit will operate as resjudicata in the subsequent suit. Even if the applicant succeeds in proving that some of the issues of the two suits are common but others are not. still then he is not entitled to get further proceedings of the subsequent suit stayed till the disposal of the previous suit.

Md. Shahabuddin Mian Vs. Agricultural Varsity 6BLT (HCD)-33

Section-10

The proceeding of any special court cannot he stayed on the ground of filing a suit under the general law even that is for the self-same matter and between the same parties. On the contrary suit filed under the general law may be stayed in appropriate circumstances.

Iftekhar Afzal Vs. Pubali Bank Ltd. & Ors. 6BLT (HCD)-166

Section- 10

Plaintiff instituted Title Suit No. 151 of 1994 for a declaration that the plaintiff is the sole owner of schedule property, subsequently the said plaintiff brought a suit being Title Suit No. 131 of 1994 for permanent injunction—defendant petitioners filed an application for stay of the subsequent suit being Title Suit No.-l31 of 1994 till disposal of the earlier Title Suit No. 151 of 1994. Learned Senior Assistant Judge rejected the application of the defendants on the ground that the two suits are not of same nature and character and the cause of action in the two suits are different—Held: I find that at least two suit plots in the above two suits are the same and in two courts proceeding are pending and to avoid conflict of judgments and to avoid possibility of multiplicity of proceeding. the subsequent suit should he stayed.

Shamsul Huq Vs. Ashkor Ali 4BLT (HCD)-9

Section- 10

Stay of subsequent suits till disposal of the previously instituted suits.

The expression ‘matter in issue” appearing in section 10 CPC has reference to the entire parties and the matters in issue in the two suits shall have to be identical. An applicant for stay of a suit under this section is bound to show that all matters in issue in the suit are directly and substantially in issue in the previously instituted suit. An applicant is not entitled to the benefit of this section where some of the issues are identical but others are different.

Abdul Jabbar Vs. Sultan Ahamed & Ors 8BLT (HCD)-55

Section-10 read with Sectioin-151

The provision of Section 10 of the Code of Civil Procedure does not apply to the simultaneous hearing of a later and earlier suit. after consolidation of the two. Its intenment is not to take away the inherent power of the court to consolidate suits and hear them simultaneously for the ends of justice.

Most. Shahida Khatun Vs. Abdul Malek Howlader & Ors. 9 BLT (AD)-148

Section-11

Barred by the Principles of Resjudicata—In the present suit the plaintiff has been litigating in respect of the same property against the same set of persons under the same title that the property is an enemy property, raising the identical objection that the agreement for sale was a false, forged and fabricated document as had been raised in the previous suit and as such, in view of the provisions of section 11 of the Code of Civil Procedure the plaintiffs suit is barred by the principle of resjudicata.

A.D.C. (Rev.) Vs. Most. Anju Bibi & Ors. 6BLT (AD)-51

Section-11

Principle of constructive res-judicata

It is clear that sale deed dated 09.11 .1989 was challenged in that Writ petition No. 798 of 1990 but no rule was issued in respect of the said sale deed and as such relief claimed by the writ petitioner-respondents in respect of the said sale deed in that writ petition was not granted by the High Court Division at the initial stage of issuing the rule and as such the relief against the said sale deed shall be deemed to have been refused for the purpose of Section 11 of the Code of Civil Procedure. So the writ petitioner-respondents cannot seek relief against the said sale deed dated 09.11.1989 by filing another Writ Petition No. 4127 of 1992. Principle of resjudicata under Section 11 of the Code is applicable in a writ proceeding as the same is also a civil proceeding. We are, therefore, of the view that relief claimed in writ Petition No. 4127 of 1992 filed by the writ petitioner-respondents against the appellants of both the appeals was baited by the principle of constructive resjudicata for implied refusal of their claim in respect of the self same sale deed dated 09.11.1989 in writ Petition No. 798 of 1990.

Govt. of Bangladesh & Ors. Vs Sri Sri Luxmi Janardhan Jew Thakur & Ors. 10BLT (AD)-16

Section-11

In order to subsequent suit within the Mischief of section 11, first and foremost requirement is that the Court in which former suit was pending and /or decided must be competent to try subsequent suit. Said Court must be of concurrent jurisdiction both in respect of pecuniary jurisdiction and subject.

Al Baraka Bank Vs. Rina Alam & Anr 12 BLT (HCD)517

Section-11

Admittedly Artha Rin Adalat Suit No. was filed for a money decree in respect of the loan amount allowed to Coast Marine Lines Ltd for a money decree of  Tk.l,33,70,592/= with interest and for realisation of the money by sale of mortgage property and the property described to the schedule in the plaint wherein respondent No.1’s property was included and it was stating in the plaint that the present plaintiff on 17.3.1988 created an equitable mortgage by depositing of title deed of her property mentioned in the schedule surety. The defendant in the said suit including the plaintiff-respondent No. 1 denying the claim of alleged mortgage, it may be mentioned here that; the bank also did not claim that on 17.3.1988 the mortgage executed a memorandum of deposit of title deed on 9.3.1989 executed another agreement for creating further charge on the deed for the loan of Coast Marine Lines Limited. Admittedly no issue on the basis of the said denial of the parties was framed regarding the disputed nature of mortgage as alleged in the said Artha Rin Adalat Suit. D.W.I Mr. Azfar Ahmed an officer of the Bank and tadbirkar has deposed in that suit that the plaintiff respondent No.1 was not a surety and that defendant No.4 did not keep the land in question as security for the loan but the instant case was a suit for the declaration, inter alia, that the plaintiffs property was not subject-matter of security in respect of the loan, the subject-matter of Artha Rin Adalat Suit No.147 of 1992.— Held; in the instant suit as we have found that no such issue was framed regarding the subject-matter of present suit and decision was arrived at and the issue of the present suit was not directly or substantially an issue in the previous suit so as to render the present suit barred by the principle of resjudicata. The High Court Division was not also unmindful as to the question of res judicata to operate as a bar in the instant suit and the trial Court as well on consideration of the material on record arrived at a finding that the suit is not barred by res-judicata.

The Oriental Bank Ltd. Vs. Mrs. Rina Alain and Anr. 13 BLT (AD)116

Section -11

When an issue is raised and decided by the trial Court but in appeal neither affirmed nor reversed, that cannot be said to be finally decided and the decision of the trial Court therefore would not act as res judicata.

Eastern Bank & Anr. Vs Sufia Re-Rolling Mills & Ors. 13 BLT (HCD)221

Section-21

No objection as to the jurisdiction shall be allowed unless such objection was taken at earliest possible opportunity. But it is by now well settled that consent or waiver cannot give jurisdiction where there is inherent lack or absence of it and in that the order is a nullity.

Supreme Court of Bangladesh Vs. Md. Shafiuddin. 10BLT (AD)-50

Section – 21

The policy of the legislature has been to treat objections as to jurisdiction both territorial or pecuniary as purely technical for the reason that section 21 of the Code of Civil Procedure provides that no objection as to the place of suing shall be allowed unless such objection was taken at the earliest stage but objection not having been taken would not vitiate the trial. Similarly objection as to pecuniary jurisdiction which is for the purpose of Court fee and availing a forum of appeal / revision is mostly of formal nature and the Court with higher pecuniary jurisdiction could decide a suit of lower pecuniary value and would not render the decree void. It is also desirable that the grievance of the plaintiff would be resolved in a single suit.

Md. Shamsul Haque Vs. Md. Salimullah & Ors 14 BLT (AD)07

Section-24

Five suits are pending in three different courts according to their respective valuation since the parties are litigating claiming title to the same property by filing several suits, justice demands that all the suits should be tried analogously by one court.

Md. Nur Hossain Vs. Mst Bibi Halima & Ors. 5BLT (HCD)-35

Section —24

It appears from the order sheet that as per the order No. 68 A dated 14.10.2004 of the learned Joint District Judge the suit being No. 03 of 2004 was transferred to the court of first Joint District Judge previously. The suit was at argument stage. The learned Joint District Judge asked staff to inform the matter to the parties concerned and also fixed the case on 28.11.2004 for hearing argument. The plaintiff prayed for time on 24.11.2004 and the court allowed the same fixing 28.11 .2004 for hearing argument. The plaintiff, Janata Bank, being aggrieved by the order dated 28.11 .2004 presumed that he will not get fair justice from that court.— Held the apprehension must appear to the court to be reasonable, genuine and justifiable. Power of transfer of a case cannot be exercised on hypersensitive or trivial grounds or mini grievances.

Nurul Haque Sarker Vs. Janata Bank & Ors 14 BLT (HCD)472

Section-24 read with Order-47 Rule-1

(a)Section 24—An application for transfer of a case or suit from a Subordinate Judge Court to the High Court Division to any other Court is to be heard by a Division Bench and not by a Single Judge.

Abdur Rashid Khan & Ors Vs A. Hye & Ors. 2BLT (HCD)211

(b) Order-47 Rule-1—An application for transfer is to be heard after issuance of notice when such application is filed before a court. In civil order no such notice was issued which the learned Judge transgress the limits of his jurisdiction in making direction to transfer the case that a direction to dispose of the same within specified period of time. — Section 24 C.P.C. does not refer to a judge but to the Court, application for review is competent.

Abdur Rashid Khan & Ors. Vs. A. Hye & Ors. 2 BLT (HCD)-211

Section-30

Mandatory requirement—On a perusal of the impugned order it appears that the court had overlooked the provision of Section 30 of the Code of Civil Procedure. The learned Assistant Judge, Kachua is directed to comply with section 30 of the Code of Civil Procedure and then proceed with the suit.

Md. Abdur Rahim Khondaker Vs. Bachu Mia & Ors. 10BLT (HCD)-245

Section-34

Whether the court can award an interest or compensation in a money suit for the period prior to the institution of the suit for loss of business for nonpayment of the balance of the price of goods supplied by the plaintiff to the defendant

When the court pass a money decree, it may order interest to be paid on the principal sum adjudged from the date of the suit to the date of the decree in addition to any interest adjudged on such principal sum for any period to the institution of the suit, with further interest on the aggregate sum so adjudged from the date of the decree to the date of payment. More simplified, the court has power to award interest for three distinct periods (1) the period from the date a sum is payable to the date of institution of the suit, (2) the period during which the suit remains pending and (3) the period from the date of decree till payment of the decretal amount.

Sonali Bank Vs. M/S. Karnaphuli Works Ltd. 2BLT (AD)-78

The Court can allow interest for a pre-suit period if the principal sum is fixed and payable at a definite time and such conditions are provided for in any agreement between the parties or in any substantive law.

Sonali Bank Vs. M/S. Karnaphuli Works Ltd. 2BLT (AD)-78

Section-34

No party has any right to pray for a decree on any interest as a principal sum.

BWDB Vs. Contractor Manu Barrage 9BLT (HCD)-21

Section —34

Exercise of discretion

The definite case of the defendant-respondent is that the plaintiff appellant sanctioned insufficient loan and that the loan was not sanctioned in time for which he could not start his Mills in due course thereby he incurred heavy loss in his business. In addition to the flood and cyclone have caused serious damage in his business and thus ruined his financial capability to repay loan with interest.-Having considered the facts and circumstances evidence on record of the present appeal, we think, it would be equitable and proper exercise of discretion under section 34 of the Code of Civil Procedure to modify the impugned judgment and decree deducting interest of Taka. 6,00,025.85 from the total interest of Taka. 12,18,025.85 and the awarding interest stands at 6,18,000.00 and if this amount is added with the principal loan amount of Taka. 8,82,000.00 which stands at Taka 15,00,000.00 and the plaintiff-appellant is entitled to Taka. 15,00,000.00 (fifteen lac) as principal and interest from the defendant respondent as on 30.07.1990 with 10% interest per annum till realization from the date (i.e. 30.07.1990).

Sonali Bank Vs Md. Mokshed Ali Khan 13 BLT (HCD)331

Section-34 (2) (4)

In the instant case the court as well as the appellate court assailant about interest of the amount claimed by the petitioner. So, where the decree doesn’t provide for interest it will be deemed to have been refused provided that which is not done inadvertently or due to mistake. When interest is not awarded on the decree it cannot he executed.

Bangladesh House Building Finance Corporation Vs. Most Amena Khatun & Anr. 4BLT (HCD)-167

Sectioin-44A Clause-B, Explanation-3

If statutory enactments are clear in meaning, they must be construed according to their meaning even though they are contrary to international Law. We have, therefore, no hesitation in coming to the conclusion that a foreign arbitration award even if such award is enforceable as a decree or judgment of the United Kingdom cannot executed in Bangladesh in view of clause (b). explanation-3 of Section 44A of the Code of Civil Procedure even if Bangladesh is a signatory of the New York Convention 1958 on the recognition and enforcement of foreign arbitral award.

Aminur Rahman Khan, Vs. Trade Aris Insurance 9BLT (HCD)-206

Section-47

Stay of Execution

Admitted position is that in pursuance to the decree passed in Title Suit No. 68 of 1990 which was a suit for specific performance of contract, the plaintiff got the kabala executed and registered through Court and it appears that possession was also obtained in most of the suit land excepting of course a very small fraction of the land which is in possession of some unauthorised persons. The High Court Division found that since the decree has already been executed in Execution Case No. 18 of 1994 and the kabala has been registered on 20.10.1994 there is nothing to stay all further proceedings of the aforesaid execution case. The petitioner filed Title Suit No. 244 of 1994 for a declaration that the exparte decree passed in Title Suit No. 68 of 1990 was illegal and void which has nothing to do with the aforesaid execution proceeding and when the decree obtained by respondent No. I has already been executed, we are of the view that the High Court Division has not committed any wrong or illegality in refusing to stay further proceedings of aforesaid Execution Case No. 18of 1994.

Tapan Kumer Basak Vs. Gouranga Ch. De Tarafdar & Ors. 7BLT (AD)-310

Section-48

The decree-holder obtained the decree on 12-8-59 and the decree-holder’s son filed the latest Execution case more than 18 years after the decree was obtained — Held : The latest Execution Case No. 5 of 1977 filed on 26-8-77 is barred by section 48 of the Code of Civil Procedure and that the High Court Division erred in law in holding that section 48 C.P.C. has no manner of application in this case.

A. D. C. Pabna Vs. Md. Abdul Halim Mia 4BLT (AD)-90

 

 

Section-48 read with Limitation Act, 1908 [IX of 1908]

Article- 182

Under Section-48 of the code of Civil Procedure fresh application of 12 years from the date of decree sought to be executed has been barred. Under Article 182 of the Limitation Act time for execution of a decree is three years from the date of the decree or order, or the date of final decree or order of the appellate court. In view of the provisions, an execution to be validly proceed with must satisfy that the application last in point of time for execution was not made after the expiration of the period of 12 years and also not beyond three years from the date of decree or order, or appellate decree or order.

Shafiqur Rahman Vs. Bangladesh Jatiya Samabaya Bank 9BLT(HCD)-72

Section 48 read with Limitation Act, 1908

Article- 182

In the Instant Case the respondent No.2 Bank attained the decree on 15-08-1987 made by the trial court, Against the said decree the decree holder Bank filed First Appeal No. 19 of 1987 which was dismissed for default order dated 24-05-1990 noted on 7-7-1990 and as such the decree passed by the trial court dated 15-08-1987 remain as decree under section 2(2) of the civil procedure code under article 182 of the limitation Act the period of limitation for 3 years from the date of decree dated 15-08- 1987 passed by the Artha Rin Adalat. The decree holder Bank put the decree dated 15- 08-1987 in execution on 1-04-1999 beyond the period of limitation. Since the execution case has been filed beyond the period of limitation, the decree is not executable as the execution, case was initialed as per the prevision of the code of civil procedure the executing court (Artha Adalat) had no jurisdiction to execute the decree.

Saleha Begum Vs. Artha Rin Adalat, Chandpur 14 BLT (HCD)255

Section - 60

Order for attachment of movables property of the Deputy Commissioner and sale in execution of decree.

For satisfaction of the decree, law does not put any limitation to the attachment of movables and immovable of a judgment- debtor only subject to what is provided by section 60 of the Code of Civil Procedure. After attachment it is in the discretion of the executing court to order for sale of so much of the attached property as would satisfy the claim of the decree. Prime focus expected of the execution Court is to promptly recover the decreed amount, particularly, the compensation on account of acquisition of valuable property of a citizen.

Asmatunnessa Khatun Vs. Bangladesh 14 BLT (HCD)319

Section - 60

Attachment of movable properties of the Deputy Commissioner.

Since the Deputy Commissioner, Dhaka was delaying to make payment of the award money to the decree-holder on the ground that the requiring body did not place the necessary found, the decree-holder petitioner filed an application before the Executing court for attachment of the moveable property of the Deputy Commissioner, Dhaka on 23.1.2003. The learned Joint District Judge noticed that several adjournments were granted to the judgment-debtor Deputy Commissioner- prayer was rejected by the executing Court- Held; The convenience and inconvenience of the Deputy Commissioner, should not be a ground to refuse the prayer for attachment.

Asmatunnessa Khatun Vs. Bangladesh 14 BLT (HCD)321

Section - 66 (1)

Interpretation of section 66(1) — When a suit is instituted by the real owner claiming his title against the benamder and the benamder comes forward and resist the claim of the real owner, the matter ends there and the Suit is hit by section 66(1) of the Code. But where the real owner instituted a suit against the benamder claiming that benamder is not the real owner simply benamder and if the benamder or any one claiming under him does not come forward to contest the claim of the plaintiff in that case, section 66(1) of the said Code will have no manner of application and the suit would not be barred under the said Provisions of the Code in the present case, since the benamder or his heirs did not contest the suit, the suit is not hit by section 66(1) of the Code of Civil Procedure.

Sananda Mohan Barua & Ors. Vs. Niranjan Proshad Barua & Ors. 4BLT (HCD)-187

Section-66( 1)

The said provision applies where the plaintiff tries to enforce his secret title as against the certificated purchaser. It has no application when the benamdar himself or his successor does not lay any claim under the sale certificate.

Sananda Barua & Anr. Vs. Pramatosh Barua & Ors. 9BLT (AD)-269

Section-75 & 77 read with Order-26 Ruel-5

Letter of request— plaintiff is an Indian national and a resident of Delhi.

The evidence of the plaintiff was not completed. In the past, when the plaintiff deposed and adduced some documents, the defendants does not cross-examine him. So the necessary of further examination of the plaintiff is more pressing for the defendants than for himself — Held: In the facts and circumstances of the case, we are of the view that letter of request to our High Commissioner in Delhi would be the most convenient and effective mode to record the deposition of the plaintiff in Delhi, who will not encounter the difficulties that a Commissioner may face with. Two Advocates on behalf of aforesaid defendants may also go to Delhi and the plaintiff will bear the costs of the Advocates for their travel to Delhi by surface, food and accommodation.

Abdul Latif Vs. Jahanara Begum & Ors. 11 BLT (HCD)-54

Section-91(2)

The primary allegation is in fact one, which affects the plaintiff and this unlawful action of the defendant causes private nuisance to the plaintiff. Sub-section (2) of section 91 of the Code can be invoked in the case of private nuisance.

Wahid Mia Vs. Dr. Rafiqul Islam & Ors 7BLT (AD)-26

Section 96(3) read with Order-20 Rule-4(2)

The opposite parties 1-4 as plaintiffs filed the suit for specific performance of contract—the evidence was closed of both the parties the date of arguments, a compromise  petition was filed by defendants No. 1 and 2 and the plaintiff No. 1 on behalf of the plaintiffs No. 2-4—the pleadings of the suit was proved by plaintiff No. 2 for all the plaintiffs as P.W.1— In such circumstances no actual authority was given to the plaintiff

 

 

No.1 by the plaintiffs No.2-4 and also to the lawyer to prefer this compromise  petition before the trial court —the order passed by the learned Munsif was not proper and accordingly to law on such compromise  petition —appellate Court was justified in sending the case on remand for arguments and deliver judgment and pass decree on merit.

Md. Joinal Abedin Vs. Jugal Ranjan Sukal & Ors. 2BLT (HCD)-97

Section-100

Section-100 of the Code of Civil Procedure does not authorise the High Court Division to disturb the finding the fact of the Court of appeal below, the final Court of fact arrived at on appreciation of the evidence even though, the High Court Division do not agree with the finding arrived at by the Court of appeal below on consideration of the evidence on record.

Hriday Chandra Day & Anr. Vs. Probat Dey & Ors. 10BLT (AD)-137

Section -100

In case of ignoring of material evidence or in case of arriving at a decision upon ignoring material evidence and the finding arrived at is vitiated by error of law or finding of fact not based on evidence, or there was no proper legal evidence in support of the finding or important evidence ignored by the lower appellate Court the High Court Division is quite within its jurisdiction to interfere with the finding and the decision of the lower appellate Court.

Rabeya Khatun. Vs Keramat Ali Behara. 13 BLT (AD) 39

Section—100

Second appeal —Suit for declaration of title, confirmation of Possession and recovery of khas possession—Trial court decreed the suit and the appellate court affirming the judgment and decree passed by the trial court—High Court Division setting aside the concurrent findings of the courts below — Held: In our view, the High Court Division exceeded its jurisdiction as provided under section 100 of the Code of Civil Procedure in setting aside the concurrent findings of the trial court and the appellate court without adverting to the finding given by those courts and without and any findings that those findings of the trial court the appellate Court were perverse or unreasonable or without any evidence and basis.

Md. Mojibur Rahman Howlader & Ors Vs. Afsar Ali Howlader 15 BLT (AD)98

Section- 103

Whether the High Court Division was justified in reassessing the evidence as to the late of demand for reconveyance within Magh. 1365 B. S. and coming to the findings that the demand was not made within that period and that the suit was barred by limitation.

Held: We have no hesitation to hold that the learned Single Judge of the High Court Division was perfectly justified in exercising his power under section 103 and give his decision as to the tender of the consideration and demand of reconveyance particularly when, as it appears from the judgment of the High Court Division, the learned Judge was loathe to send back the case on remand to consider this point as was prayed by the learned Counsels, more than 20 years having then elapsed since the institution of the suit.

Ali Ahmed and Ors Vs. Nazimuddin Patwary 5BLT (AD)-84

Section- 107

It is seen from the judgment of the High Court Division that the said Division was of the view that the parties to the suit having had not taken objection to the report filed by the Advocate Commissioner it can be said that the said report has been accepted by the Court. The observation so made by the High Court Division is not legally sound since in the absence of examination of the Advocate Commissioner as regard his report the same cannot be considered as evidence in the case. —The appeal should be disposed of by the appellate Court in the light of the provision of section 107 of the Code of Civil Procedure i.e. directing the party at whose instance the Advocate Commissioners report was obtained to make the Advocate Commissioner available for recording his deposition and if the party fails in that case to dispose of the appeal in the light of the materials already on record.

Fate Ali Vs. Joygun Nessa & Ors 15 BLT (AD)361

Section- 107 read with Section-115

The High Court Division directing the Court of Appeal to take additional evidence and get the disputed L. T. I. examined by expert without setting aside the judgment of the Appellate Court and without sending back the appeal on remand-The power of appellate court can be exercised by the revisional court in appropriate cases and in our view, the present case is one of such nature.

Meher Banu & Ors. Vs. A. Barek & Muslin, Bepari 13 BLT (AD)177

Section- 109

Section 109 (a) of the Code of Civil Procedure was amended in our country in 1961 with effect from 23.3.1956 and in India in 1950 and 1961 thereby including the word “Judgment” together with the existing words “decree or final order”

Syed Rashid Ahmed Vs Idrish Ullah and Ors. 14BLT(HCD)147

Section-114 and Order-47

Neither non-consideration of material evidence nor prolongation of litigation is a ground for review —non-consideration of material evidence, Ext.7 (the report of the advocate Commissioner) is a ground for appeal not a ground for review.

Mullan Bibi Vs Nurul Islam & others 2BLT (HCD)-38

Section 114 and order 47 C.P.C.

Review—the power of review as visualized in section 114 C.P.C. is to be traced to Order 47(1) of the Code, which contains the prescribed conditions and limitations set by law. A review is never permissible unless the case falls within the purview of the powers contained in Order 47(1) C.P.C. A review I never contemplated to be rehearing of a case for re-opening a closed chapter. It is available only under certained well defined circumstances, namely, where some important evidence has been discovered which could not, in spite of due diligence, have been known to the party to be produced at the time of hearing or the court has overlooked some important question of fact and law, which would have a direct bearing on the decision of the case or there is otherwise some apparent Mistake or error on the face of the record. The ground that the court has fallen into error in deciding an important question or that an important ground was not urged at the original hearing cannot be the ground for review. The finality or sanctity that attaches to a judgment or order passed by a competent court on hearing the contending parties cannot be lightly interfered with in review.

Sree Parimal Chandra & Ors. Vs. Most. Shaheda Begum & Ors 8BLT (HCD)-90

 

Section-114, Clauses (a) and (b) Read with Order-47 Rule-1

Review from a decree or order of a Court of Small Cause will be maintainable not under clause (c) but under clauses (a) and (b) of section 114 read with Order 47, Rule-I CPC.

Gajendra Nath Mondal & Ors. Vs. Motia. Begum & Ors. 7BLT (AD)-280

Section- 114 read with Order 47 Rule-1

Review is not a rehearing of a case. Review is not an appeal, or, to put it differently, Review is by no means an appeal in disguise whereby an erroneous decision stands corrected. Not mere error of fact and law, but error apparent on the face of the record is a ground for Review. Review lies only on a patent error. There is real distinction between a mere erroneous decision and an error apparent on the face of the record. Error apparent on the face of record is an error which can be seen by mere perusal of record without reference to an’ other matter and to find out such error one has not to scrutinize the evidence or record but it should be self-evident from a perusal of the record itself and can be pinpointed without elaborate examination.

Farmisi Khatun Vs. M. Yasin Degree College & Ors 16 BLT (HCD) 231.

1352

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 [Section 115 - 150]

Citation: 2BLT (AD)-127, 4BLT (AD)-166, 4 BLT (HCD)-80, 4BLT (HCD)-113, 5BLT (AD)-94, 5BLT (AD)-219, 6BLT (AD)-83, 7BLT (AD)-289,7BLT (AD)-19, 7BLT (AD)-5, 7BLT(AD)-147, 7BLT (AD)-33, 7BLT (HCD)-237, 7 BLT (HCD)-24), 8 BLT(HCD)-70, 8BLT(HCD)-136, 8BLT (HCD)-30

Subject: Civil Procedure

Delivery Date: 1970-01-01

 

 

 

 

 

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908

Section- 115 read with Artha Rin Adalat Ain

Revision is impliedly barred because the Artha Rin Adalat Act being a special legislation setting up a special court, the remedies will follow as provided therein.

Sultana Jute Mills Ltd. Vs. Agrani Bank & Ors. 2BLT (AD)-127

Section-115

Period of limitation—Section 115 C.P.C. is an empowering provision granting discretionary jurisdiction to the High Court Division to correct any error of law committed by any subordinate Court resulting in an error in the decision occasioning failure of justice. In appropriate cases High Court Division may suo-motu exercise such jurisdiction to rectify failure of justice. But as a matter of long standing practice one has to exercise vigilance and promptness in invoking the revisional jurisdiction at the earliest opportunity without causing any inordinate delay. Preferably within 90 days from the decree or order complained against as has been prescribed for preferring an appeal to the High Court Division from any decree or order of a court subordinate to it — relied on 39 DLR (AD) 205.

A.D.C. (Rev) Vs. Md, Abdul Majid & Ors. 4BLT (AD)-166

Section-115

Whether the order passed by the learned Artha Rin Adalat is subject to appeal or amenable to writ jurisdiction or from such order a revision lies under Section 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure

As Proviso the Section 7(1) of the Artha Rin Adalat Act, 1990 speaks relating to interim order, the order impugned is amenable to writ jurisdiction as contended by the petitioners Counsel.

Held: The Artha Rin Adalat is a civil Court and is subordinate to the High Court Division. That being the legal position we do not find that the petitioner cannot seek relief under section 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure against the impugned order, in as much as. Section 115 uses the expression “Where no appeal lies” Section 115 applies. Therefore on this Count we are not inclined to invoke our jurisdiction under Article 102 of our Constitution.

Serajuddin Hawlader Vs. Pubali Bank 4 BLT (HCD)-80

Section- 115

Whether an order passed by the Artha Rin Adalat (a court of special jurisdiction) is revisable by the High Court u/s 115 C.P.C.

Held : Artha Rin Adalat, though a special court, is nevertheless a court, subordinate to the High Court Division and is, therefore, amenable to the revisional jurisdiction of the High Court Division.

Sonali Bank Vs. M/S Alt Tannery Ltd & Ors. 4BLT (HCD)-113

Section-115

The first two courts below concurrently found that the plaintiff had no possession in the suit lands and that without a prayer for recovery of khas possession the suit as framed was not maintainable but the learned Judge of the High Court Division did not reverse the said findings and thus committed an error of law in passing his judgment as contended by the learned counsel for the appellants.

Held: We are of the opinion that the learned Single Judge of the High Court Division acted beyond his jurisdiction under section 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure in setting aside the concurrent findings of facts and sending back the case on remand to the trial Court.

Rupe Jahan Begum & Ors. Vs. Lutfer Ali Chowdhury & Ors. 5BLT (AD)-94

Section- 115

Whether the High Court Division exceeded its revisional jurisdiction in setting aside the concurrent findings of fact.

It appears from the impugned judgment that although the learned Judges have stated that the Courts below based their judgments upon Misreading and non-consideration of the evidence, yet they failed to lay their hands on any part of the evidence of P.Ws and D.Ws or on any documentary evidence to bring home this error of law on the part of the courts below. Without reversing the findings of the courts below on the grounds mentioned in Section 115 C.P.C the High Court Division has no jurisdiction to disturb the final findings of facts. It cannot superimpose itself as a third court for fresh appreciation of evidence. That is not its function in the revisional jurisdiction.

Md. Shah Alain Vs. Most. Farida Begum 5BLT (AD)-219

Section- 115

The exercise of the revisional power under section 115 of the Civil Procedure Code is a discretionary one. Ordinarily it is not be exercised where there is an alternative remedy open to a party.

Mrs. Renu Begum & Anr. Vs. Kazi Liakat Ali & Ors. 6BLT (AD)-83

Section-115

Recommending amendment in the Muslim Family Laws Ordinance, 1961 (Ordinance No. VIII of 1961) Prohibiting Polygamy

Suit for prompt dower and maintenance—It was totally unnecessary for the learned Judges to indulge in the discussion on polygamy in Islam which was neither an issue in the suit nor required to be decided in the context of the pleadings of the parties. The exercise undertaken by the learned Judges was not only gratuitous but wholly illegal being not within their jurisdiction under the Code of Civil Procedure —In the circumstances of the case, we feel compelled to observe that the discussion on polygamy in Islam and recommendation thereon as recorded in the impugned judgment should be taken to be deleted lest it may create confusion in the mind of the Subordinate Courts and the people at large.

Md. Elias Vs. Jesmin Sultana  7BLT (AD)-289

Section-115

It appears that the trial court on consideration of the oral evidence on record, the content of Ext. ‘C’ and other documents held that on the refusal to receive the summons of the said suit by said Wazed Ali Fakir, the same was served by hanging and in accordance with law in presence of mokabela witnesses namely, D.Ws. 4 and 5, but the lower appellate court without considering the evidence of those mokabela witnesses wrongly held that the summons were not properly served upon defendant No. 1 of that suit The learned Judge of the High Court Division having, thus, found fault with the appellate court’s judgment, in our opinion, rightly set aside the judgment and decree of the lower appellate court in exercise of his revisional authority. [Para-6]

Lokman Fakir & Ors. Vs. Abdul Jabber Bayati & Ors. 7BLT (AD)-19

Section-115

The Trial Judges ordered the return of the plaint to the plaintiffs advocate—Field : The Trial Court acted without jurisdiction in ordering return of the plaint and therefore the revisional jurisdiction was rightly attracted.

Shahajadpur Central Co-operative Bank Ltd. Vs Md. Majibur Rahman & Ors. 7BLT (AD)-5

Section-115

Misscarriage of Justice—Sufficient cause having been found by the trial court the learned Single Judge acted wrongly in exercise of his revisional jurisdiction in interfering with a determination of fact. In revision such an interference has in fact caused Miscarriage of justice.

Arosh Ali Vs. Shah Taslimuddin Qurashi & Ors. 7BLT(AD)-147

Section -115

Per Mustafa Kamal, J: There was no prayer for amendment of the plaint, not even before the Appellate Division. If in revisional jurisdiction the High Court Division rides roughshod over both substantive and procedural law then a litigant does not know what will happen to his case, what course will it take and what relief will ultimately emerge. This is a travesty of justice, as we know it. The suo motu exercise in the manner it was done, besides being without jurisdiction was an act of extreme judicial indiscretion.

Per Bimalendu Bikash Roy Choudhury, J: Plaintiff No.1 Shamsun Nahar Begum never appealed against the decree of the original court nor did she take any appeal therefrom. She did not also prefer any revision. In such circumstances the learned Judges of the High Court Division had no jurisdiction to give her any further relief beyond what was granted by the first two courts below.

Md. Hefzur Rahman Vs Shamsun Nahar Begum & Anr. 7BLT (AD)-33

Section-115

Revisional authority under section 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure will not interfere with the exercise of discretion of the courts below except where the discretion has been shown to have been exercised arbitrarily or capriciously or perversely or where the courts ignored the settled principles of law regulating grant or refusal of interlocutory injunction. Applying the above rule indicating the scope of interference in revision against the exercise of discretion of the courts below to grant the interlocutory injunction.

Lakshmi Bazar Shahi Masjid Committee & Anr, Vs. St. Francis Xavier Girls High School 7BLT (HCD)-237

Section-115

Maintainability—order of a Family Court— against the order of a Family Court either final or interlocutory and both are appealable under section 17 of the Family Court Ordinance, 1985—instead of presenting an appeal before the learned District Judge, look a revision petition under section 115 of the Code which is not at all maintainable.

M., Atiqur Rahaman Vs. Ainunnahar 7 BLT (HCD)-24)

Section-115

The revision application under section 115 of the Code is not maintainable against the award of the Arbitrator.

Ali Hossin Vs. Arbitrator 8 BLT(HCD)-70

Section-115

Maintainability—On a mere perusal of the order under challenge dated 30.11.1999 it appears that the learned Assistant Judge did not determine and decide the petition for adinterim injunction laid under Section- 151 of the Code but merely granted adjournment on allowing the petition presented by the defendant opposite-party and fixed 02.01.2000 for hearing of the injunction matter. It thus, cannot be said that matter was decided by the learned Assistant Judge by a decision and the said order cannot be a at all characterized to be a decision. I am of this considered view that the order under challenge having not a case decide and not a decision, the Civil Revision Petition against the said order is not maintainable.

Sirajul Islam Chowdhury Trawlers Ltd. Vs. Sirajul Islam Chowdhury 8BLT(HCD)-136

Section-115

The power to be exercised under section 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure is supervisory which may be also exercised suo motu, The High Court Division is clothed with supplementary power and superintendence and control over the judgment and Orders and action over the Courts subordinate to the High Court Division and the power of Revision is intended to be exercised with a view to subserve not to defeat the ends of justice.

Abu Mohammad Yousuf & Ors. Vs. Mrs. Basirannessa & Ors 8BLT (HCD)-307

Section-115

In exercising revisional jurisdiction under Section- 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure this Court can interfere with the finding of fact only when it can be shown that the finding is based on cross Misreading of evidence or it has been founded on a Misconception or Misapplication of law or Misinterpretation of any material document or otherwise it is perverse being contrary to law and evidence brought on record—it is also to be borne in mind that mere erroneous decision is not a ground for interference in the exercise of revisional power under section 115 of the Code. Interference may be called for if the judgment appears to have suffered from a patent illegality, legal infirmity and flagrant error of law occasioning a failure of justice.

Mrs. Razia Kader Vs. Mrs. Nurun Nahar Begum 8BLT(HCD)-343

Section- 115

Ground on surmise—we find absolutely no pleading-opposite party No.1 in his objection did not raise of any question at all as to the parentage of the minor. In her examination chief, she has testified that the minor son was born out of the wedlock. During cross examination, may be in reply to the suggestion of development of bad relations among the spouses leading to the divorce, she stated that her husband used to torture her over the birth of the son and that her husband doubted over the parentage of the son. In the absence of any pleading and without understanding the disastrous implication or consequence of his reasoning learned Additional District Judge most illegally based his finding upon such statements made in cross-examination as a reason for the deceased Shahabuddin Ahmed Khan for declaring opposite party No. 1 as the next of kin. This way of reasoning cannot be approved nor the reason, which is wholly bases on surmise.

Secondly, when the learned Additional District Judge himself found that even the appointment of the next of kin would not exempt the requirement of taking a succession certificate for withdrawing the money left by the deceased, how could he on the next breath find the opposite party No. 1 only entitled to the estate of the deceased. Learned Subordinate Judge found that the son is the only heir left by the deceased Shahabuddin Ahmed Khan and he will inherit the estate of his father. Without reversing such finding, the learned Additional District Judge fell in serious error to find opposite party No. 1 only beneficiary and entitled to the estate of the deceased. We find no reason to disturb such finding of the learned Subordinate Judge.

Muhaiminual Hassan Khan Vs. Md. Nurul Islam Khan & Ors. 10BLT (HCD)-139

Section-115

It is fact that the opposite party lady has not preferred the revisional application against the decree for restitution of conjugal rights but it has come to the notice of this court that in spite of the decree passed by the appellate court the petitioner; husband did not make any endeavor to bring back the lady to his domain which shows, the conduct of the petitioner that he is an unbecoming a person and disrespectful towards the mandate of the court and in view of the provisions under Section 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure, this Court is also of the opinion that whenever any error committed by subordinate to High Court Division in which no appeal lies thereto can rectify the error of law and even sou-motu.

Husband Vs. Wife. 10BLT (HCD)-144

Section-115

In exercising Civil Revisional Jurisdiction under Section 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure can interfere with the decision of an appellate Court which is the last and the final court of fact if is shown that the finding is based on gross Misreading of evidence or non consideration of material evidence or it has been founded on Misconception or Misapplication of law or Misinterpretation of any material documents or otherwise it is perverse being contrary to law, evidence and material on record.

Mohammad Siddiqur Rahman Vs. BWDB & Ors. 10BLT (HCD)-408

Section-115

Though the judgments passed by the courts below suffer from irregularity but the courts below committed no illegality or error of law resulting in an error in the decision occasioning failure of justice in arriving at a final decision and as such no interference is called for by this court upon the impugned judgment and decree.

Md. Sadek Uddin Chowdhury & Ors. Vs. Md. Anowarul Haque Chowdhury & Anr. 11BLT (HCD)-72

Section-115

The finding of the trial court are based on the materials on record that there was no service of summons upon Ful Meher Bibi, defendant No. 8 of the original suit. Therefore, it was no function of the High Court Division to sit in appeal over that findings of the trial court in revisional jurisdiction.

Ful Meher Bibi being dead her heirs Savura Khatun & Ors. Vs. Abdul Wahab & Ors.13 BLT (AD)180

Section-115

As the orders passed by an Assistant Judge in suits valued at Taka 1,00,000.00 only in rejecting applications for temporary injunction and vacating its earlier orders of status quo were not appealable before this Division , revision applications under section 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure made against such orders cannot be said to be not maintainable.

Standard Bank Limited Vs. Tripos Engineering & Ors. 13 BLT (HCD)15

Section- 115

The High Court Division without perusing the original dakhilas was not justified in disturbing the findings of fact arrived at by the court of appeal which is the last court of fact regarding the genuineness of dakhilas and possession of the defendants on the basis of these dakhilas and other documents.

Md. Biseruddin Sardar & Ors Vs. Md. Tofazzal Hossain Biswas & Ors. 15 BLT (AD)47

Section-115

Decisions of facts reached by Appellate Judge as last and final Judge of fact based on evidence and materials on record are not open to interference by High Court Division in exercise of revisional jurisdiction contemplated in section 115 of the Code unless it is shown that decision are based upon gross Misreading of evidence those has been founded on Misconception or Misapplication or Misapprehension of law or any Misinterpretation of any material document or otherwise those are perverse being contrary to law, evidences and materials on record.

Selim Saial Vs. A. Majid Molla & Ors 15 BLT (HCD)69

Section-115

We are of the view that the lower Appellate Court was fully competent to decide the case by itself as the evidence and other materials on record were sufficient to enable it to come to a final decision without entailing the parties unnecessary trouble and expenses and the appellate court shirked its responsibility and thus committed an error of law resulting in an error in the decision occasioning failure of justice in remanding the suit to the trial Court for fresh trial.

Abdul Quiyum Jalali Ponkhi Vs. Md. Lukman & Ors 15 BLT (HCD)122

Section —115

Learned Trial Judge failed to take into stock relevant provision of law in respect of vesting a property as Enemy Property and he totally Misdirected himself in his approach in resolving the war of words and committed a substantial error in arriving at a finding, that original owners left this country in 1964 and in their absence Plaintiff belonging to the same community adopted various devices to grab suit property which was purely an Enemy Property. Appellate Judge as last Judge of fact was duty bound to come to a finding on discussion on materials on record, whether the predecessor grand-father Krishna Chandra Basak and father Kala Chand Basak were Enemies and whether the property could be brought under the Mischief of Enemy Property laws and whether treating of property as Enemy Property suffered from illegality but Appellate Judge did not at all touch the vital issue involved in the case and, thus, committed a grave error Of law by which a failure Of Justice has been occasioned.

Sree Narayan Chandra Basak & Ors Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh & Ors 15 BLT (HCD)506

Section – 115

Expartee Decree—It is seen from the order of the learned Subordinate Judge that the defendant-petitioners in support of their case for setting aside the ex-parte decree totally failed to establish the summons was not served on the defendants or the defendants were prevented by sufficient cause from appearing before the Court when the case was taken up for hearing. In that state of the matter the learned Subordinate Judge was totally in error in setting aside the ex-parte decree and consequently the High Court Division has not committed any error or illegality in setting aside the erroneous order of the court below.

Govt: of Bangladesh Vs. Sunil Kumar Khan 15BLT(AD)142

Section- 115

Suit is for mere declaration of title

Held; On perusal of the judgment of the lower appellate Court we find that the said Court upon detailed discussions of the case of the parties and the evidence brought on record by the parties in support of their respective case disposed of the appeal upon reversing the judgment and decree of the trial Court by which plaintiff’s suit was decreed. It is seen from the judgment of the High Court Division that the said Division considered the materials on record and thereupon arrived at the finding that no material was brought on record to establish that interest of the C.S. recorded tenant whose heirs are the defendant Nos.l and 2 was extinguished in any manner either by auction purchase by the manager of the landlord or in the manner as claimed by the plaintiffs. It may be mentioned the suit was filed seeking declaration of title claiming possession in the land in suit. The last Court of fact on detailed discussions of the evidence, both oral as well as documentary, arrived at the finding that the plaintiffs failed to prove their possession in the land in suit. —In the afore state of the matter we do not find any ground to interfere with the judgment of the High Court Division.

Mongal Sarder & Ors Vs. Md. Azahar Ali Pk & Ors 15BLT(AD)383

Section-115

Non-impleading of holders of contiguous land to the land transferred strikes at the root of Pre-emption case and non-impleading of contiguous land owners in Pre-emption Miscellaneous case and non-consideration of the ground can be, also, charaterised as an error apparent on the face of the record.

Md. Mafizul Islam Sarker Vs. Sunil Chandra Biswas & Ors. 12 BLT (HCD)-169

 

 

Section-115

Whether the High Court Division was justified in summarily allowing the revisional application without issuing any Rule.

Suit for declaration of title and recovery of khas possession of the schedule —2 of the Plaint —trial court decreed the suit against which the defendant preferred Appeal and in the appeal the appellate court by a Suo-Motu order directed for holding local investigation and directed the plaintiff to pay a sum of Tk.l000/- as commission fee

—Held; we are of the view that the High Court Division committed error of law in summarily allowing the revisional application without issuing a Rule in the facts and circumstances of the present case.

Jabbar Jute Mills Ltd Vs. Md. Abul Kashem &Anr J6BLT(AD)19.

Section-115

Suit for declaration of title and confirmation of possession

The appellate Court while reversing the judgment of the trial Court has rejected the evidence of P.Ws.2 and 3 who were examined from the side of the plaintiffs to corroborate the P.W.1 as regard the case of taking pattan of the land from the Ex-zarnindar since the said P.Ws. were not the persons whom the P.W. 1 stated were present at the time of pattan. The High Court Division while making the Rule absolute did not reverse the reasoning and the finding given by the appellate Court in rejecting the evidence of P.Ws.2 and 3 — Held: we are of the view that the High Court Division was in serious error in disturbing the finding of fact arrived at by the appellate Court when the said Division did not hold that the finding and decision made by the appellate Court was vitiated by non-consideration of the evidence or misreading of evidence or that the appellate Court left the vital evidence out of consideration for no valid reason while making its decision on the question of taking pattan of the land in suit by the plaintiffs and the nature and character of the Ext. 1 series as well as regarding possession of the plaintiffs.

Govt. of Bangladesh Vs. Ershad Ali Moral & Ors 16 BLT (AD)202

Section-115

Whether the High Court Division exceeded its revisional jurisdiction in setting aside the concurrent findings of facts arrived at by the courts below without considering the evidence on record

The High Court Division set aside the findings of the trial court and the appellate court with the observations “Moreover, the courts below have come to an erroneous finding as to the possession of the suit land in favour of the defendant No.1 due to Misreading and Misconstruction of the evidence on record.” The High Court Division did not mention what was the Misreading and Misconstruction of the evidence on record by the courts below. It appears that the High Court Division did not at all discuss the evidence of possession adduced by the parties. Thus it is clear that without adverting to the reasonings given by the trial court and the appellate court which are the final court of fact, the High Court Division reversed the concurrent findings of the courts below.

Abdul Mannan Vs. Lal Miah Haji & Ors 16 BLT(AD)68

 

Section-115 Read with Constitution of Bangladesh Article-109

Under the provisions of Article 109 of the Constitution this Court has control and superintendence over all subordinate courts and under the provisions of section 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure this Court can call for the records of any case from any subordinate Civil Court and can pass an appropriate order. If any presiding officer of any such Court fails to comply with any order or direction of this Court made in any case then such officer is not only guilty of contempt of this Court but, also of insubordination.

The State Vs. Mr. Faruque Ahmed 7BLT (HCD)-251

Section-115 read with Bengal Tenancy Act, 1885 Section-103B(5)

Presumption of correctness —the plaintiff led evidence of possession and the same has also been supported by D.Ws. Thus, the presumption attached to C.S. has been, rebutted and as such subsequent recording in R.S. and S.A. are of no legal consequence. The khatian being at best evidence of present possession could not be a, document of title so as to confer right, title, and interest of the suit land. The defendant having failed to prove any basis of their title, by any cogent material, the rent receipt Ext E series are of no avail to them. When evidence was led in rebuttal of the presumption of correctness of entry in the record of right and the appellate court below comes to a finding rebutting the presumption, the said finding being of fact, arrived at by the final court of fact on consideration of the evidence on record, is not liable to be interfered with in revision as there was no error of law resulting in the error in the decision occasioning failure of justice. The Court of appeal below has considered that no question of any partition in the suit is necessary, as the plaintiff has claimed the entire suit land and more so, the suit the entire suit was for declaration of title.

Nurul Haque & Anr. Vs. Lutfor Rahman & Ors. 10BLT (AD)-173

Section-115 read with Order 41 Rule 21

Rehearing of the Civil Revision Case

The provisions of Order XLI Rule 21 CPC are applicable in case of appeals and not in the case of civil revisions.

Manirunnessa Khanam & Anr Vs. Syed Madassir Ali & Anr 15 BLT (AD)356.

 

Section 115 read with Order 6 Rule 17

Held, It is true that the learned Assistant Judge did not assign any reason in allowing, the application for amendment. We find that the defendant has not in any way prejudice by such amendment. So non-assigning the reason by itself, not a ground for revision unless the same has resulted in an error in the decision occasioning failure of justice.

Ershad Ali Ors Vs. Md. Ruhul Amin & Ors 14 BLT (HCD) 467

 

Section-115 read with Code of Civil Procedure (Third Amendments) Act, 2003

Section-115(1)

Order passed by the Joint District Judge, in appeal.

The order passed by the learned Joint District Judge, was not in the original suit but in an appeal. In that view of the matter, it is very correct that the Joint District Judge, for all practical purpose, exercised the functions of the District Judge or an Additional District Judge, in disposing of the Miscellaneous appeal but it should be remembered that the revisional powers of the High Court Division is not an inherent power, rather, the power of revision is conferred by statute and since ft is a creature of statute, a Court cannot exercise revisional powers unless those powers are expressly conferred by the statute itself.

Gouranga Chandra Dey Vs. Deputy Commissioner& Ors. 12 BLT (HCD)-75

 

Section-115 read with Limitation Act Section-5

Delay of 542 days in filing the revisional Application
