In the background of the provision of law the suit filed by the Respondents and decreed by’ the courts below was being totally nonentertainable by the civil Court, the High Court Division was required to exercise its discretionary jurisdiction to collect the gross error of law committed by the courts below.

Director of Housing and Settlement, Dhaka Vs. Abdul Majid Howlader and Ors 14 BLT (AD)36

 

Section - 115 read with Evidence Act, 1872 Section – 43

In the previous suit i.e. Title Suit No.326 of 1975 defendant No.1 was the plaintiff and the plaintiff of the instant suit was defendant No.6 and the vendor of the plaintiff was defendant No.1 and in that situation the judgment in the previous suit even if may not strictly be consideration as the judgment inter parties but the same has been certainly admissible in evidence to show that there was a litigation between the plaintiff and the defendant No.1 who were parties in the previous suit and in that suit the specific contention of the parties as to whether plaintiff of that previous suit (defendant No.1 herein) has right, title and interest in the land in suit and the Court had found in that suit that said plaintiff had no right, title and interest in the land in suit which is the subject matter of the instant suit. In the background of the facts of the instant case the trial Court as well as the appellate Court while considering the question of right, title and interest and claim of possession of the plaintiff, which was denied by the defendant Nos.1-6, the said Courts in deciding the question of right, title, interest and possession of the plaintiff were not in error in considering the judgment in the previous suit along with the other evidence, both oral and documentary and decreeing the suit and that being the position the High Court Division without considering the evidence other than Exts.4 and 6 (previous judgment) placing reliance whereupon judgment by trial Court was made and the appellate Court affirmed was in error in reversing the judgment of the appellate Court affirming the judgment and decree of the trial Court on the view that the said Courts decreed the suit solely. On the basis of previous judgments which according to the High Court Division was not relevant.

Robert Pinaru Vs. Moulana Habibur Rahman & Ors. 14 BLT (AD)102

 

Section 115 read with Order —43 rule 1(r)

Law is settled now that order of status quo is an order of injunction whereby the parties to the suit are restrained from doing the act which may bring change in the position of the parties or in the nature and character of the property which is the subject matter of the suit an as to possession of the parties in the property in suit. The order of status quo may either be of the nature of ad-interim injunction or temporary injunction. The position of law is that an order of adinterim injunction is appealable like that of an order of temporary injunction. —In our opinion the High Court Division was quite correct in holding that the revisional application was not maintainable since the order impugning which the revisional application filed was appealable.

Doulat Ahmed Vs. Md. Shafiqul Islam Chowdhury & Ors 16 BLT (AD)17

 

Section-115 read with Partition Act, 1893 Section-4

From the judgment of the High Court Division it is seen that the said Division while interfering with the judgment of the appellate Court did not arrive at any finding that the same was made upon Misreading or non-consideration of evidence or that upon Misconstruction of any document. We have already mentioned that the defendant for his entitlement to buy out the share of the plaintiff in the land of C. S. plot No. 366 has not lead any evidence to establish the fact that the land in suit is part of the dwelling house of the undivided family or in other words part of the dwelling house of the defendant No. 1. The High Court Division was unmindful of the fact that defendant No. 1’s prayer under Section 4 of the partition Act could only be allowed upon establishing of the fact that the land in suit is part of his dwelling house or that the land in suit contiguous to the defendant’s homestead or that defendant needs the land in suit for convenient use and occupation of his dwelling house. But the defendant did not establish any one of the facts stated above. It may also be mentioned that defendant has not taken exception as regard the occupation of the land of C. S. plot No. 366 by the other  stranger purchasers who purchased the land of the plot in suit from the wife of the defendant No. 1 subsequent to plaintiff’s purchase. As seen from the judgment of the appellate court that it was contended from the side of the defendant No.1 that the strangers, one of whom purchased the land from the wife of the defendant No. 1, are “compromising person” and as such they have been accommodated by the defendant No. 1 and others. Legally the said contention is not sustainable since provision of Section 4 of the partition Act does not contemplate that a member of an undivided family will take exception in respect of a buyer who has purchased the part of the dwelling house of his undivided family but will not take exception in respect of the other stranger buyers who are not his kith and kin, as in the instant case, who have purchased the land of the dwelling house of undivided family.

Maleka Khatun & Ors Vs. Amena Khatun & Ors 16 BLT (AD)80

 

Section-115 read with IFIC Bank Service Rules; Rules 30.1

Plaintiff served the IFIC Bank as Assistant Vice President and who praying for declaration that the Order of his dismissal passed by the Bank is illegal —High Court Division held that “On perusal of record and deposition of the witnesses, it is appears that all the necessary legal formalities were complied with by the petitioner Bank in respect of the departmental proceeding initiated against the plaintiff opposite party No.1 Moreover, in his deposition, the plaintiff opposite party No. I admitted his negligence. On the face of such admission, it was open to the authority concerned to take appropriate action” —we are of the view that the High Court Division took a correct view in the matter and as such the impugned judgment does not call for our interference.

S.M. Iqbal Hossain Vs. JFIC Bank & Ors 16 BLT(AD)115

 

Section —115 read with State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950

Section —96

Barred by limitation

Kabala was entered into the volume of the office of the Sub-registrar on August 13, 1981. It was the contention of the preemptors that they had the initial knowledge of the transfer on January 8, 1982 and that on obtaining the certified copy of the kabala on 15.1.1982 they had the definite knowledge about the transfer. —The High Court Division on consideration of the materials on record held that the preemptors failed to establish their knowledge as claimed on January 8, 1982 and as such the case having been filed beyond 4 months from the date of registration i.e. August 13, 1981 the Miscellaneous case was barred by limitation. Held; we are of the view High Court Division did not commit any error in discharging the Rule on the finding that the appellate Court was quite correct that the Miscellaneous Case was barred by limitation.

Abdur Rahman & Ors Vs. Most. Rahimannessa and Ors 16 BLT (AD)171

 

Section 115 read with Ordinance No.24 of 1970

Notice served for eviction of the p1aintffc as per provision of Ordinance No.24 of 1970

The plaintiff challenging the legality of the notice served as per provision of ordinance No.24 of 1970 —Trial Court decreed the suit and thereupon the appellate Court reversed the same —The High Court Division on consideration of the materials on record arrived at the finding that the Gazette Notification for the acquisition of the property in question does not show that the entire property of the plot was acquired and that the notice served for the eviction of the plaintiffs does not contain any specification of the land and the plot number. The High Court Division also observed entire land of the plot was not acquired and the notice does not contain ‘the specification of the property nor any dag number or plot number’ and no authority to serve a notice was brought on record and the material that has been produced by submitting supplementary affidavit also does not show that the person who signed a notice was authorized to serve the notice. On the aforesaid finding the High Court Division made the Rule absolute —Held: In that state of the matter we are of the view the High Court Division was not in error in setting aside judgment of the appellate Court and thereby restoring the judgment of the trial Court.

Deputy Commissioner Vs. Md. Moshiur Rahman (Miran) (Minor) & Ors 16BLT(AD)142

 

Section-115 and 151

High Court has the power to expunge objectionable materials from the judgment and order passed by the Subordinate Court.

Bibhu Ranjan Das Vs. Hakim Ali & Ors 9BLT (HCD)-99

Section- 115(1)

Undisputedly Gopalganj Pourashava was created in the year 1972. Plaintiff filed the suit in 1968 on the basis of her taking settlement in 1948. Thus when both the trial court as well as the lower appellate court upon consideration of both oral and documentary evidence held that the plaintiff in 1355 B.S. took settlement of the suit land as an agricultural land, the learned Judge of the High Court Division appears to have acted illegally and without jurisdiction in reversing a concluded finding of fact in exercise of his revisional jurisdiction and thereby Misdirected himself in holding that the suit land is a non-agricultural land and that the plaintiffs settlement of the suit land having not been made by a registered instrument she did not acquire any valid title thereto.

Mrs. Nirmala Bala Das Vs. Ganesh Chandra Dhupi 7BLT (AD)-358

 

Section-115(1)

A Single Judge exercising jurisdiction under Section 115(1) C.P.C. was not invested with the jurisdiction to strike down a piece of legislation which is the absolute and exclusive jurisdiction of a properly constituted court exercising jurisdiction under Article 102 of the Constitution.

Husna Jahan (Munna) Vs. Md. Shahjahan (Shajal) & Ors. 7BLT (AD)-98

 

Section- 115(1)

Whether the High Court Division in exercise of his revisional jurisdiction acted wrongly in setting aside the findings of fact of the lower Appellate Court and has taken a contrary view on reassessment of the evidence Thus on a careful consideration of the oral and documentary evidences, attendant facts and circumstances of the case. We hold that the lower appellate court in fact did not consider certain material evidence in this case and the surrounding facts and circumstances relevant for consideration of determining the nature of benami transaction and fell into an error of law occasioning a failure of justice calling for interference by the High Court Division in its revisional jurisdiction.

Abdul Karim & Ore. Vs. Mvi Serajuddin Ahmed & Ors. 7BLT (AD)-160

 

Section-115(1)

Revisional application is in competent— Interlocutory order in a case for probate or letters of administration before the District Judge—we are of the view that every order including interlocutory order passed by the District Judge is subject to appeal. [Para-11]

Anuj Chowdhury & Ors Vs. Sailendra Kishore Chowdhury & Ors. 7BLT (HCD)-342

Section-115(1)

 

Final Order— Where the evidence on record are enough to pass an appropriate order the High Court in exercise of revisional juris diction can decide the case finally and conclusively without remanding it to the lower appellate court.

Mst. Saleha Bibi Vs. Taib Ali & Ors. 1BLT (HCD)-57

 

Section-115 (1)

High Court Division exceeded his jurisdiction in revision in entering into a question of fact and in comparing the signatures himself to arrive at a contrary finding of fact. The finding of fact as to non service of Summons made by the trial court was not perverse, nor was it such as could legitimately justify an interference by the revisional Court on accepted principles.

Md. Wazed Ali Sardar Vs. Md. Afsaruddin Sardar and Ors. 4BLT (AD)-1

 

Section- 115(1)

Shifting of the school to the new site—the revisional court is competent to interfere in a case of non-consideration of material evidence which is specifically material for the determination of the material issue. Namely, the issue of shifting of the school to the new mouza.

Md. Abu Bakar Siddique Vs. A. D. C. & Ors. 4BLT (AD) -233

 

Section- 115(1)

Revisional authority—in a Suit for declaration—Non consideration and Misreading of material evidence of the P.W.s being a question of law the High Court Division was justified in setting aside the finding of possession against the plaintiff of the lower appellate Court.

Akil Uddin Mallick & Ors. Vs. Jonab Ali Sheikh 4BLT (AD)-254

 

Section-115(1)

The revisional power of the High Court Division is supervisory power which may also be exercised suo motu. The natural corollary would be that the High Court Division is not obliged to hear the parties before pronouncing its verdict when the parties concerned had opportunities to appear but refrained from doing so.

Safaruddin & Ors Vs. Fazlul Hug & Ors 5BLT (AD)-201

 

Section-115(1)

The factual aspect of the case and the evidence adduced are all in favour of the defence. There was no proper appreciation of the case in the light of the evidence adduced by the trial court as well as by the appellate court. The learned single Judge of the High Court Division has not therefore exceeded his jurisdiction in interfering with the matter and come to his finding on appreciation of the evidence and the facts and circumstances of the case. It is well settled that the High Court Division may interfere in a case where there is total non- consideration or Misreading of the evidence on record and the finding arrived is contrary to evidence. Here I find that the finding arrived at by the trial court as well as by the appellate Court was based on total non- consideration and Misreading of the evidence on record and as such perverse. The trial court as well as the appellate court shirked their responsibilities in properly and legally evaluating the evidence and fact, and circumstances of the case while disposing the matter in question.

Asmat Ali  Vs. Abdur Rafique Mridha &Ors. 9BLT (AD)-12

 

Section-115(1)

When there is contest over the insertion of certain recitals in the questioned document and when defendant no.1 was specific in his evidence the plaintiff ought to have produced more materials in support of his case. The test as aforesaid to find out the real intent could not be proved by the plaintiff. In view of the clear defence evidence and inadequate and contradictory evidence led from the side of the plaintiff it cannot be found that the questioned transaction is an Usufructuary mortgage. Here the question is of non-consideration and Misreading of material evidence—High Court Division may interfere in a case where there is total non-consideration or Misreading of the evidence on record and the finding arrived is contrary to evidence

Asmat Ali Vs. Abdur Rafique Mridha & Ors. 9BLT (AD)-77

 

Section-115(1)

It is well settled that once the conditions in section 115(1) of the Code of Civil Procedure are satisfied and the High Court’s jurisdiction is established, the proceedings as a whole from start to finish can be scrutinized and any order necessary for doing justice may be passed. There is no limit to the area in which the revisional power is to be exercised by the High Court Division in the facts and circumstances of the each case.

Md. Shajahan Khan Vs. A.D. C (Rev) & Ors. 11BLT(AD)-60

 

Section 115(1)

High Court Division was in error in deciding and reversing the question of fact in respect of possession and Istafa (surrender) which were found in favour of the appellants by the courts below.

Abu Hussain & Ors. Vs. Afezudding Mondal & Ors 11BLT(AD)-122

 

Section 115 (1)

The trial Court after accepting the Commissioner’s report having, passed the final decree as per provision of sub-rule (3) of Rule 14 Of order XXVI of the Code of Civil procedure there was/is no scope to file revisional application.

Abu Bakar Siddique Vs. M. Khorshed Alam & Ors. J1BLT (HCD)-508

 

Section-115(i)

Revisional powers—It is no doubt true that findings of fact, whether concurrent or not are not ordinarily disturbed by the High Court Division in revision. But where there is a Misreading of evidence or non consideration of material evidence affecting the merit of the case, the High Court Division can review the evidence and correct the error in exercise of its revisional powers.

Md. Nurul Islam & Ors. Vs. Nipendra Pathak & Ors. 6BLT (AD)-163

 

Section-115(1)

Application under order 41 rule 19 C.P.C.— learned District Judge dismissed the M/Sc. Case not only on limitation but also on merit—Held: The learned Judge of the High Court Division in the impugned judgment did not at all touch upon the question of limitation, not to speak of reversing the finding in that regard arrived at by the learned District Judge, on consideration of facts, that the M/Sc. Case in question was barred by 19 days. Thus the impugned judgment of the High Court Division is patently not a proper judgment of reversal.

Surendra Nath Sarker & Anr. Vs. Md. Jalil Sheikh 6BLT (AD)-169

 

Section-115(1)

Trial court’s findings affirmed by the appellate court—concurrent findings of fact disturbed without adverting to them— Reversal of two courts’ Judgment in revision is without any legal foundation.

Haji Nurul Alam Vs Al-haj Abdus Sobhan 3BLT (AD)-135

 

Section-115(1)

Misscarriage of justice—the trial Court appears to have failed to take to consideration of the cause of action as averred by the plaintiff in her plaint. It also did not consider the entire evidence on record on issue of possession and dispossession. It noticed some of the evidence but failed to comprehend the legal effect of those evidence. It also failed to give any decision on the date of dispossession and how dispossession took place. It failed to raise, and decide on, the important issue to raise, and decide on, the important issue of limitation and also nature of the possession of the plaintiff. In the absence of clear findings that the plaintiff was in possession and dispossessed by the defendants within six months of the institution of the suit, the trial Court fell in serious error of law in decreeing the suit for possession which has resulted in Miscarriage of justice. Such decree for possession cannot be sustained in law.

Jebun Nessa Zaman & Ors Vs. Hosneara Lili. 9BLT (HCD)-251

 

Section-115(1)

Maintainability—it is very much well settled principle of law that an Election Tribunal is empowered to pass an order of recounting of ballot papers and as such no illegality has been committed by the learned Assistant Judge in passing the impugned order. As to maintainability of the revisional Application, I am of the view relying on the decision reported in 9 DLR 173 that the Election Tribunal not being a Civil Court is not amenable to the revisional jurisdiction of the High Court Division and as such the revisional application is not maintainable and the Rule is liable to be discharged as not being maintainable.

Md. Abdul Karim Mia Vs. Md. Mohiuddin & Ors 9BLT (HCD)-335

 

Section-115(i)

A perusal of the judgment of the High Court Division shows that the learned Judge had discussed the evidence on record threadbare and pointed out that the appellate court left out of consideration important pieces of evidence and palpably Misconstrued the evidence that it had considered. The learned Judge also pointed out that the conclusion reached by the appellate court on title and possessions absurd. He was, however, quite mindful of the fact that usually in revisional jurisdiction the Court is not expected to go into evidence but that the instant case is an exception to the rule. The appellate court having absolutely Misconstrued the evidence we do not find any tangible fault with the elaborate judgment of the High Court Division.

Sufia Khatoon & Ors. Vs. Madar Mia & Ors 8BLT (AD)-47

 

Section-115(1)

It appears that the trial court had approached the case from a wrong premise discussing the defence case first and the appellate court which was the final court of fact had reversed the findings of the trial court after discussing the evidence of both the parties in proper sequence. The appellate court appears to have discussed each witness both for the plaintiff and for the defendants and also the documents in coming to its conclusion that the plaintiff could prove his title and possession but the circumstances proved that the registered lease deed dated 3 April 1957 in favour of the defendants was a collusive document since the landlord had not right to lease out the land at that time. Furthermore the defendants failed to prove any farog in confirmation of which the lease deed is said to have been executed. But the learned Judge of the High Court Division did not consider any of the above aspects of the case. Those apart the High Court Division as a revisional court had hardly any jurisdiction to set aside the findings of fact by the appellate court and that also without discussing any fault in the factual finding by the said court.

Kachi Mia Vs. Suruj Mia & Ors 8BLT (AD)-125

 

Section-115(1)

Revisional court found it to be a case of non-consideration of material evidence on record. D.W.1 Abu Taher said in his deposition that the pre-emptor is his cousin sister and she lived in the same village and her husband knew about the same transfer of the case land and requested him to purchase the case land and also told them that they would help the pre-emptor in purchasing the land. D.W. 2A K.M. Golzar Hossain also corroborated the statement of D.W. 1 that both the pre-emptor and her husband refused to purchase the land. This specific deposition of D.Ws. 1 and 2 was not at all considered by the last court of fact. So this non-consideration of the vital material evidence affected the merit of the case, the revisional court in the facts of the present case correctly found that the deposition of D.Ws 1-3 was not at all discussed and considered as has been done by the trial court. Further, the judgment of the lower appellate court is based on certain surmises and conjectures as the lower appellate court that if the pre-emptor and her husband were requested to purchase the land before preemption then probably either the pre-emptor or her husband ought to have been a signatory either in the agreement or in the kabala. This is really an assumption and surmise of the lower appellate court which is not borne out by any evidence on record. There is no scope to guess this probability on the face of positive oral evidence on record. That apart, the pre-emptor and the pre-emptee are relations and live in the same village—the exercise of revisional jurisdiction by the learned Single Judge was proper and justified in the facts of the case.

Most. Rokeya Begum Vs. Md. Abu Zaher & Ors 8 BLT (AD)-134

 

Section-115(1)

The suit was found for maintainable by the trial court for want of possession of the plaintiffs in accordance with the proviso to Section 42 of the Specific Relief Act. The appellate court found fault with the finding of possession arrived at by the trial court holding that the reasons of the trial court suffered from discrepancy. Again, the appellate court also found that the Assistant Custodian of Vested Property was necessary for the sake of effective and complete adjudication. The appellate court thus did not give any independent finding on possession or decide the matter of impleading the Assistant Custodian in the suit itself. The said court had sent back the case on remand for deciding it on all points after fresh trial. Such an order on the facts and in the circumstances of the case has not caused any Miscarriage of justice for any patent illegality as such. It was not proper for the High Court Division while exercising revisional jurisdiction to interfere with the order of remained.

Md. Chand Mia Vs. Md. Shamsuddin & Ors 8BLT (AD)-180

 

Section-115(1)

The Suit was for declaration of title of the plaintiff on assertion of possession and that C.S. R.S. and S.A Khatians are wrong. Defendant has not disputed the quantum of land in patta Ext. 1 or the suit land as claimed by the plaintiff on the basis of the patta or that land of S.A. Khatian No 311 did not form part of land of patta Ext. 1 and as such there was no dispute that the suit land was not identical to the land patta. I and accordingly, no question of relayment in order to ascertain identity of the land was necessary. Thus the High Court Division erred in law in holding that in order to ascertain the suit land claimed by the plaintiff relayment is required and as that was not done by the plaintiff, they failed to prove (heir claim as per pleading.

Nurul Haque & Anr. Vs. Lutfor Rahman & Ors. 10 BLT (AD)-173

 

 

Section-115(1)

Judgment—reversing

The learned Additional District Judge who reversed the judgment of the trial court had not controvert of facts and did not reverse the findings of fact arrived at by the trial court. The Additional District Judge did not discuss the oral or documentary evidence and therefore it was held that the appellate court arrived at an illegal and unsustainable finding that the property was a vested property.

Shamsunnaher Vs. Md. Afzal Patwary & Ors. 12 BLT (AD)89

 

Section-115 (1)

Suit for declaration and recovery of Possession

The lower Appellate Court on consideration of the evidence, both oral and documentary, has found title of the plaintiff in the land in suit and also has held that the defendant was a mere licensee of his father in the land in suit. It was the contention of the defendant that the kabala executed by Yakub Ali in favour of Ishaque was acted upon. The lower appellate Court in the background of the facts as well as on the basis of the evidence held that the kabala executed by Yakub Ali in favour of his son Ishaque was not acted upon. The High Court Division has not disturbed the findings so arrived at by the appellate Court in decreeing the suit.

 

Md. Golam Rasul Vs. Chan Mohammed 12 BLT (AD)163

Section-115(1)

The finding of the trial court that the plaintiff failed to prove that the right, title, interest and possession of the defendants No. 5-7 had extinguished from the suit plot and failed to prove that the kabalas are collusive and without consideration, illegal and not binding on the plaintiff is based on due consideration of the evidence on record of the case which has not been reversed by the appellate court below. In that view of the matter the impugned judgment and decree passed by the appellate court below is not sustainable in law.

Faziul Haque Bepari & Ors. Vs Abdul Mannan Dewan & Ors 12 BLT (HCD) 339

 

Section-115(1)

The decision on the issue of resjudicata

Both the courts before committed Mistake in rejecting the plaint outright on the ground of res-judicata without proper adjudication after taking evidence Disposal of the suit on the decision of resjudicata issue without holding trial and without taking decision in other necessary issues involved in the suit, resulted erroneous decision which occasioned failure of justice.

Md. Echmail Howlader & Ors Vs. Bangladesh & Ors 12 BLT (HCD)210

 

Section - 115 (1)

The defendant Nos.6-8 being year to year lease holders had no locus-standi to prefer any appeal before the appellate court as well as in the High Court Division.

Srimati Aroti Rani Paul. Vs Sree Sudarshan Kumar Paul & Ors. 13 BLT (AD)36

 

Section —115 (1)

We find that the High Court Division in the exercise of revisional jurisdiction considered that the trial court dismissed the suit on the ground of limitation taking the decision dated 3-8-1974 that is Exhibit-A as a document of possession. The appellate court being the final court of fact discussed the evidence on record namely evidence of Pws. 1,2,3 and 4 and Dw.l as well as the Exhibit-5 and came to the definite finding that the college authority dispossessed the plaintiff from the 2 ka schedule land in 1986 and accordingly held the suit was not barred by limitation. The High Court Division in our view rightly held that the plaintiff is entitled to get the suit decreed as a whole.

Boalkhali Sirajul islam College Vs. Ahmed Hossain Chowdhury & Ors 13 BLT (AD) 30

Section-115(1)

Not a Proper Judgment of reversal

The trial Court has considered all material facts and has considered the evidence of Pws 1,2,3 and 4 and held that the plaintiff could not prove his possession and subsequent dispossession from the suit land but the learned appellate court being the final court of facts has totally ignored to consider those material facts — Held Judgment is not a proper judgment of reversal.

Md. Abdul Mazid Vs. Md. Basiruddin & Ors 13 BLT (HCD)110

 

Section -115(1)

Proper Judgment in reversing the decision of the trial court

Recognised Non-Government Secondary School Teacher’s (Board of Intermediate and Secondary Education, Dhaka) Terms and Conditions of Service Regulation, 1979- the plaintiff’s removal or dismissal from service without proper approval of the Board was illegal and without jurisdiction.—The lower appellate court also considered the plaintiffs case as regards cause of her removal and found that the decision of the trial court that the suit is hit by the section 42 of the Specific Relief Act was not correct and reversed the said finding on consideration of the materials on record.

Kadamtala Purba Basaboo Uchha Biddalaya & Ors Vs Hachna Hena Sarker & Ors.13 BLT (HCD) 289

 

Section - 115(1)

The High Court Division without adverting to the findings given by the court of appeal regarding of pattan by Basanta Kumar in favour of the plaintiffs by dakhilas, subsequent execution of unilateral kabuliyats by plaintiffs in favour of Basanta Kumar and possession of the defendants in the suit land reversed those finding on reassessment of the entire evidence. Accordingly, the High Court Division committed error of law in making the Rule absolute.

Promad Chandra Barman & Ors. Vs. Most. Khodeza Khatun & Ors 14 BLT (AD)222

 

Section - 115(1)

The trial court found possession of the plaintiff in the suit land. But the court of appeal below considering the background of the case held that the plaintiff has failed to prove his possession rather the defendants’ witnesses have been able to prove the possession of the defendants in the suit land. The court of appeal below in support of the conclusion regarding possession of the defendants in the suit land observed that there was no denial of the fact that C.S. Dag Nos.585 and 586 are in possession of the defendants in their jote right from the time of their predecessors under the common landlords within the same Mouza as of Dag No.490 and both of them are on the contiguous east of the suit land forming part of Dag No.490 and it was apparent that the plaintiff had no land or house near about the suit land. In such circumstances it was natural that the riparian owner of the adjoining holding of the suit land would go into possession of any land coming out of the river by way of alluvion contiguous to his original holding under the same landlord. In that view of the matter the defence case was found to be more acceptable than the plaintiffs story of possession. The above observations of the court of appeal below are based on proper consideration of the materials on record and averments made in the plaint that the suit land was part of a large navigable river and gradually the river had silted up. It further appears that the court of appeal below assigned cogent reasons for disbelieving the evidence of plaintiffs witnesses regarding possession and for believing of the evidence of defendants witnesses regarding possession of the defendants in the suit land -the appellate court below reversed the findings of the trial court on exhaustive consideration and elaborate discussion of both the documentary and oral evidence on record. So the observations and findings of the High Court Division in reversing the findings of the lower appellate court are rather without any basis.

Md. Abdul Hanif Mia & Ors. Vs. Kad Banu & Ors 14 BLT (AD) 170

 

Section - 115(1)

The instant impugned decree having passed by the learned senior Assistant Judge of the first instance which is appeal able as already found by me, the instant civil revision does not lie. Provision of sub-section (1) of Section 115 of the Code can only be invoked against an order or decree passed by the learned District Judge or Additional District Judge or against the decree passed the Joint District Judge, Senior Assistant Judge or Assistant Judge from which no appeal lies. The impugned decree having also not been passed by the learned District Judge or Additional District Judge no revision lies under sub-section (4) of Section 115 of the Code, the present civil revision is Misconceived.

Abdur Rashid Salam Vs Dr. Md. Moniruzzaman 14 BLT (HCD) 01

 

Section—115(1)

The petitioners are 3rd Party to the decree and to the execution proceeding-the execution proceeding has been started by the decree holder against the judgment debtors but not against the present petitioners-The subsequent leasing out of the suit property by the judgment debtor in favour of the 3rd party petitioner having made during pendency of the appeal and also in violation of the Court’s injunction order, that leasing out of suit property will not affect the merit of the suit-revisional application is not maintainable.

Hazi Altas Member & Ors. Vs. Sirajul Huq & Ors 14 BLT (HCD) 346

 

Section—115(1)

Non-consideration of the material evidences

In the instant case the plaintiff is admittedly a co-sharer to the ka schedule land to the plaint to the extent of 8-annas share. The total land covered by Ka schedule land measures an area of 1.33 acres of land. Admittedly the plaintiff is entitled to get a preliminary decree for partition to the extent of .661/2 acres of land but the Courts below have given a preliminary decree to the extent of 30 decimals. It is nobody’s case that the plaintiff has sold some property elsewhere. In view of the above the plaintiff was entitled to get a preliminary decree to the extent of .661/2 acres of land. I find that the learned Sub-ordinate Judge has committed an error of law resulting in an error in the decision occasioning a failure of justice in assessing the share of the plaintiff and the impugned judgment and decree is not sustainable in law. The plaintiff is entitled to get a decree to the extent of .661/2 decimals in preliminary form.

Surajit Kumar Das & Ors. Vs. Jahanara Hossain & Ors 14 BLT (HCD)383

 

 

Section 115 (1)

Essential elements of adverse possession

Plaintiff’s case that he entered into the suit land on the strength of an oral agreement and he paid the full consideration money—Held; the plaintiff if be found to be in possession on the basis of the oral contract that possession cannot be considered to be adverse possession against, the true owner. The learned District Judge were not justified in finding adverse possession without framing any issue on the point. The Courts below were not justified in declaring title by adverse possession and the decisions arrived at by the courts below are liable to be set aside.

Abu Taher& Ors Vs. Ayub Ali Mollah & Ors 14 BLT (HCD)486

 

Section 115 (1)

The decree has been passed declaring title by adverse possession without framing any issue on such vital question of law and fact—Held; the learned the learned Sub-ordinate Judge being the, trial Court and the learned District Judge being the appellate Court have committed an error of law resulting in an error in the decision a failure of justice declaring title of the plaintiff by adverse possession in the suit land without being based on a proper pleading as any evidences on record. Those finding and decision arrived by the learned District Judge are although concurrent in nature but those are per versed and not sustainable in law. Those decisions having arrived at without being based on any evidence on record are set-aside.

Abu Taher & Ors Vs. Ayub Ali Mollah & Ors 14 BLT (HCD) 486

 

Section-115(1)

It appears from the judgments of the courts below that the pre-emptee persistently raised claim that he being co- sharer in the case holding pre-emptor was not entitled to maintain the pre-emption case- but as already observed no evidence was produced in support of the claim—any ground not canvassed before the courts below cannot be raised before the Appellate Division.

Abdul Kashem Vs. A.N.M. Azizur Rahman & Ors 15 BLT (AD)86

 

Section-115(1)

The application/lied by the defendant No.52 to allow him to make construction at his own risk in the land seeking partition whereof the aforesaid suit has been filed.

In the instant case the definite contention of the plaintiffs is that the land in a portion whereof the defendant No.52 seeks leave of the Court to make construction would certainly exceed his share and this fact is not disputed by the defendant. In that state of the matter we are of the view that High Court Division was in error in allowing the prayer of the defendant No. 52 to build a multi storied building on the land in excess of his share.

Hazi Mohammad Hossain & Ors Vs. Obaidul Haque & Ors 15BLT(AD)188

 

Section —115(1)

Jurisdiction to consider the prayer for exempting from comply with the order of High Court Division entirely

The High Court Division instead of disposing of the Rule on merit discharged the same only on the ground the appellant, petitioner before the High Court Division was required to comply with the order of the said Division directing him to furnish certified copy of the decrees of the courts below within the time specified i.e. by 5.12.1999, but he complied with the part of the order of the High Court Division by filing certified copy of the decree of the appellate Court on 5.12.1999 and thereby defaulted in the compliance of the order of the High Court Division passed at the time of issuance of the Rule. The High Court Division discharged the Rule for default on the view that because of the expression used in the order of the High Court Division the same was final one and that on the expiry of the stipulated time the High Court Division had no power to consider the application filed on 6.12.1999 stating the fact in the background whereof the appellant was unable to comply with the order of the High Court Division.—Held; In our opinion in the background of the statement made by the appellant explaining the reason or ground for his non-furnishing the certified copy of the decree of the trial Court the High Court Division would have been within its jurisdiction to consider the prayer for exempting him from furnishing the certified copy of the decree of trial Court and could have very much exercise its power for the purpose of advancing the cause of justice by allowing the prayer for exempting the appellant from filing the certified copy of the decree of the Trial Court.

Md. Farhat Rahman Vs. Roomee Tareque Moudud 15(AD)193

 

Section-115(1)

The High Court Division while exercising its revisional jurisdiction is competent to reverse the judgment of the courts, below when the same has been made either upon M/S-reading or non-consideration of the material evidence and the said M/S-reading and non-consideration of the evidence caused failure of justice. The High Court Division is also competent to set aside the judgment of the lower appellate Court when the same has been passed on the basis of evidence which cannot be considered legal evidence and had the same been not taken into consideration the judgment would not have been one as has been made.

Md. Habibullah Vs. Mr. Sher Ali Khan & Ors 15 BLT (AD) 319

 

Section-115(1)

Since the Court of fact on detail discussion of the evidence on record held that the plaintiffs failed to prove their exclusive possession in respect of the land in suit and that the last Court of fact also held that, the land in respect whereof decree for permanent injunction has been sought is unspecified and as the said finding did, not suffer from any mis-reading or non-consideration of the evidence or in other words any legal evidence was not left out in making the decision in the case by the Court of fact the High Court Division was in serious error in reversing the concurrent finding of fact of the courts below.

Md Habibullah Vs. Mr. Sher Ali Khan & Ors 15 BLT (AD) 319

 

Section-115(1)

Suit for mandatory injunction Compelling the defendants for paying her salary as a teacher of the defendant’s Non-government Primary School —The plaintiff being a teacher is entitled to get her salary so long the school functions.

Matler Char Non-Govt. Primary School Vs. Razia Sultana and others & Ors 15 BLT (HCD)418

 

Section-115(1)

A case of title by adverse possession and a case of title on the basis of documents cannot be claimed simultaneously but in the instant case the plaintiffs tried to do so —we are of the view that the court of appeal and the High Court Division wrongly relied upon the receipt Ext. 1, the agreement Ext.2 and the kabala Ext.3 as documents of title in favour of the plaintiffs and accordingly fell in error in decreeing the suit holding that the plaintiffs have title in the suit property.

Pushpa Rani Saha Podder Vs. Kartick Chowdhury Saha & Ors 16 BLT (AD)350

 

Section-115(1)

Whether provision of order 17 rule 7 of the code of civil procedure (Third Amendment), 2003 debar a party from availing other legal remedies

The defendant filed an appeal under section 96(2) of the Code of Civil Procedure against whom an exparte decree has been passed- The learned District Judge rejecting the appeal summarily on the finding that the appellant had his remedy under order 17 rule 7 of the Code of Civil Procedure (Third Amendment) 2003- Held; that the learned District judge committed a gross error of law in holding that the appeal was not maintainable and thereby rejecting the appeal summarily which has resulted in an error in the impugned decision occasioning failure of justice

Md. Nurul Islam & Ors Vs. Abdul. Mannan Howlader & Ors 16 BLT (HCD)60

 

Section-115(1)

Whether the issue on maintainability is Permitted to raise before the revisional Court.

Suit for Simple Petition —The issue on maintainability of the Suit was not raised before the trial court or before the appellate Court or even revisional application —The plea of maintainability of a simple suit for partition may be raised for the first time before the revisional court which does not require any other evidence to decide the maintainability issue.

Jotimoy Datta & Ors Vs Mritunjoy Datta @Palash & Ors 16 BLT (HCD) 446

 

Section-115(1) read with State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950 Section—91(1)

Subsisting interest at least to the extent of 12 decimal of land in the case jote.

Defect of parties—the pre-emptors definite case is that after his sales Nitya Gopal Biswas was left with no subsisting interest in the case jote and the pre-emptee led evidence to substantiate the said fact. The learned courts below on considered of the evidence on record concurrently found that Nitya Gopal Biswas had no subsisting interest in the case jote after his sales— Held : — The findings fact arrived at by the learned courts below on all points at issue appear to be well supported by the evidence on record, both oral and documentary, and these do not suffer from any legal infirmity calling for interference in revision.

Dhirendra Nath Biswas & Ors Vs. Nikhil Chandra Biswas 6BLT (HCD)-206

 

Section 115 (1) Read with Order-47

Review of the Judgment

The Revisional Power of the High Court Division is supervisory power which may also be exercised suo motu. The natural corollary would be that the High Court Division is not obliged to hear the parties before pronouncing its verdict when the parties concerned had opportunities to appear but refrained from doing so. (Para-6)

Safaruddin & Ors. Vs. Fazlul Huq & Ors. 5BLT (AD)-129

Section-115(1) read with Specific Relief Act, 1877 [I of 1877]

 

Section-9

It is the admitted position that. defendants No.1-2 in possession of the suit land at the present. There is nothing on record to show that the defendants entered into the suit land lawfully inasmuch as it is not the case that the defendant No.7 got possession of the suit properties from her father amicably. Finding as to the possession is a finding of fact and finding to fact is not to be interfered with in revisional jurisdiction of his court unless there is any Misreading or non-consideration of any materials on record.

Sri Durgesh Chandra Sin ha & Ors. Vs. Md. Mozibur Rahman & Ors. 10BLT (HCD)-285

 

Section-115(1) read with Wakfs Ordinance, 1962

Section-56(1)

In the instant case Exbt. ‘Kha’ shows that permission was granted for permanent lease. In view of such clear provision of law and the evidence on record, the court of appeal below fell in serious error of law in holding that the lease for a term exceeding 5 years even with sanction of the Administrator cannot be valid, and such view cannot be sustained in law.

Mohiuddin Fahim & Anr. Vs. Md. Kolimullah & Ors. 10BLT (HCD)288

 

Section-115 read with State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950

Section-95 and 95A

The plaintiff attested the Kabala of defendant No. 1, exhibit A(2). The plaintiff explained in his deposition that he put his signature on the request of the defendant and that he thought that the deed was in respect of other land. He also stated that they live as neighbors—by attestation to deed exhibit A(2). the plaintiff cannot be held to have knowledge of the contents of the deed, exhibit A (2) in order to be estopped under Section-115 of the Evidence Act for claiming restoration of the suit and under Section —95 and 95A of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950.

Mrs. Wahida Begum & Ors. Vs. Tajul Islam & Ors. 8BLT (HCD)-238

 

Section-115(1) read with Order-26, rule 14(2)

In effecting partition, the Commissioneris always guided by long established principles for partition. If it is found that the Commissioner divided the joint property beyond the writ of partition or in violation of any established principles of partition the court can always interfere. But second commission superseding the report cannot be ordered just on the objections, Appellate court is also empowered to scrutinize the report and make such further inquiry as may be necessary. Were the report is unsatisfactory, this division exercising revision jurisdiction can also exercise the same jurisdiction as vested in the trial Court.

A. Ali Sheikh & Anr Vs. K. Ali Sheikh, & Ors. 11BLT(HCD)-444

 

Section - 115(1) read with Trust Act, 1882 Section-18

Considering the terms and conditions of the Trust deed itself and upon consideration of the said terms and conditions of the Trust deed the learned Additional District Judge arrived at a definite finding to the effect that the new management committee proposed to the formed by the petitioners has been in direct violation of the terms of the Trust deed itself and that is the reason why the learned Additional District Judge refused the prayer for constituting the proposed committee for the Management of the Trust by his impugned order.—Held: I am of the opinion that the impugned judgment and order do not call for any interference by this Court particularly view of absence of any materials to show that the findings on the basis where of the impugned order was passed are not based on consideration of the materials on record.

Raj Ballav Paul Vs. Tapon Kumar Paul & Ans. 11BLT(HCD)460

 

Section-115(1) read with State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950 [28 of 1951]

Section-96(12)

Revisional application is not maintainable

—Pre-emptor filed, an application for addition of parties and the said application was rejected —Held : This Act being special law, the provision of this Act excludes the general law and requirement of this law is to file appeal to the ordinary Civil Appellate Court and as such the revisional application under Section 115(1) of the Code of Civil Procedure does not lie.

Abdul Gani Vs. Bachu miah & Ors. 9BLT (HCD)-256

 

Section-115(1) read with Non-Agricultural Tenancy Act, 1949 [XXIII of 1949]

Section 24(9)

The impugned order having been passed under special law and where method of enforcing the right is pointed out by the law must be followed that is in the present case the appeal lies before the Civil Appellate Court having jurisdiction to entertain such appeals and as such the rule is maintainable.

Sunil Baran Dey & Ors. Vs. Gitashri Das Gupta & Ors. 9BLT (HCD)-340

 

Section-115(1) read with Order 41 rule-23

In the instant case since it is found that both the court below did not at all consider or assess the evidence on record, this court does not feel it proper to embark upon a task which is specifically assigned to the Trial Court and not to a revisional court like the present one.

Md. Mozibar Rahman Molla & Anr. Vs. Md. Rehazuddin & Ors 12 BLT (HCD)219

 

Section-115(1) ‘read with’ Succession Act (Act No. XXXIX of 1925)

Section-372

Section 81, 82 and 83 of Mullas Hindu Law clearly describe that brother and mother of a deceased Hindu governed by the Dayabhaga Law are heirs as ‘Sapindas’. The claims of such heirs however inferior to those of said opposite parties wife and son, their right to citation and to be present in the proceeding for a succession certificate could not be denied. So, the impugned order of learned Joint District Judge rejecting the application for addition on the view that the applicants were not heirs of said deceased Rana Dutta is Wholly erroneous and cannot be sustained.

Prodip Kumar Dutta & Ors. Vs. Mira Rani Dutta & Ors. 12 BLT (HCD)287

 

Section-115(1) read with Order 41 rule-23

Whether the Order of remand is not permissible,

Held, the High Court Division while remanding the case to the trial court wrongly took the view that the appellate court disposed of the appeal without disposing the earlier application dated 20-04-1995. We therefore hold that in view of the subsequent application dated 25-4-1996 of the preemptor there was no existence of application dated 20-04-1995, so the High Court Division. has totally Misdirected itself in remanding the case to the appellate court without noticing that there was no existence of the application dated 20-4-1995 and this kind of non consideration is a non application of judicial mind which not only caused a failure of justice resulting in an error in the decision.

Abdul Matlib & Ors Vs. Abdul Malik 12 BLT (AD) 109

 

Section - 115 (1) read with Specific Relief Act, Section -54

Suit for permanent injunction

High Court Division in its revisional jurisdiction found that the defendant could not proved their prima facie title and exclusive possession in the suit land, the documents filed by the plaintiff respondents are not forged and the plaintiff respondents have proved the existence of a boundary wall on all sides of the suit land which did not in any way discard their exclusive possession.— Petition is dismissed.

Md. Abdus Zaher & Ors. Vs. Abdul Jabbar & Ors. 13 BLT (AD)69

 

Section 115(1) read with State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950

Section —96

The Court of 1st instance allowed the prayer for pre-emption on the finding that the preemptor is a contiguous land owner to the land of Plot No.909. The pre-emptee went on appeal. The appellate Court without adverting to the finding of the trial Court that pre-emptor is the owner of the land of plot No.911 and that the said plot is contiguous to the plot No.909, land of which sought to be pre-empted set aside the judgment and order of the trial Court. Thereupon the pre-emptor moved the High Court Division in revision jurisdiction. The High Court Division on consideration of the materials on record upon arriving at the finding that fact of pre-emptor’s being the owner of the land of plot No.911 has been established by reliable evidence and the said plot is contiguous to the plot No.909 land of which sought to be pre-empted made the Rule absolute held; -Judgment of the High Court Division is based on Consideration of the materials on record-Petition is dismissed.

Md. Lal Mia Matabbar Vs. Motaleb Fakir & Ors 12 BLT (AD)250

 

Section—115(1) read with Civil Courts (Amendment) Act, 2001

Section—21 read with Suit Valuation Act, 1887 Section—8

The High Court Division under Section 115 (I) of the Code can entertain revisional application against the order passed by the Joint District Judges in a suit or preceding the value of which is more than taka five lac in exercise of the power of superintendence and control over the subordinate courts.

Md. Zahid Abbas Vs. Alan, Bhuiyan and Ors 14 BLT (HCD)269

 

Section—115(1) read with Union Parishad and Paurashava (Election) Rules, 1973 Rule—62

The Tribunal itself having failed to feel necessity of counting the votes to satisfy itself as to correct counting by the presiding officer and no counting of votes having made by the Tribunal itself the result of election cannot be disturbed by him.

Rafiqul Islam & Ors. Vs. Md. Abdul Jabbar Sarker & Ors 14 BLT (HCD) 352

 

Section 115 (1) read with Order 26 Rule 11

Whether the advocate Commissioner had jurisdiction to go beyond the direction given in the preliminary decree. It appears from the saham chittar that .02 acre of land from Plot No. 449 has been allotted to the plaintiff which he is not entitled to get as per the preliminary decree. So it appears that the final decree impugned in the Rule has been passed violating admission made by the plaintiff himself in his evidence and also has been passed violating the specific direction given by the trial court in the preliminary decree. Both the courts below committed an error of law resulting in an error in the decision occasioning a failure of justice in accepting the final decree.

Nur Alam & Ors Vs. Majibar Rahman & Ors 14 BLT (HCD)498

 

Section —115(1) read with Limitation Act Article—44

Suit for a declaration—The plaintiff was minor at the time of execution and registration of the deed in question. He filed the Suit within 2 months from the date of knowledge on 6.5.95 —Held Article 44 of the Limitation Act provides a limitation for filing, any suit by a award within 3 years on attaining majority or within 12 years from the date of execution and registration of the deed. The Plaintiff had to file his suit within 3 years from the date of attaining majority. But in the instant case he has filed the suit long after 3 years of his attaining majority. As per his admission he was aged about 28 years on 9.5.1995. So in any view of the matter the suit is barred by limitation. The appellate Court being failed to consider the question of limitation as per law the impugned judgment and decree are not sustainable in law and is liable to be set aside.

Md. Anwar Hossain @ Anu Vs. Md. Lal Miah 14BLT(HCD)519

 

Section — 115(1) read with Arbitration Act, 1940,

Section —8(1)(b)

Whether the dispute was referable by all means to an arbitrator because the work was duly completed.

When an arbitration clause contains an absentee, as in the present one, the court could assume jurisdiction when such riders remain unfulfilled. It is nobody’s case that persons designata issued the necessary certificate —It is not, as the revisional forum against a decision under section 8(i)(a) of the Arbitration Act 1940 open to us to make a finding, of facts on the question as to whether the work has been completed or not since the dispute, in the absence of a certificate, is not referable to the Arbitration, question of appointment of an arbitrator under section 8, is a state one. By directing the parties to supply the name of Arbitrators the ‘learned, court below, sine dubio acted beyond the shallow jurisdiction section 8(1)(a) confrere upon it.

Bangladesh Bank Vs. Md. Kasedul Haque Majumder 15 BLT (HCD)11

 

Section-115 (1) read with Contract Act, 1872 Section- 11

A minor cannot enter a contract for sale of any land so also a mother of a minor without being empowered from a Court of law cannot enter into a contract for transfer of land. Held: In view of the above both the Courts below have committed an error of law resulting in an error in the decision occasioning a failure of justice in granting a relief against law and the judgment and decree impugned in this Ru1e is liable to be set aside.

Hanif Chowdhury Vs. M. Hasan Ali & Anr 15 BLT (HCD)415

 

Section-115(1) read with Evidence Act, 1872 Section-73

Both the Courts below has committed an error of law resulting in an error in the decision occasioning a failure of justice on Misreading Ext. Ka and non-reading evidence of DWs, as contended by the learned Advocate for the defendant-petitioner.

It appears from the record that the Plaintiff has filed the suit wherein she has written in her name as Lilifa Khatun. He executed a vokalatnama as Lilifa Khatun. She also executed vokalatnama before the appellate Court by writing her name as Lilifa Khatun. Before this Court she has submitted vokalatnama as Lilifa Khatun. But in Ext. ‘Ka’ it appears that the name of the Plaintiff has been written as Lilifa Begum. Moreover the signature as contained in the vokalatnama and the signature contained in the Ext. Ka does not tally. It appears to me that both the Courts below have given their anxious consideration in considering the, Ext. ‘Ka’ and have not committed any error of law resulting in an error in the decision occasioning failure of justice.

Md. Shermat Ali Vs. Lilifa Khatun 15 BLT (HCD)439

 

Section-115(1) read with State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950

Section 96

It appears that the only dispute is with regard to the co-sharership of the pre-emptor in the case holding. The trial court has found that the pre-emptor is a co-sharer is the case holding by purchase while the lower appellate court has found that the preemptor is not a co-sharer in the case holding by purchase. —Held; the learned Appellate court Misconstrued the schedule of the property as described in the kabala dated 4.2.91 in as much as in the said kabala dated 4.2.91 C. S. Khatian No.82 along with plot Nos. has been mentioned, C.S. Khatian No.82 in the kabala dated 4.2.9 1 and C.S. Khatian 82 in the schedule of the case land being the same, it can be concluded that the pre-emptor is a co-sharer by purchase in the case holding. The trial court has noticed that the pre-emptee did not challenge that the pre-emptor is not a co-sharer in the case holding by purchase. It thus appears that the learned Subordinate Judge has committed an error of law in reversing the decision of the trial court on the finding that the pre-emptor is not a co-sharer by purchase in the case holding which has resulted in an error in the impugned decision occasioning failure of justice and cal is for interference.

Mozahar Ali Dewan Vs. Md. Tomizuddin Mondal & Anr. 16 BLT (HCD) 190

 

Section —115(1) read with Order 21 rule 32(1)

In the present case, I find that during the existence of a decree passed by the trial Court which has been affirmed by the Court of appeal below, the present petitioners who are the defendant; dispossessed the plaintiff opposite party from the suit land although the plaintiff has a decree in his favour for permanent injunction and after dispossessing the plaintiffs, the defendant as petitioners filed the present Civil Revision. The petitioners have flouted the Court’s order and showed disrespect and dishonour to the judgments and decrees passed by Courts which is a total disregard for the machinery of justice and with a criminal attitude, after dispossessing the plaintiffs and getting into the possession of the suit land, filed a suit for simple declaration of title. The defendant petitioners have committed a criminal offence by disobeying a decree of permanent injunction and the decree shall be enforced by resort of Order 21 Rule 32(1) of the Code of Civil Procedure.

Md. Zia Bepari & Ors Vs. Sheikh Abu Taher 16 BLT (HCD) 210

 

Section —115(1) read with State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950,

Section-95A

I am of the view that a transaction of an out and out sale attended by an unregistered deed of reconveyance constitutes a complete Usufructuary mortgage for a maximum period of 7 years and the mortgagor is permitted to pray for recovery of possession by way of redemption of mortgage It is true that the impugned judgment was in favour of the defendant and thus cud not file any revision before this court but the power under section 115(1) of the Code of Civil Procedure is wide enough to exercise its supervisory power to pass a necessary and proper order to meet ends of justice when the matter has been brought before this court by any of the parties to the suit.

Ranjit Sharma & Ors Vs. Nikunja Behari Sharma 16 BLT (HCD) 213

 

Section-115(1) and Section-151

Section-115(1) of the Code can be invoked only for correcting error of law resulting in an error in the decision occasioning failure of justice. Section 1 15 of the Code should not be confused with Section 151 thereof.

Md. Raziur Rahman Bangladesh & Ors. Chowdhury Vs. 9BLT (AD)-147

 

Section-132(1)

Court has no power to refuse the right under S. 132— Trial Court is directed to appoint another Commissioner to record the deposition of plaintiff at her residence on Commission.

Rabeya Khanam Vs. Asstt. Comn. Housing & Settlement & Ors. 3BLT (HCD)-160

 

Section- 139 read with The Evidence Act, 1872

Section-2

Ext.9. the affidavit sworn before the Presidency Magistrate in India —This exhibit has been filed as a documentary evidence in this case and duly proved. The onus of rebuttal that the affidavit is not validly executed and authenticated is on the defendants and they having not done so it is admissible as a piece of documentary evidence.

Abdul Karim & Ors. Vs. Mvi. Serajuddin Ahmed & Ors. 7BLT (AD)-160

 

Sections-144 and 151

It is clear that dispossession was done not on the strength of any decree passed by the Civil Court but it was done on the strength of a notice which was found to be illegal and of no legal effect by the High Court Division — the High Court Division it appears though found that Section 144 of the Code is applicable but even if it is found that this provision is not applicable as submitted by the learned Additional Attorney General but when the plaintiffs were dispossessed on the basis of a notice which was found to be illegal by the High Court Division the civil court can exercise its inherent power under Section 151 of the Code in such a case and in the present case this discretionary exercise of power has not run counter to the interest of justice.

Military Estate Officer & Ors. Vs. SK. Mohammad Ali & Ors. 10BLT (AD)-2

 

 

Section- 148

In a case where a court passes a decree for specific performance of contract the court retains the jurisdiction to extend time under section 148 of the Code of Civil Procedure, even though the decree contains a default clause that in default of the plaintiff to make the requisite payment within the period fixed by the court the suit shall stand dismissed.

Idris Shaikh Vs. Jilamon Bewa & Ors 6BLT (AD)-123

 

Section- 148 read with Section-151

Plaintiff filed an application under Order 9 Rule 9 of the Code of Civil Procedure, learned court below allowed the case with direction that the plaintiff petitioner was to pay Tk. 300.00 as cost by 22.02.1988 in default, the application shall be deemed too. have been disallowed. On 22.02.1988 the plaintiff filed an application praying for one month’s time for depositing said Tk. 300.00 Held Since the petitioner applied for extension of time on 22.02.1988 which was within the given time, the learned court under facts and circumstances of the case and also under Section 148 read with Section 151 of the Code of Civil procedure could extend the time for deposit of the Cost.

Md. Khoda Baksha Mondal Vs. Baksha Sarder & Ors. 9BLT (HCD)-315

 

Section-148 read with State Acquisition and Tenancy Act, 1950,

Section-96(4)

Whether deposit of money under section 96(4) is mandatory

Pre-emption Proceeding —special law-the co-applicant cannot get benefit of section 148 of the Code of Civil procedure was under section 96(6) of the State Acquisition and Tenancy Act. Discretion cannot allowed nor such application can be entertained after lapse of so many years where section 96(6) specifically discloses that the applicant if not deposited the money within time it shall stand dismissed.

Md. Dabirul Islam Vs. Md. Chan Miah & Ors 15 BLT (HCD) 500

 

Section-149

An opportunity to pay the ad valorem court fee

The plaintiffs filed a suit for a declaration that the decree dated 9.1 .84 passed in O.C. Suit No. 271 of 1982 was fraudulent, void, inoperative and not binding upon the plaintiffs. Trial court passed a decree declaring that the impugned decree was not binding upon the plaintiffs as prayed for and further set aside the impugned decree. The learned District Judge and the learned Judge of the High Court Division took the view that the decree could not be set aside because the plaintiffs neither prayed for the same nor paid ad valorem court fee as required for the relief under the Law—Held The declaratory part of the decree passed by the learned Subordinate Judge is restored and the other part, namely, setting aside of the decree will also be restored provided the plaintiffs deposit ad valorem court fee in the Trial Court for the said relief within 3 (three) months from date.

Md. Umed Ali & Anr Vs. Mst. Hamida Khatoon & Anr. 6 BLT (AD)-273.

 

 

1353

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 [Section 151 - 153]

Citation: 2 BLT (AD)-182, 2BLT (HCD)-69, 3BLT (AD)-168, 3BLT (HCD)-189, 5BLT (HCD)-95, 6BLT (HCD)-88, 6BLT (HCD)-161, 7BLT (AD)-29, 7BLT(AD)-139, 7BLT (HCD)-34, 7BLT (HCD)-278, 9BLT (HCD)-37, 9BLT (HCD)-99, 9BLT (HCD)-141,9BLT (HCD)-206, 9BLT (HCD)-384, 9BLT (

Subject: Civil Procedure

Delivery Date: 1970-01-01

 

 

 

Code of Civil Procedure, 1908

Section – 151

Section 151 simply confirms Courts inherent power and this power cannot be exercised where alternative remedies, such as remedies by way of appeal, revision or review are available.

Bangladesh Vs. Luxmi Bibi & Ors. 2 BLT (AD)-182

 

 

Section- 151

Admiralty Court lacking jurisdiction as there is no cause of action to try the suit—the plaint is returned to the filing advocate without rejecting it u/s 151 C.P.C.

Madina Vegetable & Oil. Refinery Industries Vs. M.T. DOLORES 2BLT(HCD)-69

The provision of the Code of Civil Procedure was not made applicable to the Admiralty Court in the matter of rejecting the plaint hence the order u/s 151 C.P.C.

Madina Vegetable & Oil Refinery Industries Vs. M.T. DOLORES 2BLT (HCD)-69

Section-151

Inherent power of the court —Respondent No.3 Bank as plaintiff instituted money suit against respondents No.1 and 2. Suit was decreed ex parte on 27.7.72. The said decree was put into execution in Money Execution Case and filed an application under Order 21 Rule 30 of the Cr.P.C. before, the executing court. Executing Court allowed the said application and public auction was accordingly held on 5.11.88— respondents No 1 and 2 filed an application under section 151 of the Cr.P.C. for cancellation of the auction sale and the execution of the auction sale and the execution court on 27.1.90 was pleased to allow the said application—the executing court has exercised a discretion after the sale become absolute and the learned Judges of the High Court Division on a wrong reliance on the case reported in 41 DLR (AD) 109 upheld the exercise of the discretion—the learned Judges did not act legally in affirming the order of the executing court.

Fariduddin Chowdhury Vs. M/S Sylhet Glass Works Ltd. & Ors. 3BLT (AD)-168

Section-151

In the instant case the defendant has disconnected the gas line on 16.3.92 long before the institution of the suit. The plaintiff has not challenged the order or the act of disconnection of the gas line. The gas line is not in continued connection as such the learned Judge acted without jurisdiction injunction on a subject matter not within the suit property. The Court cannot travel the suit beyond the suit property.

Chairman B.O.G.M.C Vs. Abdul Kashem 3BLT (HCD)-189

Section-151

The inherent power is the last reserve in the hands of the court and cannot be used to remand the case unless there is some violence to the sense of justice which cannot be remedied otherwise than by an order of remand — In the instant case all the evidences and materials were before the lower appellate court and the lower appellate court itself could have disposed of the appeal finally— this is not a case where the court could exercise inherent power under section 151 of the Code in remanding the suit to the trial court for fresh decision.

M. K. Bhuiyan & Ors. Vs. Most. Lutfunnaher Begum & Ors. 5BLT (HCD)-95

Section-151

The inherent power of the court can be resorted to in the interest of justice only when there is no specific provision in the Code of Civil Procedure to meet a particular situation and that too for preventing an abuse of the process of the court or an apparent injustice.

Harendra Nath Mandal Vs. Chitta Ranjan Halder & Ors. 6BLT (HCD)-88

 

 

Section-151

Law is settled that a proceeding under section 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure cannot be resorted to where there is alternative remedy available for seeking redress. The inherent power conferred under section 151 of the Code can be available in a case where there is no other provision for providing a redress. Power under section 151 of the Code can be invoked by a court only when the court is satisfied that prevention of the abuse of the process of the court is necessary or when ends of justice demand that the wrong complained of would be remedied. In the name of ends of justice, the remedy provided in the Code itself cannot be allowed to be negative and also to be thwarted. The court, of course, under section 151 of the Code preserves the power to set aside order passed under Misapprehension of facts when true facts are brought to light. The court also got the inherent power to vacate any order obtained by Misleading the court and practicing fraud upon it. The court, in the exercise of the power under section 151 of the Code, also, can collect the unintentional or inadvertent mistake committed by it. The court also preserves the inherent power to vacate any order if the same is passed under Misapprehension of law. But the power cannot be invoked in cases which would result in overriding the express provision of law.

Amirunnessa & Ors. Vs. Abdul Mannan & Ors. 6BLT (HCD)-161

Section-151

The plaintiff petitioner instituted Title Suit No. 92 of 1987 (was renumbered as Title Suit No. 53 of 1989) for recovery of possession of the suit properties. In the ex parte disposal of the suit the learned Assistant Judge dismissed the same on 7.2.90. But in Civil Revision 962 of 1990, preferred by the petitioner, a Single Bench of the High Court Division on 7.2.91 decreed the suit. The petitioner however, instituted Execution Case No.1 of 1992— Respondent Nos. 1 and 2 as representatives of the deity on 15.11.80 instituted Title Suit No. 1085 of 1980 (was renumbered as Title Suit No. 225 of 1986) for declaration of her title to the suit land. The present petitioner is a party in the case of Title Suit No. 225 of 1986 and that the petitioner in his suit did not implead the plaintiff of Title Suit No. 225 of 1986 as party—Held: The High Court Division in the facts and circumstances of the case has rightly refused to interfere with the discretion exercised by the executing court under section 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure in the interest of justice staying further proceeding of the execution case pending disposal of Title Suit No. 225 of 1986.

M. A. Salek Vs. Sree Sree Kripamaya Kali Mata & Ors. 7BLT (AD)-29

Section-151

Whether the judgment-debtor-respondents could seek the remedy by filing an application under Section 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure wherein he challenged the execution proceeding itself as illegal and without jurisdiction and prayed for restoration of possession as an ancillary relief after setting aside the entire execution proceeding

It is to be stated at the outset that the decree of the trial court as passed in Title Suit No. 4 of 1994 was modified by the High Court of the then East Pakistan on 22.3.60. The decree of the trial court having been modified by the High Court it merged into the decree of the High Court. Hence, the question of drawing up of a modified decree on 9.8.93 in the light of the judgment and decree of the High Court in First Appeal is wholly illegal and without jurisdiction. It is found that the modified decree was passed on 22.3.1960 and to avoid the question of limitation a modified decree was again drawn up by the trial court on 9.8.93 and which is so obvious that it was obtained from a court by fraudulent means. Even if, it is admitted that a Mistake was committed by the executing court itself even then there are innumerable authorities of this court to hold that any error or wrong committed by the court itself can be corrected in exercise of its jurisdiction under Section 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure to secure the ends of justice and to prevent the abuse of process of court. Thus, the execution proceeding is apparently barred under Article 182 of the Limitation Act. The plaintiff did not take any steps within three years from the modified decree of the High Court nor he kept alive the decree by taking steps to execute the decree within 12 years from the date of the final modified decree. Thus in order to avoid the bar of limitation the plaintiff fraudulently got the modified decree drawn up by the trial court. Hence the application, under Section 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure is maintainable in the facts of the present case. Further, the plaintiff got decree for 8 Anna’s share of the suit property as modified by the High Court. In the execution proceeding the application was filed by the decree-holder for partition and for possession. Without filing a partition suit the executing court cannot also pass an order for possession when the decree itself does not contemplate such possession by partition of the property by metes and bounds. This exercise of jurisdiction by the executing court is palpably erroneous and without jurisdiction.

M. Majid Vs. Iqbal Bahar Chowdhury & Ors. 7BLT(AD)-139

Section-151

If the plaintiff petitioners are aggrieved in any way due to their own Mistakes, they may seek remedy in an appropriate forum, if so advised, but they are not certainly entitled to get a remedy under Section 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure to rectify substantive Mistakes affecting the merit of the decision. Section 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure is no doubt a special preserve of the Court for doing even-handed justice under given circumstances but the Court is not competent to exercise its inherent power in any and every matter which is not sanction by law.

Harun-Or-Rashid & Ors. Vs. Quyum Khan & Ors. 7BLT (HCD)-34

Section-151

Inherent power of the Court to do justice

It is well-settled that no party to a proceeding should suffer due to the act of the Court, one of the first and highest duties of the Court being to take care that its act does not cause any injury to any of the suiters. It will be quite harsh and inequitable if the illegal action of the Commissioner on the basis of a writ issued to him in violation of the provision of law is allowed to stand, driving the aggrieved party to have recourse to other ardorous, costly and time-consuming exercise for getting back possession in the suit property from which it has been dispossessed illegally. In such a case, exercise of the inherent power of the Court under Section 151 C.P.C. is clearly permissible.

Md. Mizanur Rahman Khan & Anr. Vs. Mrs. Jinnatul Ferdous & Ors. 7BLT (HCD)-278

Section- 151

Inherent powers of the Court

Ordinarily the court does not exercise its power under Section 151 whenever a remedy is available to the aggrieved party under any provision of C. P. C But when the disputed order has been obtained by practicing fraud upon the Court or it has been occasioned due to the fault of the Court, it can certainly undo the wrong in exercise of its inherent power.

Procedural laws are devised to advance the cause of justice and not to obstruct it is the name of any technicality.

Md. Refat Ali & Ors. Vs. Govt. of Bangladesh & Ors. 9BLT (HCD)-37

Section-151

The inherent jurisdiction of the court under Section- 151 of the Civil Procedure Code can be invoked subject to the rule that if the Code contains specific provisions, which would meet the necessities of the case, such provisions should be followed, instead of invoking the inherent jurisdiction of the court.

Bibhu Ranjan Das Vs. Hakim Ali & Ors 9BLT (HCD)-99

Section-151

Power under section- 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure is a power inherent in the Court by virtue of its duty to do justice between the parties. The section does not confer new powers on court but only to save inherent power to make orders necessary for the ends of justice, Section 151 of the Code is only a legislative recognition of well known doctrine and principle that every court got inherent power to act ex debito justitae and to do that real justice for the administration of which alone it exists court acts ex debito justitae according to equity justice and good conscience of a cause and in consonance with sound judicial principle and also fundamental laws and judicial procedure.

Rotis Chandra Das Vs. Sudhir Chandra 9BLT (HCD)-141

 

 

Section-151

Recourse to section 151 for rejection of a plaint can be resorted to in exceptional cases where if the suit is allowed to continue, it would amount to an abuse of the process of the court or in cases where the plaint was signed by a person not authorized to sign the same and the plaintiff did not remedy the defect when called upon to do so.

Aminur Rahman Khan Vs. Trade Aris Insurance. 9BLT (HCD)-206

Section-151

Dismissal of suit for default is illegal where the suiter died before passing of the order of dismissal.

Inherent power — Apart from Section 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure the court possesses an inherent power to rectify its Mistake committed inadvertently.

Afitan Nessa & Ors. Vs. Bangladesh & Ors. 9BLT (HCD)-384

Section-151

Whether the Court deferred the date of argument and fixed the case for further hearing.

Held: From the facts as has been narrated it is palpably clear that the case was fixer on several dates and for securing the ends of justice and for proper adjudication of the issue the trial Judge exercised his judicial discretion and deferred the date of argument and ultimately fixed the case for further hearing.

Mrs. Hosne Ara Begum & Anr Vs. Islami Bank Bangladesh Ltd. 9BLT (AD)-1

Section-151

Inherent power of the Court

Section-151 of the Code is not an alternative remedy for appeal or revision but it is the special preserve of the Court to be exercised only under special circumstances for preventing an apparent injustice or an abuse of the process of the Court and for administering even handed justice, for which alone the Court exists. A casual exercise of power under this section of law on any illusory ground is never contemplated in law.

Md. Israil Vs. Zilla Parishad, Rangpur 8BLT(HCD)-163

Section-151
